item.title: re: The Consensus Conference On NET-Liver-Metastases - London Dec 13th 2012
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
The Consensus Conference On NET-Liver-Metastases - London Dec 13th 2012 
Comment: Last week’s meeting provided a useful insight into the positioning pros and cons of NET treatments beyond the targeted and biological therapies e.g. radio-frequncy ablation, liver directed embolization therapies, PRRT, priomary surgical resection and transplantation. These therapeis are already quite widely deployed but the need for more definitive comparative controlled trials was underlined as was such data for adjuvant and neoadjuvant therapeutic approaches..  ...
6%–93% of patients with NETs will find Liver metastases (LMs) involved at the time of diagnosis and LMs significantly worsen the prognosis of patients with NET.
Nevertheless, there is considerable controversy regarding the optimal management of GEP-NET metastases. Surgical interventions for LMs have consistently been shown to have superior outcomes to non-operative therapies, but they are limited to only 10% of these patients, due to excessive metastatic tumor burden in difficult locations.
Among treatment options for patients that are not surgical, it looks that SSAs and PRRT are considered as methods of choice in selected conditions based on already sufficient level of evidence and with expectations for promising results from forthcoming investigations.
In order to document briefly the above sentences, please find the following figures:
- The 5-year survival of NET patients with LMs on supportive care is 0%–20%. (as a comparison, The median survival probabilities in patients with G1/G2 NETs who had localized, regional, and distant disease are 82%, 38% & 25 %, respectively.
- Also 50% of all patients with reported disease stage have either regional or distant metastases at diagnosis (please refer to Yao JC et al., 2008 J Clin Oncol 26:3063-3072 for wider information).
- Grades of recommendation for alternative treatment options in neuroendocrine liver metastases are available in , with ( as a reminder) “Standard medical therapies prescribed for distant or recurrent neuroendocrine tumors include long-acting somatostatin analogues (octreotide and lanreotide) for both palliation of hormonal symptoms and for the control of tumor growth. Grade of recommendation A” (highest level of evidence).
As explained on the E-AHPBA website of the organization of the Consensus Conference (NET-Liver-Mets), 300 worldwide experts from key societies were expected to attend this meeting whereas the hot topics are extensively discussed and reviewed well in advance by working groups of key people, named expert panels.
Thanks to CI-Digest and Jacquelyne Cantle who reported this event, we understand that
- Liver metastases not only render the resection of primary tumor or local regional surgical treatments limited and questionable, but their benefit on long-term survival and patient quality of life has been poorly investigated. (NB: postoperative mortality is high and surgery could lead to disabling and chronic complications such as short bowel syndrome.
- Also, although liver transplantation is uncommonly performed in NET, it appears for the attending experts that
  • Liver transplantation is a reasonable option for NET patients with LM, according that disease is well-differentiated with a moderate tumor burden;
  • A worldwide transplant registry of NET patients with liver metastases is needed.
- Rate of recurrence post liver resection is high (50-80%) and highlights the need for adjuvant strategies (with an expected role of SSAs ? please refer to Chung MH et al. Surgery 2011; 130: 954-962 ).
- Of course, therapeutical methods are the same as currently investigated in the whole scope of NETs, including chemotherapy, MTT, SSA, PRRT, Intra-Arterial …
  • From Van Gulik’s communication (unpublished trial data) it is indicating a 30% response with PRRT in terms of downsizing after 6 months;
  • Still on PRRT, -as reported by Jacquie-, D Kweekboon noted that the maximum effect of therapy is generally seen at 6 months post treatment and even can be later
  • D Kweekboon’s slide seems to show that globally PRRT results from CT in NETs are the same with Lu vs Gamma-DOTATOC with respective disease response ranges of [17%-31%] and [4%-33%]…to be confirmed indeed.
  • Other information on PRRT “picked-up” among Jacquie’s one :
    • PFS is the outcome parameter to be used ++
    • Patients with stable disease and progression have the same response (on PFS) to PRRT.
    • PNET responds to PRRT shorter than Midgut NET
  • Extensive liver involvement is a negative predictive factor for response to PRRT
- Finally, concerning neo-adjuvant and adjuvant therapies, there is no clear evidence to date that an effect on Overall Survival and PFS can be expected in patients after LM resection. However, there is considerable disagreement about what type of trial would be best and which patients should be included, some arguing that there was more of case to be made for pNET downsizing than for carcinoid.
To conclude, it must be mentioned that all topics treated during the meeting are listed and available at page and it must be opportunistically noted that conference outputs can be followed up as a summary is expected to be published in a high impact factor journal.

item.title: 2012 in emerging markets growth and investment
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment : 2012 growth rates in emerging markets have continued to outstrip those in the developed markets by a notable margin for Big Pharma.
Despite a global economic slowdown, increased government focus on drug prices in some key emerging markets, and the realisation that not all of these territories are immune to the impact of patent expiries, emerging markets will remain a key focus in 2013 and beyond by virtue of their likely sustainable growth opportunity.
Source : Firstword, Annual Reviews Desk, December 20th, 2012

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Court rules Medivation has no rights to ARN-509
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment : a California state court ruled that Medivation Inc. does not have rights to ARN-509, a second-generation androgen receptor antagonist from Aragon Pharmaceuticals Inc.
In February 2011, Medivation filed suit against the University of California and Aragon alleging that the university breached a 2005 deal with Medivation when it granted Aragon rights to ARN-509, which Medivation said is based on technology similar to its prostate cancer drug Xtandi enzalutamide. Under the 2005 deal, Medivation has rights to the university's small molecule androgen receptor antagonists, including Xtandi. The court ruled Medivation has exclusive rights to a specific series of compounds identified by a chemical structure that does not include ARN-509, which is in Phase II testing for castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC).
The court has not yet ruled on Medivation's claim that the university improperly disclosed information to Aragon about the compounds covered in the 2005 deal. The companies could not be reached for comment.
Source : BioCentury Extra for Wednesday, December 26, 2012

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Novel medicines approved in 2012
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment : in a recent report issued by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) “Fiscal Year 2012 Innovative Drug Approvals,” the agency highlighted 35 new drug approvals. This marks the second year in a row where FDA has issued 35 approvals and continues the trend of more annual approvals than in years past.
In addition, FDA approved 77 percent of these drugs on the first review cycle without the need for additional information. Of the 35 drugs, 32 were also approved in other countries, and in these cases, FDA was the first to approve 75 percent of the time. The list includes a total of 10 drugs to treat cancer, as well as important new therapies for HIV and macular degeneration. The proportion of these drugs from small biopharmaceutical companies is also significant. Many are the companies’ first-approved products. Notable drugs from small companies include Eylea for macular degeneration, Kalydeco for cystic fibrosis, Jakafi and Xtandi for cancer, and Elelyso for Gaucher disease.
Approximately one-third of the NMEs approved in the last five years have been drugs for rare diseases. In FY 2012, FDA approved 9 NMEs for rare diseases. Two of the drugs represent advances in personalized medicine (Perjeta (pertuzumab) for late-stage breast cancer and Kalydeco (ivacaftor) to treat a form of cystic fibrosis). These approvals also include nine new drugs for orphan diseases, continuing FDA’s commitment to approving drugs for patients with rare conditions.
In 2013, the European Medicines Agency expects a stable total number of applications for human medicines, with 100 applications in 2013. These include some 54 applications for new medicinal products (excluding designated orphan medicines), 20 new orphan medicines and 20 generic applications (2012: 52, 13 and 39 respectively)
Sources :
http://www.fda.gov/downloads/AboutFDA/ReportsManualsForms/Reports/UCM330859.pdf
http://www.ema.europa.eu/ema/index.jsp?curl=pages/news_and_events/news/2012/12/news_detail_001680.jsp&mid=WC0b01ac058004d5c1

Comments
I just put a focus in Oncology. FDA uses a range of tools to expedite the development, review, and approval of the most promising new therapies. These tools include Fast Track, Priority Review, and Accelerated Approval. For 2012, in oncology, 8 drugs (listed below) were approved as Fast Track drugs.
  1. Erivedge (vismodegib)for late-stage skin cancer Hedgehog inhibitor
  2. Xtandi (enzalutamide) for late-stage prostate cancer Androgen inhibitor
  3. Jakafi (ruxolitinib) for myelofibrosis Janus Associated Kinase (JAK) inhibitor
  4. Voraxaze (glucarpidase) to lower toxic levels of the chemotherapy drug methotrexate
  5. Erwinaze (asparaginase erwinia chrysthemi) for acute leukemia
  6. Stivarga (reborafenib) for late-stage colorectal cancer A multi-kinase inhibitor
  7. Perjeta (pertuzumab) for late-stage breast cancer Anti HER2 inhibitor
  8. Bosulif (bosutinib) for chronic leukemia

item.title: Scientists find new marker to measure LRRK2 activity implicated in Parkinson’s disease
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment : the biotech company Genentech recently published a paper in Science Translational Medicine suggesting that they may have in fact found such a laboratory tool to both measure abnormal LRRK2 activity that might lead to disease, and how drugs are affecting this abnormal activity.
Mutations in the LRRK2 gene are the most common cause of familial Parkinson's disease accounting for 1-2% of all cases. The protein is viewed as a promising drug target to treat Parkinson’s, but it is not possible to track LRRK2 activity in the brain, making the search for targeted therapies against the disease challenging. In this paper, researchers now provide evidence for a way to measure LRRK2 activity.
The scientists also developed a molecular screening approach to test hundreds of potential LRRK2 inhibitors. In the end, they identified one such compound, G1023, which that can block the damaging effects of the protein in rodent neurons. G1023 protected embryonic neurons taken from mice with the LRRK2 mutation, returning the growth rate of these cells to the same level as that seen in cells taken from healthy mice.
Sources :
Nature.com blogs;
see preclinical results published on Decembrer 12 in Science Translational Medicine
http://stm.sciencemag.org/content/4/164/164ra161.full
see basic patent WO 2011151360

Allergan Receives European Approval For iOAB Indication 
Comment: Allergan has announced today that it has received a positive opinion from the Irish Medicines Board for the treatment of idiopathic overactive bladder (iOAB) with symptoms of urinary incontinence, urgency and frequency in adult patients who have an inadequate response to or are intolerant to anticholinergic medications. This is an important step towards securing national licenses in all 14 European countries involved in the MRP.  ...
Ireland acted as reference member state. Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Greece, Iceland, Italy, Luxembourg, Norway, Portugal, Spain and Sweden are concerned member states of the Mutual Recognition Procedure.

item.title: USA: Unapproved Botox
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The FDA has warned 350 medical practices that they may have purchased unapproved—and potentially counterfeit—versions of Botox from a network of wholesalers controlled by Canada Drugs.
Canada Drugs, a 10-year-old Internet pharmacy based in Winnipeg,sells cheaper, foreign versions of medicines from price-controlled markets such as the U.K. and Turkey to American customers and doctors. The FDA considers the activity illegal, even when the drugs are authentic medicines, because those drugs aren't approved by the agency.
A spokeswoman for Allergan said the company learned of the suspect Botox vials from the FDA last week. In a statement, the company said, "[w]e cannot confirm the safety or authenticity of products that are imported from unauthorized distributors."
Source: Wall Street Journal 23 December 2012

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: re: FDA Advisory Committee Recommends Approval of Gattex For Short Bowel Syndrome
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Source: npsp.com 
The FDA approved Gattex on 21 December 2012. NPS said it plans to launch it in the U.S. in 1Q13 and will disclose details on the drug's pricing during a 2 January early evening conference call with investors and analysts.
The approval comes with a REMS that includes a communication plan and training for prescribers. NPS is also required to conduct a postmarketing study in SBS patients to evaluate the drug's potential increased risk of causing colorectal cancer and other conditions.
fda.gov/NewsEvent…

item.title: Novartis to Position in the "Activated Cellular Immunotherapy" Area
item.dc:creator: spoon

Comment: Novartis is to buy Dendreon's immunotherapy manufacturing facility (IMF)based in New Jersey (USA) for $43M in cash. ACI offers the potential to treat a variety of diseases
The transaction is to bring value for the company's shareholders, and will accelerate path to profitability.
To take the opportunity to work with the 100 existing employees to build out immunotherapy operations and dedevelop new treatments.
173,100 square foot sate-of-the art IMF.

item.title: Combination of BMS' Ipilimumab and Anti-KIR MAb for CRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon

Comment: FIM trial is anticipated to recruit approx. 150 participants with selected advanced tumors (NSCLC; CRPC; melanoma). Primary endpoint will assess rate of AEs and serious AEs.
Official Title: A Phase 1 Study of BMS-986015, an Anti-KIR Monoclonal Antibody, Administered With Ipilimumab, an Anti-CTLA4 Monoclonal Antibody, in Subjects With Select Advanced Solid Tumors
Start date: Dec 2012 - Completion: July 2015
Location: USA

item.title: POC Study to Assess Abiraterone and Degarelix 1M Together
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Sponsored by the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and ten collaborators among which J&J, this randomized, 3-arm trial will assess both drugs in combinaison as possible treatment for PSA recurrent prostate cancer, following definitive radical prostatectomy, as compared to abiraterone and degarelix alone. Primary endpoint will measure PFS.

Background

The FDA recently approved abiraterone acetate (Zytiga ®) in combination with prednisone to treat patients with mCRPC in the post docetaxel setting.

Degarelix (Firmagon ®), is FDA approved for the treatment of patients with advanced prostate cancer.

Objective

- to evaluate abiraterone acetate and prednisone in combination with degarelix as a possible treatment for PSA recurrent prostate cancer as compared to abiraterone acetate alone and degarelix alone.

Recruitment: approx. 120

Start date: Dec 2012 - Completion: Oct 2014

Location: USA (10 sites)

PI: Howard I Scher, MD @ the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

Source: clinicaltrials.gov


Comments
Comment: Interestingly, the trial end date was initially postponed in March 2014 from Oct 2014 to Oct 2015. Again, the trial completion has now been postponed to Oct 2016 mainly due to opening of additional clinical sites in the US. This is still a proof of concept trial as the target patient remains quite small (n=120) for a 3 arm study. At this stage, the primary focus for J&J likely remains to ensure its ARN509 market entry. (Source: clinicaltrial.gov)

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Valeant Cuts Medicis Staff
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Following the takeover of Medicis, and according to the Phoenix Business Journal, 319 Medicis employees lost their jobs.
Valeant is consolidating workforce in Arizona and New Jersey.
Commercial dermatology operations will remain in Scottsdale.
Valeant also is removing some of the functions currently in New Jersey to Arizona.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Recordati Enters Into Asset Purchase Agreement To Strengthen US Business
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Recordati has acquired a portfolio of non-core products from Lundbeck, aimed at strengthen its US operations and its rare disease portfolio. Lundbeck, meanwhile, wishes to exit these areas to focus on its core CNS business.
Deal Terms
As part of the transaction Recordati has acquired rights to 8 products with annual revenues of approximately $45m in 2011.
The total cost of the purchase will be $100m with $80m paid uprfront upon closing during the Q113 and the further $20m subject to product registration transfers.
Nature Of The Product Portfolio
The acquired portfolio will be marketed in the U.S. by Recordati Rare Diseases, a wholly-owned U.S. corporation. The main product in the portfolio is Panhematin® (haemin for injection) for the amelioration of recurrent attacks of acute intermittent porphyria. Other important drugs acquired are NeoProfen® (ibuprofen lysine injection) and Indocin® I.V. (indomethacin injection), indicated to close a clinically significant patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in premature infants, and Cosmegen® (dactinomycin for injection) used mainly in the treatment of three rare cancers: Wilms’ tumor, childhood rhabdomyosarcoma and choriocarcinoma. The portfolio also includes Chemet® (succimer) indicated for the treatment of lead poisoning in pediatric patients, Desoxyn® (methamphetamine hydrochloride) indicated for the treatment of attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in children over 6 years of age and for the short-term treatment of exogenous obesity, and other minor products.
The acquisition of this portfolio of products is a confirmation of Recordati’s intention to become a leading player in rare diseases worldwide and it will reinforce Recordati’s entry into the Hematology and Oncology fields
Yesterday Lundbeck announced a downward revision of its financial forecasts based on the need to invest signficantly in product launches and development.
Source: www.recordati.it and www.lundbeck.xom

Comments
Recordati has completed its acquisition of a portfolio of H. Lundbeck’s non-core products. Recordati paid Lundbeck $80 million at closing. Recordati said it expects 2013 revenues for the acquired portfolio to be about $40 million.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: New US Reimbursement Codes For Botox Procedures In Chronic Migraine and OAB
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Leerink and Swann analysts have noted in a reported issued on Tuesday that starting January 2013, the official US CPT code for migraine will reduce physician's estimated reimbursement by 40-50%, whilst the new CPT code for OAB is positive for the forthcoming approval and launch of the iOAB indication.
Migraine Situation
With the official code, the estimated procedure reimbursement for chronic migraine is expected to decrease from $350 and$300 to $200 and $150 for commercial and Medicare respectively.
Lerrink's small survey of neurologists seems to indicate that a cut was expected and thit was not expected to impact their prescribing.
OAB situation
Currently urologists are reimbursed $400 per Botox procedure (both commercial and Medicare). With the new CPT code the commercial rate will remain the same whilst the Medicare rate will reduce to $300. Notably the CPT code will cover all overactive bladder indications, a clear positive for Allergan in terms of hitting the ground running once the iOAB indication is approved.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Portugal to Revise Basket of Reference Countries 
Comment: Slovenia and Spain are expected to remain on the list, and France to be replaced by Italy.  ...
Correction: According to the new law and with confirmation of the Portuguese team, the previous reference basket was Spain Italy and Slovenia. And now the current reference basket in Portugal is France, Spain and Slovakia as from January 2013.

item.title: Fast Track Status for Lexicon's LX1033 (IBS-d)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: LX1033, an inhibitor of tryptophan hydroxylase (TPH) that acts locally in the gastrointestinal tract, is currently being evaluated in Ph2 (results expected Q1:13).
Lexicon also has FDA Fast Track status for telotristat etiprate, or LX1032, an oral, systemic TPH inhibitor currently in Ph3 for carcinoid syndrome.
Source: Lexicon

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Portugal to Revise Basket of Reference Countries
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Slovenia and Spain are expected to remain on the list, and France to be replaced by Italy.
According to Diário Económico – which has seen an internal document of the Government on the sixth review of a troika of the European Commission, IMF, and European Central Bank – Portugal's drug regulator, Infarmed will be responsible for introducing the second price change in the 2013. According to the source, under the law, the retail price of drugs is defined on the basis of prices prevailing for the same drug in the reference countries. However, if the comparison will result in higher prices than the current price, the current price will remain. Thus, comparison with the reference countries should not result in an increase in drug prices. According to Diário Económico, the prices of drugs are expected to reduce further in 2013, with an average variation in price expected to be 8% in 2013.
As part of Portugal's agreement with the troika signed in 2011, several policies were introduced that were aimed at reducing the budget deficit in return for a financial bailout. In the health sector, these included reducing expenditure on drugs through introducing a new basket of reference countries – Spain, Italy, and Slovenia, as well as restricting the price of generics to no more than 50% of the branded product with the same active ingredient.
It is noteworthy that in the fifth review of the Memorandum of Understanding between Portugal and the troika, it was agreed that the government was to implement an annual revision of medicines, as well as that of the reference countries, aimed at attaining further savings in costs. The potential change in reference countries aimed at further price reductions therefore reflects the government's continuing cost-containment policies with the aim of reducing the overall spend on pharmaceuticals 1 % of GDP in 2013.
Source: Global Insight

Comments
Correction: According to the new law and with confirmation of the Portuguese team, the previous reference basket was Spain Italy and Slovenia. And now the current reference basket in Portugal is France, Spain and Slovakia as from January 2013.
Contact initiated with the provider of the initial information.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Drug Sales in Brazil Increased 7.6% m/m in October
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The growth in sales experienced by the Brazilian pharmaceutical industry in the branded and generics sectors is linked to the expansion of the domestic industry as more money is being invested into the sector by the government and international brands operating in the country. The Brazilian pharmaceutical sector is expected to double its sales volume in the next five years, with more investment in the sector. Generics account for a consistent part of this outcome, with patients increasingly gaining more confidence in the generics sector and the market growing accordingly. According to Geraldo Monteiro, executive director of the Brazilian Association of National Pharmaceutical Laboratories (ABRADILAN), cited by Investimentos e Noticias, the expansion of the Brazilian domestic industry in terms of sales and volume is sizeable, especially in the generics segment.
Monteiro said that the Brazilian population has increasingly gained confidence in using generics drugs as a more affordable alternative to branded drugs, with generics accounting for 26.5% of total units sold in Brazil. According to the source, the national laboratories associated to ABRADILAN represent 22% of the country's laboratories that produce generics, distributing their generic products to 82% of Brazilian cities and 77% of the 71,000 pharmacies in the country; specifically 82% of the pharmacies in the Southeast, 75% in the South, 80% in the Northeast, 83% in the Central East, and 34% in the North regions of the country.

The growth in sales experienced by the Brazilian pharmaceutical industry in the branded and generics sectors is linked with the expansion of the domestic industry as more money is being invested into the sector by the government. Brands operating in the country are also focusing on upgrading investments in Brazil, which is one of the top Latin American markets, hence the increase in branded sales.
In terms of generics, the increase in sales and revenues volumes is a consequence of the strong pro-generics policy of President Dilma Rousseff, which is leading to a strengthening of the domestic industry and encouraging domestic production of drugs, taking advantage of the many branded products that are going off patent. The Brazilian generic industry is forecast to flourish in the short-to-medium term, placing itself as one of the strongest generics markets in the Americas. Current price-control policies being implemented on branded drugs in the country are also another element in favour of generics, as the wide use of generics in the public sector would help the government to cut the national healthcare budget significantly.
The Brazilian pharmaceutical sector is expected to double its sales volume in the next five years, with more investment in the sector from the government and international brands operating in the country. The new pro-generics era envisaged by Rousseff's government is likely to further boost the domestic generic sector in the country – the most profitable in Latin America – with major international generics giants eyeing opportunities to invest in the country.
Source: Global Insight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: South Korean Pricing Pressures See GSK and Pfizer to Reduce Staff Numbers
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: According to a report in the Korea Herald, GSK has offered early retirement packages to up to 100 employees, out of a total of 750 in the country, expected to take effect before the end of this year. Although Pfizer has not issued details regarding the exact nature of its plans, a similar downsizing in staff is also expected to take place, the first restructuring since the company first entered South Korea in 1969.
GSK and Pfizer are joining a number of multinational pharma firms in downsizing their workforce numbers in South Korea; the source reports that the local subsidiaries of Bayer (Germany), Janssen Korea (subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson, US), Sanofi (France), and AstraZeneca (UK) have all undergone similar restructuring in recent months.
Such moves reflect the South Korean government's increasing desire to suppress drug prices as the country's population continues to age: in April 2012, 13,800 medicines, including 6,500 types of prescription medicines, saw their prices slashed by 14%.
The South Korean market is generally becoming more competitive for innovative firms, with the government targeting ingrained corrupt practices in the pharma industry, and generic competition increasing, as Pfizer has experienced with generic competition against Viagra (sildenafil) earlier this year.
Sorce: Global Insight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Allergan Receives European Approval For iOAB Indication
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan has announced today that it has received a positive opinion from the Irish Medicines Board for the treatment of idiopathic overactive bladder (iOAB) with symptoms of urinary incontinence, urgency and frequency in adult patients who have an inadequate response to or are intolerant to anticholinergic medications. This is an important step towards securing national licenses in all 14 European countries involved in the MRP.
The positive opinion which is specfic to Botox is based on Allergan's successful global phIII programme which was reported earlier this year (see Neurology6332: Allergan's R&D Day Highlights New Therapeutic Opportunities For Botox & Its Novel TEM Programme). Regulatory filings were made in March with first approvals at that time anticipated in Q1:13.
Allergan's European President Douglas Ingram notes in the press release that "this is a critical milestone for the company extending its commitment to urology beyond neurogenic detrusor overactivity and building on a long-term commitment to innovation in botulinum toxin research".
The positive opinion is based on the results of two randomised placebo-controlled phIII studies involving over 1,100 patients. In these studies patients ecperienced a significant and clinically relevant response to treatment compared to placebo in the reduction of urinary incontinence, including more patients becoming dry ( no urinary leakage at 12 weeks). Patients also reporeted an improvement in their QOL.
The most common adverse events reported were urinary tract infection and dysuria (painful urination).
Source: allergan.com

Comments
Ireland acted as reference member state. Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Greece, Iceland, Italy, Luxembourg, Norway, Portugal, Spain and Sweden are concerned member states of the Mutual Recognition Procedure.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Teva Creates Business Ventue in South Korea
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The venture with Handok Pharm., expected to begin operations in the next few months, is a strategic fit for Teva and the first commercial deal in East Asian territory outside Japan.
Teva's plans in S-Korea include selling Copaxone (for MS).
Teva will contribute for manufacturing and supplying a wide range of "affordable and innovative medicines".
Handok will assume responsibility for sales and marketing, distribution and regulatory affairs.
Financial terms are not disclosed.
  • Founded: 1954
  • Focus: prescription and OTC
  • The company has a strong tradition of partnerships.
  • Its vision is to be the top 3 Korean pharma companies by 2016.
Source: Teva; Handok
  1. ScreenCapture1.jpg  (56,8 KB)

item.title: New Development Candidate Moves In To Clinical Development For ALS
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Phytopharm announced today plans for the clinical development of Cogane for ALS based on successful preclinical data.

In collaboration with two leading grant bodies the ALS Association and the North-East ALS Consortium and the Masachusetts General Hospital, Phytopharm is to move forward with a clinical study.

The company is also in discusion with leading regulatory agencies with regard to the design of a clinical development programme for Cogane in ALS. The drug has been granted ODS in both the US and Europe for ALS.

In parallel Phytopharm has been completing a 400 patient phII trial of Cogane in early-stage Parkinson's disease (CONFIDENT-PD). All patients have now completed the trial and the company is on track to receive the results from the trial in Feb 2013.

Whilst the progression of the ALS programme is not wholly dependent on the outcome of the PD trial its results may inform the design and conduct of future studies in ALS.

Source: phytopharm.com


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Otsuka Signs Cell Therapy Deal For Parkinson's Disease
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Living Cell Technologies today announced an agreement with Otsuka pharmaceuticals to co-develop NTCELL a cell therapy for the treatment of Parkinson's disease and other neurological disorders.
What Type of Cell Therapy Is NTCELL?
NTCELL is pig choroid plexus cells which have been encapsulated ith IMMUPEL, LTC's proprietary immune-protective capsule system which precents the immune system rejecting the pig cells as foreign.
Development Status
LCT has received approval from Medsafem New Zealnad medicines regulator and ethics approval for the first clinical trial to comence in early 2013.
Key Terms Of The Agreement
1. Otsuka and LCT will form a co-development partnership to undertake the phI trial in PD during 2013 and 2014. Otsuka will fund all costs.
2. In consideration of the partnership Otsuka will make a $3m upfont payment to LC, plus an additional $2m milestone payment when the first patient in the trial has been safely implanted with NTCELL. This milestone is expected to occur in Q213.
3. Upon exercise of an option LCT will vest the NTCELL IP for use in developing treatments for neurological diseases and hearing loss into DIATRANZ OTSUKA Ltd a 50:50 JC formed between LCT and Otsuka in November 2011. At the same time Otsuka will invest and additional $20m of capital into DOL to fund the clinical development of NTCELL in Parkinson's through to market approval. Both companies will retain a 50% interest in DOL.
4. LCT will retain the exclusive right to develop NTCELL for the treatment of other non-neurological diseases.
Source: www. otsuka.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: The Consensus Conference On NET-Liver-Metastases - London Dec 13th 2012
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Last week’s meeting provided a useful insight into the positioning pros and cons of NET treatments beyond the targeted and biological therapies e.g. radio-frequncy ablation, liver directed embolization therapies, PRRT, priomary surgical resection and transplantation. These therapeis are already quite widely deployed but the need for more definitive comparative controlled trials was underlined as was such data for adjuvant and neoadjuvant therapeutic approaches..


Comments
6%–93% of patients with NETs will find Liver metastases (LMs) involved at the time of diagnosis and LMs significantly worsen the prognosis of patients with NET.
Nevertheless, there is considerable controversy regarding the optimal management of GEP-NET metastases. Surgical interventions for LMs have consistently been shown to have superior outcomes to non-operative therapies, but they are limited to only 10% of these patients, due to excessive metastatic tumor burden in difficult locations.
Among treatment options for patients that are not surgical, it looks that SSAs and PRRT are considered as methods of choice in selected conditions based on already sufficient level of evidence and with expectations for promising results from forthcoming investigations.
In order to document briefly the above sentences, please find the following figures:
- The 5-year survival of NET patients with LMs on supportive care is 0%–20%. (as a comparison, The median survival probabilities in patients with G1/G2 NETs who had localized, regional, and distant disease are 82%, 38% & 25 %, respectively.
- Also 50% of all patients with reported disease stage have either regional or distant metastases at diagnosis (please refer to Yao JC et al., 2008 J Clin Oncol 26:3063-3072 for wider information).
- Grades of recommendation for alternative treatment options in neuroendocrine liver metastases are available in , with ( as a reminder) “Standard medical therapies prescribed for distant or recurrent neuroendocrine tumors include long-acting somatostatin analogues (octreotide and lanreotide) for both palliation of hormonal symptoms and for the control of tumor growth. Grade of recommendation A” (highest level of evidence).
As explained on the E-AHPBA website of the organization of the Consensus Conference (NET-Liver-Mets), 300 worldwide experts from key societies were expected to attend this meeting whereas the hot topics are extensively discussed and reviewed well in advance by working groups of key people, named expert panels.
Thanks to CI-Digest and Jacquelyne Cantle who reported this event, we understand that
- Liver metastases not only render the resection of primary tumor or local regional surgical treatments limited and questionable, but their benefit on long-term survival and patient quality of life has been poorly investigated. (NB: postoperative mortality is high and surgery could lead to disabling and chronic complications such as short bowel syndrome.
- Also, although liver transplantation is uncommonly performed in NET, it appears for the attending experts that
  • Liver transplantation is a reasonable option for NET patients with LM, according that disease is well-differentiated with a moderate tumor burden;
  • A worldwide transplant registry of NET patients with liver metastases is needed.
- Rate of recurrence post liver resection is high (50-80%) and highlights the need for adjuvant strategies (with an expected role of SSAs ? please refer to Chung MH et al. Surgery 2011; 130: 954-962 ).
- Of course, therapeutical methods are the same as currently investigated in the whole scope of NETs, including chemotherapy, MTT, SSA, PRRT, Intra-Arterial …
  • From Van Gulik’s communication (unpublished trial data) it is indicating a 30% response with PRRT in terms of downsizing after 6 months;
  • Still on PRRT, -as reported by Jacquie-, D Kweekboon noted that the maximum effect of therapy is generally seen at 6 months post treatment and even can be later
  • D Kweekboon’s slide seems to show that globally PRRT results from CT in NETs are the same with Lu vs Gamma-DOTATOC with respective disease response ranges of [17%-31%] and [4%-33%]…to be confirmed indeed.
  • Other information on PRRT “picked-up” among Jacquie’s one :
    • PFS is the outcome parameter to be used ++
    • Patients with stable disease and progression have the same response (on PFS) to PRRT.
    • PNET responds to PRRT shorter than Midgut NET
  • Extensive liver involvement is a negative predictive factor for response to PRRT
- Finally, concerning neo-adjuvant and adjuvant therapies, there is no clear evidence to date that an effect on Overall Survival and PFS can be expected in patients after LM resection. However, there is considerable disagreement about what type of trial would be best and which patients should be included, some arguing that there was more of case to be made for pNET downsizing than for carcinoid.
To conclude, it must be mentioned that all topics treated during the meeting are listed and available at page and it must be opportunistically noted that conference outputs can be followed up as a summary is expected to be published in a high impact factor journal.

item.title: Enzon To Review Asset Sales Or Sale Of The Company
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment Enzon has announced that its Board of Directors has retained Lazard to act as financial advisor in a review of the possible sale or disposition of one or more corporate assets, or a sale of the Company. Its androgen receptor modulator programme is to be suspended.
Based on clinical data on the androgen receptor program, Enzon plans to suspend clinical development with a goal to conserve capital and maximize value returned to shareholders.
The press release notes that a special committee of Enzon's Board of Directors was established to oversee the review. There can be no assurance that the review will result in the consummation of any transactions.
Alex Denner, Chairman of the Board, commented: "The Board of Directors, following a review of the Company's assets and strategic direction, has determined that it is in the best interest of Enzon's shareholders to pursue a sale, in whole or in part, of the Company. In addition to a strong balance sheet and royalty revenues, Enzon's drug candidates and technologies offer the potential for a variety of transactions."
Enzon's Development Pipeline
Source: enzon.com

item.title: Recruitment Now Well Underway In The Lutathera Trial
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: NETTAR-1 an international multi-centre open label study of PRRT against high dose Sandostatin LAR, in somatostatin receptor positive progressive mid-gut carcinoid patients, has now opened centres in the US.
This announcement was made on the Caring for Carcinoid website with the following comments made:-
"This study will evaluate the safety and efficacy of Lutathera in neuroendocrine tumor patients. This is a long awaited clinical trial that is anticipated to fill up quickly. We encourage any patients that have been discussing peptide receptor radiotherapy with their physician to consider discussing this clinical trial. The trial is anticipated to accrue patients quickly to the 14 centers in the United States".
In fact AAA, the company developing Lutathera was present at the NET- Liver Metastases meeting in London last week promoting this new study.
To date, 3 patients have been treated, 4 randomised, 9 patients registered on CRFs and 18 patients are in screening. Forty-two centres will participate in the trial of which 13 are active at the moment. The trial was initiated in Europe in July 2012.
The clinical trial submission took place later in the US than elsewhere, hence the late opening of centres in this region. The US participants are as follows:-

item.title: FDA Approves Signifor For Cushing's Disease
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: On friday the FDA approved the use of Signifor for the treatment of Cushing's disease in patients who cannot be helped through surgery. Following a positive recommendation from EMDAC in early November this had been anticipated (see Endocrinology7165: FDA EMDAC Unanimously Voted in Support for the Use of Pasireotide for Cushing's Disease). There are significant post-marketing commitments associated with the approval (see below).
The FDA is requiring three postmarketing studies for Signifor: a clinical trial to assess high blood sugar (hyperglycemia) management; a long-term prospective observational cohort study (registry) of patients with Cushing’s disease treated with Signifor; and focused safety monitoring for reports of serious hyperglycemia, acute liver injury, and adrenal insufficiency.
According to Signifor's US product website the drug is likely to be launched in March 2013. Pricing information has yet to emerge.
Source. http://www.signifor.us/index.jsp?usertrack.filter_applied=true&NovaId=4029462041663896145
http://www.fda.gov/NewsEvents/Newsroom/PressAnnouncements/ucm332351.htm

item.title: Adenosine A2A Receptor Antagonist Tozadenant Meets PhIIb Endpoints
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Biotie has announced top-line data from its double-blind, international Phase IIb trial in 420 patients whose levodopa treatment was insufficient to control PD symptoms until their next dose demonstrating that twice-daily oral tozadenant met the primary endpoint of reducing mean daily “off” time.

Study Design & Key Findings

In the phIIb study, patients received placebo or twice-daily 60, 120, 180 or 240 mg tozadenant for 12 weeks.

Biotie noted that tozadenant met several secondary endpoints, including increasing “on” time in which patients were symptom free, improving UPDRS Part III and Parts I-III combined scores and improving clinician and patient-assessed global impression scores.

The study has helped Biotie to identify the minimally efficacious and maximum feasible dose.

Tozadenant was generally well tolerated.

Next Steps

Biotie, which declined to provide further details about the study, said it plans to analyze the data with partner UCB and expects a decision from UCB regarding next steps in 1Q13.

UCB, which has exclusive, worldwide rights to tozadenant will be responsible for Phase III testing and commercialization should it choose to proceed with development.

Competition

Tozadenant is one of three A2A antagonists moving forward in development for the treatment of "off episodes" in Parkinson's disease. The lead comound is Kyowa Hakko's Istradefylline (partnered with Valeant) which has a chequered history but has now been filed for approval in Japan. Meanwhile, close to completing phIII development is Merck's preladenant.

Source: www.biotie.com

item.title: re: Gilead Adds YM Biosciences Drugs to its Growing Oncology Pipeline
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Source: YM; Gilead 
International Strategy & Investment analyst Mark Schoenebaum suggests that current consensus estimates for CYT387 are around $300 million for 2020. In terms of benchmark products, Novartis and Incyte's Jakafi – approved in November 2011 and indicated for myelofibrosis and myeloproliferative disorders – is the obvious reference point. Sales of the product, to date, have been modest, although limited patient data in Phase I/II trials suggest that CTY387 may be a more efficacious product.
With Big Pharma competition in the JAK inhibitor space high, commercial projections for CTY387 may remain fairly muted.
Source: FirstWord 16 December 2012

item.title: re: New CRPC Study With Tokai's galeterone
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
New CRPC Study With Tokai's galeterone 
Comment: ClinicalTrials.gov is listing a new Ph2 study with Tokai's androgen modulator galeterone. The randomised 2 part trial will evaluate safety and efficacy in CRPC patients who have yet to receive TAK-700, ARN-509 , ketoconazole or enzalutamide as well as CRPC patients who have demonstrated progression on Zytiga.  ...
Tokai has announced the treatment of the first patient in the ARMOR2 trial. With its improved new tablet formulation, ARMOR2 will provide the company with additional important insights on the clinical utility of galeterone in several distinct CRPC patient populations.
Investigators
The study is being led by co-principal investigators Bruce Montgomery, M.D., associate professor of medical oncology at the University of Washington School of Medicine and Mary-Ellen Taplin, M.D., associate professor of medicine, director of genitourinary clinical research, Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, Harvard Medical School

item.title: Efficacy Data of Zytiga Published in the NEJM
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Results from analyses of COU-AA-302 have been published online in the NEJM. This PhIII study was the basis of the pre-chemo indication approved by the US FDA.
See Oncology8611: CHMP Recommends Approval of J&J's Zytiga.
Since its first approval in the US in 2011, Zytiga has been approved in >65 countries. More than 40,000 WW have received the treatment.


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Key Messages from Astellas' Press Conference
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Astellas is progressing with the roll-out of Eligard, which was approved last month in Hong-Kong. Gonax (degarelix 1M), launched enf of October, is expected to be a growth driver in Japan. Management highlighted that sales in China and Russia increased by 13% and 18% respectively for FY2011. Astellas Growth Strategy is to maximize OAB global sales, develop oncology franchise and improve R&D productivity. Of note, the strong initiatives of the company in the field of neglected tropical diseases (NTDs).
The company has bet on 'precision medicine' and 'multi-track R&D' approaches.

item.title: Scrip Interview with AZ's VP Strategic Partnering and Business Development
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Three quarters of Az's Phase III pipeline comes from business development activity.
During 2012 Shaun Grady has kept business development activities on track and has also concluded some innovative deals. He states that business development is at the centre of AZ's strategy and is key to how the company now discovers and develops drugs - 60% of the company's R&D leaders are new to the organization and were recruited partially with business development and externalization in mind.
AZ has a '5Rs approach' to both internal and external programmes - all need to meet the 5R criteria of right target, right tissue/exposure, right safety, right patients and right commercial.
The company does have a New Opportunities team which looks at all areas, including those that are currently off-strategy.
Grady's focus currently is on good high quality Phase III programmes. His team of about 130 look for assets via 3 routes: they look at and monitor all of the small- to mid-cap biotechs, .they look at others' pipelines and try to identify potential value that they may not have spotted and engage in late stage asset conventional licensing and collaborative deals. The third route is peer to peer transactions - assessing peer pharma company pipelines and looking for overlaps in areas that might still be considered too high risk or expensive to pursue on their own.
Source: Scrip 12 December 2012

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Bayer/Algeta's Alpharadin Submitted to the EMA for CRPC Patients with Bone Metastases
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: On August 20th, at last Bayer's Q2 financial results, management highlighted EU launch to occur in Q2/Q3:13. In Russia, the drug is expected to reach the market in the course of the next five years.
Bayer expects to submit an NDA to FDA by year end.
See Oncology8603: Algeta Provides Additional Highlights on Alpharadin.

Comments
Bayer has received notification from the FDA granting priority review of the NDA (filed in December 2012). The application is under review for the treatment of CRPC patients with bone metastases.
FDA now has 8 months to complete its review (This suggests an estimated PDUFA action date of 13 August 2013).
Analysts with Deutsche Bank "believe Alpharadin has blockbuster potential in prostate cancer alone, supported by use as an alternative to Taxotere and potential for use in combination with new oral anti-hormonals.
Benefits on bone palliation are particularly important given additional potential for repeat use in patients with bone pain at the end of life. In addition, our discussions with physicians suggest Taxotere is often used more for its palliative benefits than for its improvement in survival. The data suggests Alpharadin could be competitive in this regard and further adds to its benefits which include an improvement in overall survival (14.9 vs 11.3 mo; HR=0.695) and delay in time to skeletalrelated events (15.6 vs 9.8 mo;P< 0.001; HR = 0.66; 95% CI: 0.52-0.83)."

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Gilead Adds YM Biosciences Drugs to its Growing Oncology Pipeline
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Gilead has acquired YM for a total of $510M, all paid with cash on hand. YM's lead oncology candidate (CYT387) is a selective inhibitor of the Janus kinase family. The transaction is expected to close 1Q:13.
- to expand its R&D expertise in the area of oncology beyond antivirals.
- Idelalisib, is a specific inhibitor of the phosphoinositide-3 kinase delta isoform. Five PhIII studies in CLL and indolent NHL are progressing.
- Simtuzumab (PhII) mAB candidate targeting the human lysyl oxidase-like 2 protein for myelofibrosis, colorectal cancer pancreatic cancer, and certain fibrotic diseases.
Source: YM; Gilead
International Strategy & Investment analyst Mark Schoenebaum suggests that current consensus estimates for CYT387 are around $300 million for 2020. In terms of benchmark products, Novartis and Incyte's Jakafi – approved in November 2011 and indicated for myelofibrosis and myeloproliferative disorders – is the obvious reference point. Sales of the product, to date, have been modest, although limited patient data in Phase I/II trials suggest that CTY387 may be a more efficacious product.
With Big Pharma competition in the JAK inhibitor space high, commercial projections for CTY387 may remain fairly muted.
Source: FirstWord 16 December 2012

item.title: Galderma Joins Forces with Spirig Pharma AG
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Galderma is to acquire Spirig Pharma, a leading company in the development, production and marketing of dermatics. With 390 employees in total, Spirig generated sales of CHF98.4M in 2011. Transaction is expected to close in 2013.
- Acquisition of Spirig gives Galderma a dermato leading position in Switzerland
- Spirig's approach for protection, treatment, and prevention of dermatological conditions is closely aligned to that of Galderma.
- Galderma intends to utilize Spirig's Egerkingen location as HQs to its Swiss market operations, and as a center-of-excellence.
Focus: skin barrier function impairment; sun protection; solar damage
Lead products: Excipia® for dry and sensitive skin, Daylong®, and Daylong Actinica® for sun protection
Employees: 270 in Switzerland + 120 in international subsidiaries
Network: dermatologists, GPs, drugstores, and pharmacies
Locations: http://www.spirig.ch/en/company/locations.html

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Teva Unveils Its New Strategy At Yesterday's Analyst Meeting
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: With Jeremy Levin now acting CEO, Teva's strategic focus is undergoing a transformation with a focus on execution, modernisation and extension of its global presence. The newly established NTE platform will focus on a pipeline of differentiated medicies which will be re reasonbly priced, high vlaue and s uniquely meld together the company's generics and R&D branded products capability. Meanwhile, in terms of its specialty business, Teva will focus on its CNS (neurodegeneraton) and Respiratory pipelines with its business development activites focused upon these key areas. Oncology has been clearly de-emphasized in the new structure although custirsen's launch for CRPC is still planned for 2015.
The New R&D Strategy
The New NTE Division
The company intends to place renewed and special emphasis in the area of complex generics, improving compliance, improving convenience, improving efficacy and safety. The focus will be on areas where the business is already quite strong such as oral delivery, modified release combinations, liposomal and long-acting release products but it will also look to grow these capabilities particularly in the area of injectables, nasal, patches and devices.
It acknowledged that it wasn't the first to develop NTES but just as it was the first to scale up industrialised paragraph IV submissions in the US it intends to be the first to scale up and trully industrialise NTEs. The group's API business is central to the potential for NTEs something that needs to be closely watched in the context of Teva's capability to produce lanreotide.
In 2013 it will approve 10 to 15 NTEs, four have been approved thus far for development in 2013 and are scheduled for first launch in 2016.. No hint was given as to what might be amongst them besides three examples, possibly the ones approved so far a treatment for HIV another for schizophrenia.and the third to treat Lupus.
Plans To Sustain & Levarge CNS Business
For those interested in the full 238 slide presentation, please find a copy attached.
source:www.tevapharm.com

item.title: Toxins 2012 Intelligence Update - Allergan and Other Insights of Note
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan’s BPH trial data will read out by mid-2013 as well as the 2nd Urological indication being granted in iOAB by Q1 2013. It has also come to our attention that Allergan is the only institution given permission by the US authorities to express toxin by recombinant methods at this time point.
Allergan presence was not as heavily felt as Merz, this probably had a lot to do with Merz ‘re-introducing’ itself off the back of the injunction which will be lifted on the 9th of January. They only had six posters on display (See Allergan Poster Review) and did not sponsor any symposia.
The booth had various hand-outs in Spanish and English including the new injector checklist to schedule your training day for Chronic Migraine injections as well as post training (see attachment titled New Injector Checklist) and a leaflet on Chronic Migraine highlighting Botox as the first and only preventative treatment approved by the FDA for adults with chronic migraine.
I would like to thank Dominic Marchese, Brice Vignon, John Bruins, Eric Schultz and John Kramer for their intelligence scoops during the congress. Their insights are contained within this report — this includes intell on Allergan, recombinant toxins, Myobloc and Purtox.
A very interesting talk on comparing toxins was presented by Dr. Alberto Albanese (Milan, Italy) looking at efficacy safety and potency of the 3 marketed toxins
Key questions addressed included:
  • Is one toxin more efficacious?
  • Are there differences in the therapeutic index?
  • Relative potency of different toxin brands
  • Does relative potency vary based on injection site or indication
Dr. Albanese conducted a number of Medline searches (up to November 2012) of systematic reviews, clinical trials and observational studies on Dysort (abobotulinum), Botox (onabotulinum), Xeomin (incobotulinum) and Myobloc (rimabotulinum toxin B).
Results and summary below. Full slide deck available upon request.
Potential new product of note: Mark Hallet spoke of a BoNT A cream used for wrinkles which he is trialling for blepharospasm at his centre which will be moving into phase II at the beginning of next year. The product is called AH8 and is produced by BCN Peptides. He believes it will work on superficial muscles only. Hence the trial in blepharospasm (see Neurology6672: Hexapeptide-8 is Safe for Extending Duration of BoNT for Blepharospasm (BSP)).
Allergan Poster Review
Botulinum Neurotoxin Serotype — A Specific Cell Based Potency Assay To Replace The Mouse Bioassay which has previously been posted on TRACTION.
  • Although this is a cell based assay, mouse is still used.
  • Patent was granted in July 2012
  • Full paper found at http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0049516
Reconstituted BOTOX retains potency and safety under extended refrigerated storage
  • The study presented evaluated the potency and microbial growth promotion of reconstituted BOTOX.
  • Microbal challenge study included
  • Staphylococcus
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • E.Coli
  • Candida albicans
  • Aspergillius niger
  • Results showed that equivalence in potency was established between the 0 hour and both the 24hr and 5 day (120hr) time points for three lots of BOTOX reconstituted
  • Providing additional support in favour of a 24 hr reconstitution
Efficacy and Treatment of Botox for the treatment of Crows Feet
  • Multicentre double blind randomised placebo controlled, parallel group study
  • Single treatment cycle with 5 months follow up
Results
  • Groups did not differ significantly in their demographics or CRL severity (which was moderate to mild)
  • There was no statistical significance between group differences in FLO-11 item scores, FLO -11 total score or perceived age of appearance on the SPA
BOTOX Significantly Reduced Urinary Incontinence And Improved Quality Of Life In Patients With Idiopathic Overactive Bladder
Results:
  • Significantly greater reductions from baseline in UI episodes/days occurred with BOTOX 100U compared with placebo (-2.65vs-0.87 at week 12 P5 episodes/day)
  • A high proportion of BOTOX treated patients reported a positive response on the TBS (60.8% vs 29.2% for placebo)
CD PROBE Study: The use of Electomyogrpahy for BOTOX Treatment of CD — a sub-analysis of the CD patient Registry for the observation of BOTOX
Rationale: The usefulness of EMG for BoNT injections is controversial and utilisation has not been previously described from a large, prospectively ascertained treatment cohort.
Methods: CD PROBE is an on-going observational study of CD patients treated with BOTOX that includes physicians with prior injection experience. Subjects were included if they had primary CD and were new to the treating physicians practice and who had not received toxin 16 weeks or were toxin naive. This baseline was designed to describe the use of EMG by physicians at the baseline injection.
The Percent of Chronic Migraine Patients who Responded to Botox Treatment per Treatment Cycle in the PREEMPT Clinical Programme
Patients were randomised (1:1) to BOTOX (155-195U) or placebo every 12 weeks, evaluating ≥50% responder rates for 3 treatments cycles across multiple efficacy variables. This rate exceeds the previously suggested clinically meaningful response rate of ≥30% in patients with CM
Intelligence gathered from Eric Shultz (BOTOX)
Source: Dr. Bahroo off the back of Allergan’s speaker training meeting
  • They will be conducting DIP programs where the injector goes to the trainee (same as ours without the presentation)
  • Their CD and Bleph sales are flat and they are taking a renewed focus on these indications.
  • First time in several years they conducted training for these indications
  • Allergan has 2-3 hospital reps per territory. They are divided out by indication. This is in addition to their office based sales force.
Intelligence gathered from John Bruins (Recombinant Toxin - Allergan)
Source: Dr. Singh (UMass Dartmouth) made the following statement:
"Allergan in the only facility in the US that is permitted (by the government) to express toxin by recombinant methods".
Dr. Singh is quite knowledgeable in this area and runs the Botulinum Research Facility in Dartmouth, Mass. He is closely aligned with the DOD, DHS, and other government agencies
Intelligence gathered from Brice Vignon (PurTox and RT001)
- Corey S MAAS : Clinical Botulinum neurotoxin protocols for the upper third of the face
  • Purtox : PhII study demonstrated : Purtox has > 30-60 days longer duration than Botox with the optimal dose Purtox 30U vs. Botox 20U
- Neil Sadick : Treatment of hyperhidrosis — What’s new in 2012?
  • Topical gel BoNT : Transcutaneous delivery (Richard G Glogau 2012 publication)
  • Sub dermal laser treatment
  • Non Invasive Laser treatment
  • Microwave Glandular ablation
According to Neil Sadick, "Revance" is a topical BoNT type B (?), shows very good efficacy, is going to get FDA approval. Onset of action= to injection, time of application : 5-7 mn and dose = to injection
Intelligence gathered from Dominic Marchese (Myobloc)
  • Medical Director at US Worldmeds said that they (Solstice Neurosciences/Myobloc) have filed with the FDA an NDA for the treatment of sialorrhea.

item.title: Merz Found in Breach of ABPI Code of Practice
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The complaint against Merz was filled by Allergan, which said that 3 ads showed Bocouture and Botox standing alongside each other and used phrases such as "equipotent", "equal potency" and "1:1 clinical conversion ratio".
The overall message was the products were the same, and could be interchanged.
The Prescription Medicines Code of Practice Authority (PMCPA) agreed with Allergan and found Merz in breach for making an "inaccurate, misleading and unsubstantiated claim".
In addition, Merz was found guilty of breaching Clause 2 of the code, bringing discredit upon and reducing confidence in the pharma industy, which is seen as the most serious breach.
Details @1 (attached document - from page 18)
  1. Code of Practive Review_2012 November Review.pdf  (725,6 KB)

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Toxins 2012 Intelligence Update - Merz Insights
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Merz's main theme at the congress was pointed towards flexible dosing, with various data supporting this initiative including i) patient/physician satisfaction surveys highlighting the wish for indivualised dosing/injection intervals; ii) long term safety data of Xeomin in order to demonstrate the lack of antibody formation; and, iii) actual injection interval data.
The congress was the first INA (International Neurotoxins Association) meeting and had ~400 attendees compared to last years Toxin meeting which had around 700+ participants. The INA meeting had a balance of clinical vs scientific events with the second half of most days focused on live patient cases(with injection demos) or patient videos.
Merz dominated the poster hall and had a total of 16 posters on display along with being the supporter of the opening symposia - Managing Patient Satisfaction, Safety And Therapeutic Efficacy In CD. A copy of the slides can be found at www.jhasim.com/d&s.
In order to garner a label change with regards to flexible dosing, Merz has initiated the CD Flex Trial (see Poster Review). This trial is US based and will not branch to EU sites in the near future. It is understood that this data should be available by 2016.
Two previous trials looking at flexible dosing in CD and blepharospasm conducted by Merz (previously presented at MDS 2012) are believed to not have had sufficient data to file. This could be due to the need for more immunogenicity data which is included in the CD Flex trial. Previous trials were also US based only.
Speaking with Cynthia Comella regarding the CD Flex trial, ‘recruitment is going at a snail’s pace and the trial is slightly biased in that it only looks at patients who want/request shorter injection intervals but the real goal of the trial is so we can wave the data in the face of Medicaid and not get sued for injecting prior to the guidelines’. When challenging her on increased cost, she replied ‘it’s what a good number of our patients want’.
Note: Individualised dosing may turn into an actual advantage rather than just a point of differentiation. The presumed increase of cost may not be as big of a concern when taking into account Merz’s history of discounting.
During the opening symposia, Dr. Steven Frucht’s talk revolved around improving symptom control — a look at dosing/frequency setting the scene to update the audience with data from the extension period of the "Xeomin Injected With Flexible Intervals Is a Well Tolerated Long Term Treatment of CD Trial" and the results of a "Satisfaction with BoNT A toxin treatment in CD" (see poster review below)
Further supporting the theme, immunoresistance featured in the programme with Dr Dressler’s overview of Immunological issues of BONT therapy. His talk foucused on concerns over an increased risk of neutralising antibodies with short injection intervals which may largely be based on early studies with the original formulation of Botox to which he referred to as ‘Old Botox’. He pushed for further investigation of this issue in order to challenge the 'myth'. Upon speaking with him, he stated that he believed Xeomin was the only product on the market he could safely say will not cause antibody formation due to its lack of complexing proteins.
Merz also seems to be trying to clean up its image after the injunction scandal by conducting ‘green’ trials in the form of greenhouse gas emissions due to secondary shipping packaging of temperature controlled and non-temperature controlled botulinum neurotoxin products.
Merz is clearly taking advantage of the fact that Xeomin does not require refrigeration - highlighting that the difference in GHG emissions between the shipping of 1000 packages of Xeomin vs Botox is equivalent to taking 0.6 cars or light trucks off the road for one year or a reduction in the use of >1500 litres of gasoline.
Merz sources on the booth stated that they are interested to move forward with pain and gynaecology indications in the future and hope to have a cell based assay by 2014.
POSTER REVIEW
CD FLEX (NCT01486264 - see Neurology6155: Merz to Start Comparison Study of Xeomin® in Cervical Dystonia Flex): An open label, non-inferiority study evaluation the efficacy and safety of 2 injection schedules of Xeomin (Short Flex vs Long Flex) in subjects with CD who receive treatment benefit of <10 wks with Botox treatment. Enrolment began in Jan 2012 and has not fully recruited to date. Target is 424 pts with a study length of two years. Results expected in 2016.
Following on from the flexible dosing theme, two posters highlighted the satisfaction with BoNT A treatment in post stroke spasticity — results from a patient survey (76 patients interviewed) and results from a physician survey (105 physicians interviewed) highlighted:
  • Most patients with post-stroke spasticity are basically satisfied with BoNT A toxin treatment
  • Patient satisfaction typically declines over time and is lowest just prior to injection and highest at the time of peak effect
  • When questioned about treatment intervals many patients prefer an injection interval of less than the standard 12 wks, although overall patients favoured a median interval of 12 wks
  • Patients would prefer to be given the option of individualised BoNT-A treatment intervals
  • Most physicians are basically satisfied with BoNT A toxin treatment
  • Despite this, physicians believed that greater flexibility regarding the dose and duration of injection intervals for BoNT-A injections would benefit patients
  • The majority of physicians felt that their patients would experience improved outcomes and greater satisfaction if dose and injection intervals were individualised
In addition, the two prior flexible interval studies in CD and blepharospasms was shown and have been previously reported in TRACTION (see Neurology6473: Intelligence From MDS Part 1 - Botulinum Toxin Company Activity) and (see Neurology6410: Intelligence From The AAN - Merz US Injunction Likely To Last Full 10 Months).
The CD data was a part of Dr. Steven Frucht’s talk during the Merz Symposia whereby the Extended Period of this trial was presented. The Main Period being presented at the previous Movement Disorders meeting as well as the blepharospasms data.
Study Design for Xeomin injected with flexible intervals in CD patients:
  • Main Period — Investigate the efficacy and safety of 2 different doses of Xeomin compared with placebo in subjects with CD
  • This part turned out to be safe and effective — no relevant safety findings
  • Extended Period - Investigate the efficacy and safety of repeated injections of the two doses of Xeomin in subjects with CD over a year period
  • Majority of patients received re-injections at intervals of 6 to 20 weeks
  • Mean (SD) injection interval: 14:0 (7.4) weeks (median: 13 weeks)
  • Mean cumulative dose (SD) were 917.8U (332.0) in the 240U group and 423.7U (166.3) in the 120U group
Satisfaction with BoNT A treatment in CD — results from 2 cross sectional surveys (Patients and Physicians)
  • Physicians survey indicated that there are still patients likely to be more effectively treated if shorter treatment intervals and higher doses are utilised
  • Listed cost issues and reimbursement problems as biggest hurdles BoNT A treatment in CD with pain relief being the number one treatment goal
  • Out of the 120 phyisicans surved, 66 said they would prefer shorter injection intervals
  • Mainly due to efficacy not lasting long enough
  • Structured patient interviews (n=136) were conducted in 4 countries (CAN,FR, DE, USA) by clinically experienced interviewers
  • All interviewed patients had received ≥2 injection sessions with Botox or Xeomin
  • Interviews were conducted wither at 7 to 8 weeks or 9 to 10 weeks after patients last injection sessions
  • These time frames were considered to allow sufficient time for the BoNT A to confer peak clinical effects

TOWER (NCT01603459 - see Neurology6414: Dose-Titration Trial of Xeomin for Spasticity in the Leg and Arm): Open label Xeomin dose titration study (≤ 800U) in LL/UL spasticity. Fifty patients have been recruited since end September 2012 and expect to complete enrolment by mid-2013. Enrolment target is 150 patients. Results expected in Q3/4 2014. Primary outcome of safety while also looking at antibody formation and pulmonary function. Secondary objectives include usual clinical evaluations (Ashworth, REPAS, GAS etc).

Study Flow:

XCiDaBLE: NCT01287247 Phase IV, observational prospective trial evaluating Xeomin for CD or blepharospasm. Data below outlines the preliminary baseline results for subjects with blepharospasm. As of Feb 2012, 170 subjects (with blepharospasm) have participated in the study. Final results are expected in Feb 2013.

Study design:

Most subjects and their physicians described their baseline Global Impression of Severity as 'mild to marked'. The mean SD baseline SF-12v2 scores were 49.6 (10.0) for the Mental score and 43.8 (11.7) for the Physical score.

SPACE: An international, non-interventional study of BONT A in treatment-naïve patients with spasticity. Up to 100 study sites in 9 countries. By end December 2011, 282 patients have been enrolled. Target enrollment is 1000 patients.

The purpose of this study is to understand how spasticity is managed in the long term and gain insights into ‘real life’ clinical practice. Patients can receive any number of treatment sessions with any type of BONT A toxin available in their country. The planned study duration is 2 yrs per patient. Outcomes include daily practice information, HRQoL and efficacy assessments.

Interim analysis of 205 patients in 7 countries (UK, DE, CAN, MEX, RUS, FR, SE) is outlined below:

  • Most patients had post-stroke spasticity
  • At baseline, 26.8% of patients reported no spasticity related pain, 25.3% reported mild pain, and 11.6% reported severe pain — no data were recorded for 15 patients
  • 48.1% of participating physicians stated that would like to inject higher doses of than permitted by current product labeling
  • Most important primary treatment goals for patient's improvement in dexterity and reaching (26.8%), relief of pain (12.7%) and improvement in mobility (11.75)
  • Improvement of self-care was the most common additional treatment goal

Conversion from Dysport to Xeomin: Clinical experience in 257 pts: This study was initiated to assess the potential advantages of Xeomin including cost.

  • Switching was generally initiated at a 4:1 ratio of botulinum toxin untils (Dysport: Xeomin)
  • Switching to Xeomin was well tolerated without any significant problems suggestive of over-treatment such as ptosis, facial droop or swallowing difficulty
  • Switching from Dysport to Xeomin reduced expenditure to 77.2% of the pre-switch cost of botulinum toxin, saving >22%
  • Pre-switch, the expenditure for Dysport was £329.90 per patient, per year( $520, €403)
  • After switching, the expenditure for Xeomin was £249.60 per patient ($398, €309)

Observational Study With Xeomin In Post-Stroke ULS Patients In Nursing Homes. This study took place in Austria at 18 nursing homes across the country. It has been highlighted that nursing home residents suffering from ULS often lack treatment to BoNT- A treatment.

Outcome measures included changes in SAPS, pain intensity, changes in self- care activities, rating of response to treatment and safety.

Results

  • Pain in the UL decreased dramatically
  • A distinct improvement in UL self-care activities was noted
  • Response to treatment was high

Xeomin demonstrated equivalent efficacy to Botox in the treatment of CD. This was the results of the registration study from 2005 outlining that this H2H study demonstrated therapeutic equivalence of Xeomin to Botox at a 1:1 dosing conversation ration in the treatment of CD within the dose range of 70U and 300U.

Xeomin demonstrated equivalent efficacy to Botox in the treatment of bleparhospasmsThis was the results of the registration study from 2006 outlining that this H2H study demonstrated therapeutic equivalence of Xeomin to Botox at a 1:1 dosing conversation ration in the treatment of blepharospasms with dose of up to 50U per eye.
