item.title: Novo Successfully Completes PhI Development Of Oral GLP-1
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Merrion announced today the successful completion of this trial by its partner Novo Nordisk. The oral formulation utilises Merrion's proprietary GIPET technology to enhance the oral biovailability of the drug.
The aim of the trial was to investigate the safety, tolerance and pharmacokinetics, of the GLP-1 analogue NN9926.
Deal Terms
Under the terms of the license agreement signed in January 2009, Merrion will receive payments based on achievement of certain development, regulatory and sales milestones as well as royalties. Certain milestone payments have been received by Merrion as a result of this successful Phase 1 trial.
Source: www.merrion.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Russian Prostate Cancer Market Will See Steady Growth
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Russian prostate cancer market is set for 6% annual growth over the next 4 years.
A report from Decision Resources has highlighted that an expanding patient population and a raft of novel product launches will result in steady growth for the Russian market over the coming four years. The report also estimated that the number of diagnosed incident cases of prostate cancer in Russia will increase by 5% each year over this time period.
Russia will also realise the launch of three novel branded agents: Orteronel (TAK 700), Alpharadin (radium-223 chloride) and Xtandi (enzalutamide)over the course of the next five years which will support this growth.
Together with the recent approvals of Sanofi's Jevtana (cabazitaxel) and Johnson & Johnson's Zytiga, these therapies are expected to contribute 19% of the total market sales in 2016.
Currently, a locally manufactured Buserelin (Pharma-Sintez), is the most popular LHRH agonist prescribed in Russia today.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Active Biotech Sees Success With its Phase IIa Study in Crohn’s Disease
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Teva and Active Biotech announce positive findings for laquinimod in Crohn’s Disease (CD) at the United European Gastroenterology (UEG) congress.
The phase IIa dose ranging study demonstrated that treatment with 0.5 mg/day oral laquinimod resulted in a robust, early and consistent effect on remission and response rates in patients with moderate-to-severe CD versus placebo.
Dr. Michael Hayden, President of Global R&D and CSO for Teva stated “Our developmental program for laquinimod has demonstrated that the immunomodulatory effects of this oral compound stand to apply to multiple autoimmune diseases, and data presented at UEG showed an impressive impact on clinical remission in Crohn’s disease as early as one week of treatment,”
The data are currently undergoing further analysis and evaluation to finalize next steps in the CD clinical development plan.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Takeda's Key Priority Is To Improve Profitability
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Takeda has reported a 12% increase in revenues but a 49% drop in operating income, the latter due to acquisition related costs and increased R&D spending on late-stage development assets such as TAK-700. Development of this product for CRPC is progressing well, however, timelines for approval in Europe and Japan appear to have slipped a little compared to those presented at the R&D Day in May 2012.
Key Income Statement Developments
The group's sales performance is shown below. Sales of new products and those associated with the acquisition of Nycomed appear to be absorbing sales declines amongst the group's older products including that of Takeda's GnRH-agonist Leuprorelin.
During the group's webcast, company President Hasegawa made several referecences to his pre-occupation with profitability and noted that a project would be implemented with the aim of achieveing an operating margin of 20% post-transition to IFRS. The company plans to reduce costs by Y60bn on top of the Y200bn cost reductions coming from the acquisition of Nycomed.
Key R&D Developments
Noticeably, in terms of pipeline approvals by region the approval of TAK-700 has slipped from FY14 to FY15-FY16 for Japan and from FY14 to FY15-FY16 for Europe. The US approval time at FY2014 remains the same. Takeda'a year-end is March.

item.title: Another Feather In Avastin’s Cap
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Avastin is now the first biological therapy approved for newly diagnosed and recurrent ovarian cancer.
Roche has received an EC approval for Avastin in combination with standard chemotherapy as a treatment for women with first recurrence of platinum-sensitive ovarian cancer.
The approval is based off the back of the Phase III OCEANS study which showed a statistically significant improvement in PFS for patients being treated with Avastin plus gemcitabine and carboplatin versus those receiving gemcitabine, carboplatin and placebo.
Avastin is already approved as a front-line treatment for women with advanced ovarian cancer.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: New Trial Will Assess Benefit of Early Switch from 1st-line Docetaxel to Cabazitaxel
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The primary objectives of the TAXYNERGY Ph2 trial will explore the benefit of an early switch from docetaxel/prednisone to cabazitaxel/prednisone in men with mCRPC who do not achieve >30% PSA decline from baseline by cycle 4 with the initial docetaxel treatment.
Secondary Outcome Measures:
  • Progression-free survival [ Time Frame: up to max 5 years ] [ Designated as safety issue: No ]
  • PSA progression-free survival rate [ Time Frame: up to max 5 years ] [ Designated as safety issue: No ]
  • Objective response rate [ Time Frame: up to max 5 years ] [ Designated as safety issue: No ]
  • Radiographic progression-free survival (rPFS) rate [ Time Frame: up to max 5 years ] [ Designated as safety issue: No ]
  • Clinical progression-free survival (cPFS) [ Time Frame: up to max 5 years ] [ Designated as safety issue: No ]
  • Overall survival [ Time Frame: up to max 5 years ] [ Designated as safety issue: No ]

Recruitment: approx. 100

Start date: Nov 2012 - Completion date: July 2015
Location: USA

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Novartis' New Facility in Singapore Will Support Biologics Porfolio
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The construction is to start in early 2013, and will represent an investment of >$500M. It will focus on drug substance manufacturing based on cell culture technology, and pharmaceutical production.
The site will be designed to operate in a flexible manner to handle small and large scale volumes. It is planned to support both clinical and commercial production of potential new products that include monoclonal antibodies for use in helping patients with diseases in autoimmune, respiratory and oncology indications.
The biologics pipeline currently accounts for 25% of the clinical pharmaceutical research pipeline with a trend for future growth.
  • Lucentis® (ranibizumab)
  • Xolair® (omalizumab)

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: New Comer in the Iranian Aesthetic Market
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Thank to the recent feedback from M. Raimbault and our partner, we have learnt that the safety of MasoonDarou Pharm's Botulinum Toxin A for moderate-to-severe glabellar lines (GL) is being evaluated vs Neuronox (Medy-Tox) at the Razi Hospital in approx. 12 participants. According to the source, the efficacy phase in unlikely to be assessed. The objective of the company is to register as soon as possible.
Name of the drug: 500 IU (
Protocol:
Results: "effective, without side effect".
According to the source:
  • Clinical: tests on animals were not performed
  • MSO: the company have produced around 5,000 vials in their first batch

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Norditropin® Sales Increase in the First Nine Months of 2012
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Q3 results were driven by a 62% jump in sales of diabetes drug Victoza, and a 23% rise in modern insulin sales. Novo Nordisk reported that 9Mo-sales of Norditropin® increased by 14% measured in Danish kroner to DKK 4,237 million and by 8% measured in local currencies. The sales growth is primarily driven by North America and International Operations.
Novo Nordisk is the second-largest company in the global growth hormone market with a 24% market share measured by volume.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Allergan's Q3 Financial Results
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment:
The top ten markets for neuro-modulators are roughly $1.8 billion, growing at a rate of roughly 13%. BOTOX has approximately an 84% market share. Year-to-date that market is growing 11% and year-to-date BOTOX market share is 84%. The worldwide market for neuro-modulators is roughly $2.3 billion, growing at a rate of roughly 13%. BOTOX has approximately a 76% market share. Year-to-date that market is growing 12% and year-to-date BOTOX market share was 76%.
The worldwide market for dermal facial fillers is roughly $1 billion, growing at around a rate of 11%. Allergan has approximately a 37% market share. Year-to-date that market is growing 6% and year-to-date Allergan’s share is about 40%.
The worldwide breast aesthetics market for aesthetic and reconstructive is roughly $880 million, growing at a rate of around 7%. Allergan has approximately a 42% market share. Year-to-date that market is growing 10% and year-to-date Allergan’s share is around 41%.
Source: Allergan

item.title: FIM of Merz' Drug for Glaucoma
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Clinicaltrials.gov is listing a new Ph1 study aimed at assessing the safety and tolerability of repeat doses of MRZ-99030 ophtalmic solution in approx. 70 participants. This investigational drug represents the one and only compound in development for this indication in the company's pipeline.
Study Details NCT01714960

item.title: US Healthcare Reform Success Hinges on Election Results
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: This report examines the presidential candidates' diverging views on healthcare and the impact on the Affordable Care Act (ACA) of the possible election outcomes.

  • The presidential election on 6 November will decide not only who the country's next leader is, but also whether the United States moves closer to the implementation of a nearly universal healthcare system.
  • Healthcare is the second most significant issue for voters in the run up to the election, after the "economy".
  • More than two years after its passing, the ACA remains highly controversial, especially as a recent Supreme Court decision has chipped away at some of its original provisions.
  • The individual mandate to purchase health insurance has remained in effect following the Supreme Court's ruling but the states will not be required to expand Medicaid, as originally intended under the ACA – with the result that more people than originally expected will have to purchase health insurance in the insurance exchanges or face financial penalties.
  • The rivals for the presidential post – incumbent Barrack Obama (Democrat) and former Massachusetts governor Mitt Romney (Republican) – have vastly diverging views on the future of healthcare reform and the role the federal government should play in healthcare provision.
  • If re-elected, Obama intends to press on with reform implementation. His ability to do so would be facilitated if Republicans fail to win a 60-seat Senate representation.
  • If Republican candidate Romney is elected, he plans to "act to repeal" the ACA in its entirety – and introduce in its place a system where the market and states play a greater role in healthcare provision.
  • Whatever the election outcome, it is clear that the momentum for change of the healthcare system is undeniably there: some of the elements of that change are already under way and are unlikely to be reversed completely, and a future Republican president may not be a in a position to undertake a complete repeal of the healthcare reform.

The next US presidential election, due to be held on 6 November, will see Republican candidate Mitt Romney challenge the incumbent Democrat president Barrack Obama. In choosing between the two candidates voters are also asked to make a decision on the future healthcare system of the United States. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, known simply as the Affordable Care Act (ACA), is at the centre of increasingly heated pre-election debates.

2010
  • Ban insurance companies' policy of dropping people from coverage and of imposing lifetime coverage limits; health insurer annual cover limits to be restricted for new plans.
  • Bar insurers from denying coverage to children (under 19) due to pre-existing conditions.
  • Establishing consumer assistance programmes in states and an appeals process for insurance company decisions; providing new resources to help combat healthcare fraud.
  • Require insurers to keep young adults on their parents' health plans until the age of 26.
  • Set up a temporary programme allowing uninsured adults with pre-existing conditions to obtain health coverage (this will expire once new insurance exchanges begin operating in 2014).
  • Create a temporary (until 2014) reinsurance programme to help companies maintain health coverage for early retirees between the ages of 55 and 65 and their spouses and dependents.
  • Provide a USD250 rebate to Medicare drug beneficiaries who reach the "doughnut hole" coverage gap.
  • Provide a tax credit to some small businesses to help provide coverage for workers.
  • Require new insurance plans to provide free preventive care, such as mammograms and colonoscopies.
  • Allow states to cover more people under Medicaid – with federal matching funds available.

2011
  • Require insurance companies to spend at least 85% of all premium dollars for larger employers and at least 80% for smaller employers and individuals on healthcare services and quality improvement.
  • Require insurers to provide preventative care services to Medicare beneficiaries at little or no cost to patients.
  • States to offer home and community-based care for Medicaid beneficiaries under a new programme coming into effect in October.
  • Payments to insurers offering Medicare Advantage services to be gradually reduced to bring them more in line with basic Medicare.
  • Offer 50% discount to seniors who reach the doughnut hole coverage gap on Medicare Part D covered brand-name prescription drugs.

2012
  • Provide incentives for physicians to join together to form Accountable Care Organisations; implement physician payment reforms.
  • Incentivise hospitals to improve the quality of care under the Value-Based Purchasing programme in Traditional Medicare.
  • Create a voluntary long-term care insurance programme (CLASS) to provide cash benefits for adults who become disabled.

2013
  • Expand number of Americans with access to preventive care by granting new funding to state Medicaid programmes which offer preventive care at little or no cost to patients.
  • Establish a national pilot programme on payment bundling under Medicare aiming to improve patient care-co-ordination. Savings to be shared between providers and Medicare.
  • Require states to increase Medicaid payments to primary care physicians, paying them no less than 100% of Medicare payment rates in 2013 and 2014.
  • Provide additional funding to states for two more years to continue coverage of children not eligible for Medicaid under the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP).
  • Raise the threshold for claiming medical expenses on tax returns to 10%, from 7.5% of income (excluding the elderly, for whom the threshold remains at 7.5% through 2016).
  • Raise the Medicare payroll tax to 2.35% from 1.45% for individuals with income of more than USD200,000 and for married couples with incomes of more than USD250,000.

2014
  • State health insurance exchanges to be opened for small businesses and individuals.
  • The majority of Americans to be required to obtain health insurance coverage or face penalties. Healthcare tax credits for purchasing health coverage on the insurance exchange to be made available to people with a family income of up to four times the federal poverty limit (equivalent to USD88,000 in 2010).
  • Fines to be imposed on employers with 50 or more workers who do not offer coverage (USD2,000 for each employee). Tax credits available to small businesses to help with health insurance costs.
  • Health plans to be banned from excluding people from coverage due to pre-existing conditions or gender.
  • Annual limits on insurance coverage to be eliminated.
  • Prohibit insurers from dropping coverage for individuals participating in clinical trials.
  • Allow Americans with income of less than 133% of the poverty level (USD14,000 for an individual or USD29,000 for a family of four in 2010) to enrol on Medicaid. States to receive 100% of federal funding for the first three years of expanded Medicaid coverage, phasing to 90% federal funding after that.

2015
  • Improve cost-efficiency in medical treatment by rewarding Medicare physicians for providing quality of treatment rather than by volume of services provided.

2018

Encourage a gradual switch to lower-cost plans by introducing additional tax on high-cost employer-provided plans from 2018.

Sources: Key Features of the Affordable Care Act, by Year; Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act of 2010 (available here)
Obama ran his last election campaign on the promise of passing a wide-reaching healthcare reform providing access to healthcare to millions of currently uninsured or underinsured Americans. He won the election, but passing the reform was no easy task as the president's initiatives were kept in check by Republicans in the House of Representatives. Even after the ACA passed Congressional review in 2010, House Republicans have made attempts to repeal it as a whole or dismantle certain aspects of it. Although such attempts secured enough support in the House, similar endeavours have failed to gain majority support in the Senate where Republicans have only 47 seats at present.
Crucially, the ACA also survived a review by the US Supreme Court, which ruled in July 2012 that the reform was not anti-constitutional. Although weakening some federal demands on the states (in particular the requirement for states to expand their Medicaid programme), the Supreme Court confirmed that it was within the power of Congress to impose an individual mandate on Americans to purchase health insurance. The latter had been challenged by Republicans as evidence of Big Government infringing on individual freedoms.

Although the ACA has been approved by Congress and now has successfully passed the scrutiny of the US Supreme Court, it clearly remains at the heart of party differences. Healthcare is one of the distinguishing issues in the election as far as voters are concerned. In a recent national survey of a representative sample of likely voters by polling company Rasmussen Reports, healthcare was ranked second (with 66% of votes) as an issue affecting how respondents would vote – after the economy with 80% of votes. Considering that the economy as an issue is also closely related to whether the ACA is fully implemented – given the latter's impact on government spending – it can be argued that even those voters that are primarily focused on economic policy as a deciding factor in the voting decision cannot avoid considering healthcare policy as an issue.
The electoral debate this year is also made more interesting by the fact that voters are not only electing a new president. All the seats in the House of Representatives and a third of the Senate seats are also up for grabs. The outcome of these Congressional elections has the potential to impact how much power the new president-elect has to press ahead with healthcare reform or alternatively move to repeal it.

As the pre-election debates heated up, both candidates have moved to disclose their healthcare reform plans. They recently articulated these views in statements ran side by side in the New England Journal of Medicine.

Follow through with implementation of the ACA by requiring individuals to purchase heath insurance while denying health insurers the ability to deny coverage based on pre-existing conditions.

  • The law "roots out waste and fraud in Medicare and Medicaid, gets rid of insurance overpayments, reinvests those savings back into the system, and adds eight years to the solvency of Medicare".
  • By closing the doughnut hole, the ACA provisions are "saving people an average of USD600 last year".
  • "Provider groups are working with us to form accountable care organisations and more and more hospitals are moving toward bundled payments."
  • Looking ahead, additional steps are needed, including: a "permanent fix to Medicare's flawed payment formula" that threatens physicians' reimbursement; medical malpractice reform to prevent needless lawsuits; continued support for life-sciences research; and building the healthcare workforce to meet the demands of an aging population.
  • The aim is to "keep Medicare and Medicaid strong, working to make the programmes more efficient without undermining the fundamental guarantees".

Act to repeal the ACA on day one of presidency; replace it with a healthcare law that gives more power to the states and encourages people without health insurance to purchase it in the private market – including in other states which offer lower-cost insurance plans.

  • Pass regulations preventing insurers from discriminating against people with pre-existing conditions who maintain continuous coverage.
  • End tax discrimination against people purchasing insurance, strengthen and expand health savings accounts, establish strong consumer protection.
  • Limit malpractice lawsuits targeting physicians.
  • Insurance market reforms must "promote competition by eliminating onerous mandates, facilitating purchasing pools, and opening up the interstate market".
  • Convert Medicaid into a block grant that properly aligns each state's incentives around using resources efficiently.
  • Reform Medicare: without making changes for people enrolling today or during the next 10 years, but providing future beneficiaries "a set of Medicare-approved, guaranteed-coverage plans to choose from, including today's traditional fee-for-service option".
Unsurprisingly, Obama's plans are clearer given that the recently approved – if still controversial – reform is his signature bill. The president has even moved to embrace the term "Obamacare" that the bill's critics have used to refer to the healthcare reform. In recent weeks, he's stated: "Supporters and detractors alike refer to the law as Obamacare. I don't mind, because I do care."
His opponent, on the other hand, remains somewhat vague on the details of his plans. It is one thing to state one would repeal Obamacare, but another altogether to come up with a detailed plan on what Obamacare is to be replaced with. Given the pre-election pressures, Romney also needs to be careful not to alienate potential voters who like some aspects of the ACA legislation.
Gaining access to health insurance for those with pre-existing conditions is one of the few things that Romney is clearly keen to assure voters about. So under his plans for healthcare reform, people with a pre-existing condition who have been "continuously insured" would be guaranteed to have access to health cover if they lose their job or change jobs. But this policy has been questioned on grounds that it is already incorporated in the provisions of former president Bill Clinton's Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, which was enacted in 1996. Enforcing the act, however, is the stumbling block and Romney has been vague on what enforcement action would be taken if the ACA – which also incorporates a similar provision – were to be repealed in its entirety.

Another aspect of Romney's healthcare reform vision is that more power should be given to the states. Shifting the focus from the federal to the state level is also a strategy to help Romney distance himself from the ACA. After all, the ACA is closely modelled on the healthcare reform the state of Massachusetts adopted while Romney was state governor. Massachusetts now has nearly universal health cover as a result of that reform – and that is all good and well from Romney's perspective, it seems, as long as such policy is undertaken at the state level rather than being enforced at the federal level.
Romney recognises in his NEJM statement one of the ACA provisions which is proving popular with voters – allowing children to stay on their parents' health insurance until the age of 26. However, he states that this is an initiative that health insurers are already implementing, suggesting that under his health reform plans this would not be a mandatory requirement for insurers, but something insurers would do nonetheless because "they are responding to consumer demands".

Given the two candidates' diverging visions of healthcare provision, IHS Global Insight expects one of two possible scenarios to unfold in the US following the election: with different possible permutations under each.

If Obama wins the presidential election, he is expected to push ahead with the implementation of the ACA. The main provisions of the bill are due to come into effect at the start of 2014. With Obama as president – and assuming that Republicans do not win a filibuster-proof majority of 60 seats in the Senate – implementation of the ACA is expected to proceed without delay.
The main mandatory element of the healthcare bill – with immediate implications for individuals – is the enrolment on healthcare plans. The vast majority of US residents without health insurance and who are not otherwise exempt through Medicaid or Medicare eligibility would be required to purchase health insurance in 2014. Enrolment in health insurance plans offered by states through the so-called insurance exchanges is due to commence from October 2013. Should some states fail to set up insurance exchanges, Obama is expected to direct the Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) to step in and create the exchanges on behalf of non-compliant states without any delay.
Obama would also be expected to use his presidential authority to encourage the states to implement some expansion of their Medicaid programme as envisaged under the ACA provisions. However, achieving this may prove difficult – especially in Republican-run states – following the July 2012 Supreme Court ruling. Based on the ruling, it is not mandatory for states to expand their Medicaid programme. As a result, some states will choose not to expand Medicaid, leaving a higher number of individuals with no health insurance who would then face penalties if they do not purchase health cover. A recent CBO analysis indicates that as fewer individuals choose to purchase health insurance or can afford to purchase it, the overall spending impact will be a net reduction in federal healthcare spending as "the projected decrease in total federal spending on Medicaid is larger than the anticipated increase in total exchange subsidies". Hence, for Obama, the removal of the state mandate to expand Medicaid should not at least cause problems by pushing federal spending up. Blaming Republican-run states which fail to expand Medicaid – thus forcing more individuals to buy health insurance or pay the financial penalties – could earn the Democrats some political credit. As such the Supreme Court ruling has not necessarily made implementation of the ACA that much more difficult for Obama during a second term in the Oval Office.
On another note, health insurance premiums – particularly for younger people – will probably increase if the ACA implementation proceeds promptly. This trend will be partly driven by the ACA provisions preventing health insurers from discriminating against people based on pre-existing conditions or age. The real challenge for Obama, if re-elected, will be to ensure insurance premiums do not rise substantially, while also allowing free market forces to guide the health insurance market dynamics.

Scenario 2: Romney wins

If Mitt Romney were to win the presidential election, he would have no choice but to attempt a repeal of the ACA. Romney has stated repeatedly throughout the campaign that he would seek to repeal the ACA. Following the Supreme Court ruling in support of the ACA, Romney said: "What the court did not do in its last day in session, I will do on my first if elected president of the United States. I will act to repeal Obamacare."
It is clear that repealing the bill and acting to repeal it are two different things. Realistically, Romney's only chance of repealing the ACA would be if somehow Conservatives secured a majority in the House Representatives and at least 60 seats in the Senate. They currently have 47 seats in the Senate – which is the reason why they have so far failed to secure a repeal of the ACA. Although securing 60 seats in the Senate seems to be a long shot at present, if Conservatives were to win a simple majority of 51 seats they could potentially attempt to disable the ACA by diverting federal funding needed for its implementation. Through the so-called budget reconciliation process, Senate Republicans could vote against the financial provisions of the ACA as they are due to take effect. Provisions of the bill such as individual tax breaks for people purchasing health insurance and additional funding for the states agreeing to expand their Medicaid programme could be rendered powerless if their funding is removed through the Senate budget reconciliation process.
Another potential route that Romney could take would be to order the secretary of the DHHS not to implement the law. This could be done via granting waivers to states allowing them to not implement certain the ACA provisions or failing to act if some states choose not to set up the health insurance exchanges (under the ACA provisions the DHHS can step in and set up insurance exchanges for states which fail to create them by 2014).
One other option open to Romney – albeit a rather extreme one – would be to unilaterally repeal the ACA, using his interpretation of the Constitution to reject the Supreme Court's ruling. This outcome is possible, but, in our view, highly unlikely considering that a) it would trigger a Constitutional crisis and b) it may incentivise the other pillars of power – the Senate and the House of Representatives, the Supreme Court, and the media (often considered the Fourth Pillar in US politics) to attempt to curb a presidential "power grab".

The options for Obama and Romney would be somewhat limited following the elections. Obama, if he were re-elected, would have fewer constraints it seems. The main challenge for him would be to rein in health insurance premium rises without giving Republicans cause to complain that the president is interfering in the free market. Even without a mandatory requirement for states to expand their Medicaid programme, the ACA provisions would come into effect one by one, under an Obama second term, and even states unwilling to support the reform may be persuaded into setting up insurance exchanges and allowing Medicaid expansion.
The future of healthcare reform is somewhat more unpredictable under a Romney presidency. It is fairly certain that a full repeal of the ACA is unlikely – despite Romney's promises that he would attempt it. Only a filibuster-proof Republican majority in the Senate could lead to complete repeal of the ACA, unless, of course, Romney were to unilaterally declare the bill unconstitutional – in breach of the recent Supreme Court ruling. Both of these options are highly unlikely, leading us to conclude that a full the ACA repeal is not to be expected. A simple Republican majority in the Senate could, however, lead to removal of funding for some the ACA provisions. Accompanied by a presidential campaign to discourage implementation of the ACA by the various levels of the executive, such de-funding could seriously destabilise the ACA implementation.
Even if the ACA implementation were to stop on day one of a Romney presidency, the few provisions of the bill that have already come into effect have changed the US healthcare landscape so much that going back to the pre-2010 situation is impossible. Americans – regardless of their political orientation – have begun to see the attractiveness of certain measures to curb health insurance excesses. Allowing children up to the age of 26 to remain on parents' health insurance and barring health insurers from denying coverage to people with pre-existing conditions are just two examples of those. More importantly, it appears that the American public has warmed up to the need for healthcare reform. Even if the unlikely scenario of a complete the ACA repeal were to materialise, the removal of the ACA would leave a vacuum that needs to be filled by healthcare reform of some kind. Such is the momentum for change that the future occupant of the Oval Office after the 6 November election would have a clear healthcare reform mandate – although interpreting and implementing that mandate in unlikely to be easy.
Source: Global Insight

item.title: Bayer's Q3 Financial Results Driven by HealthCare
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Pharma sales grew 13% to €2,734M, mainly driven by sales of Kogenate. The growth in North Amrica and China helped offset a declining Europe. Additionally, Bayer announced the €1.2bn acquisition of Schiff Nutrition, which underlines Bayer's strategy to focus more on Healthcare.
The strongest growth was recorded in China. The company raised sales there by 27.5% (Fx adj.) in Q3 through increased marketing activities, especially the expansion of its distribution network.
Business developed well in Latin America and in Eastern Europe, particularly Russia.
The emerging markets accounted for 32.9% of total HealthCare sales in the first nine months of 2012 and 33.4% in the third quarter.
Source: Bayer

item.title: New Ph3 Trial of Zytiga in Newly Diagnosed Patients with High-Risk mHNPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Recently listed in clinicaltrials.gov the goal of this Ph3 trial is to determine if newly diagnosed (within previous 3 months) patients with metastatic prostate cancer (mHNPC) who have high-risk prognostic factors will benefit from the addition of abiraterone acetate and low-dose prednisone to androgen deprivation therapy (ADT; LHRH agonists or surgical castration). PE will assess OS.
Sponsor: Janssen Research & Development LLC
Recruitment: approx 1270
Start date: Dec 2012 / Completion date: July 2018
Location: USA

item.title: Spanish Pharma Industry Set to Shrink 5% Annually As a Result of Citizens' Co-payment Measure
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: According to El Economista, the citizen co-payment austerity measure is also affecting the volume of drugs that are being purchased through the public healthcare system, and prescriptions have also been greatly affected throughout the months of September and October.
The drop in sales and expenditure did not come as surprise as citizens were preparing for weeks before the new rule came into effect, by purchasing additional drugs. Two weeks after the mandatory co-payments came into place on 1 July, pharmacies experienced a 23% drop in drug sales in comparison to two weeks before the co-payments come into force, equating to an 11% year-on-year drop in drug sales in July.
According to the source, 14 weeks into the co-payment enforcement, the volume of drugs sold in pharmacies across the country has decreased in all segments, including generics. The sector is not forecast to achieve any further growth until at least 2015/16.

Although there is uncertainly on whether the citizens' co-payment will be staying in place as an effective cost-cutting measure in the short-to-medium term, the effects of the austerity measure have already started to be felt, not only by the citizens and pharmacies, but also by the domestic and multinational pharmaceutical sector operating in the country, aggravating their already delicate position in the country as their volume of drugs sold will decrease with a consequent direct effect on revenues.
The Spanish pharmaceutical sector will experience a decrease in sales, revenues, and volume of drugs purchased through the public healthcare sector, which is realistically not forecast to increase for at least three years. In terms of foreign multinational companies operating in the country, there is a risk that some may think to relocate their production to other Southern European countries, such as Portugal, in an attempt to escape the unwelcoming business climate in Spain as a consequence of the co-payment and other recent tough cost-cutting austerity measures.
Domestic firms, will also experience a decrease in sales and volume. For the generics industry, the recent measures will also have a negative impact, despite governmental efforts to boost the sector as much as possible through its pro-generic stance with the enforcement of Royal Decree 9/11 on mandatory prescriptions by active pharmaceutical ingredients.
Source: Global Insight

item.title: An Orally Active Ghrelin Mimetic Macimorelin (AEZS-130) as New Available Test for Diagnosis of Adults GH Deficiency
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: At the 6th International Congress of the Growth Hormone Research Society and the IGF Society, Aeterna Zentaris (AEZS) announced a Phase 3 results for its ghrelin agonist AEZS-130 (please see below).
The objective of the study was to evaluate the safety and efficacy of AEZS-130 in the diagnostic accuracy of Adults GH Deficency.
Previous comparison of this test with GHRH+L-Arginine test showed a better response of AEZS-130 as rapidity and as ROC (receiver operating characteristic) area under the curve (Slide 27 and 46 of the Investor Presentation of Aeterna Zentaris (October 2012)).
Adverse Effects were mild and 70% of patients undergoing both tests expressed a favorable preference for AEZS 130.
As first oral diagnostic tool AEZS-130 has a market oppurtunity of about 160.000 Diagnostic Tests (Slide 12 of the Investor Presentation of Aeterna Zentaris (October 2012)).
Conclusion: AEZS-130 would be a promising short, rapid, safe and well-tolerated diagnostic test for adult patients with GH Deficiency

item.title: Roche Predicts Price Cuts Will Lead to Drop in French Sales
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Corinne Le Goff, the president of Roche (Switzerland)'s French pharma division, has predicted that price cuts will cause the company's drug sales in France to decline in 2012. According to AWP Swiss News, Le Goff singled out a 15% reduction in the price of the oncology drug Avastin (bevacizumab) as being particularly significant.
On a broader level, Le Goff bemoaned the fact that medicines are being made to play a "disproportionate" part in the government's budget cuts. Nevertheless, she predicted that the company's overall drug sales in France would pick up again in 2013.
Despite Roche's concerns over the difficult operating environment in France, the country's size and level of development mean that it remains a key market for the Swiss company.
Notably, Roche currently has more than 35,000 patients participating in clinical trials in France, out of its global total of 300,000 clinical trial patients. The company is planning to launch 16 products in France over the next six years, mainly in the areas of oncology and nervous system diseases.
Source: Global Insight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: First Pediatric Trial with Versartis' Once-Monthly rhGH
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Versartis Trial In Children to Assess Long-Acting Growth Hormone (VERTICAL) Ph1b/2a study is being conducted in > to 26 sites in the US, and was initiated following the successful completion of a Ph1 trial in AGHD.
Design
The VERTICAL study is a randomized, open-label, multi-center Phase 1b/2a study being conducted in pre-pubertal GHD children that have not been previously treated with rhGH.
The study is designed in two stages:
the first stage (Phase Ib) utilizes an ascending dose design to evaluate the safety and tolerability of up to four dosing levels of a single subcutaneous (SC) dose of VRS-317 in approximately 48 pre-pubertal GHD children.
the second stage (Phase 2a) will further study these patients to determine the efficacy of VRS-317 as defined by an increase in height velocity over six months of treatment.
Secondary objectives of the six-month Phase 2a study include evaluating the safety and tolerability of repeat dosing as well as change in bone age, body weight and other measures of growth.
Presented at ESPE2012 by George M. Bright, MD, Vice President of Medical Affairs at Versartis - (Endocrinology7094: Intelligence from ESPE 2012 (Part1) - Developments and New Results of rhGH Drugs)

item.title: re: Octreotide Fails To Benefit MBO Patients In PhIII Trial
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Octreotide Fails To Benefit MBO Patients In PhIII Trial 
Comment: Disappointing results from a phIII trial with octreotide in malignant bowel obstruction has prompted Dr Currow, the study PI, to suggest that ranitidine plus dexamethosone may be a more cost-effective alternative.  ...
As mentioned by Raphael this poster has been presented at ASCO 2012 and the Medical Franchise liaised after ASCO with Dr Currow the PI of the study to get more data on it. The same data were presented again at the 19th International Congress on Palliative Care 2 weeks ago and made more noise than at ASCO with a Medscape article. The main point is that this Australian octreotide study, a double blind, placebo controlled, well designed study is negative (same effect for octreotide and placebo on the vomiting endpoint) challenging then the place of octreotide for this indication in some EU SMPC (Italy for example) and in many guidelines (US, Fr, Be, NL, UK...), the cost of the treatment being put upfront..
Within the context of our on going MBO dossier preparation with Somatuline 30mg, the Endo Medical Franchise and Clin Devpt are currently revisiting all the different studies performed with octreotide and lanreotide in MBO to illustrate similarities and differences of these studies (in terms of study population, drug formulation, endpoint, treatment duration, stage of the disease...).
This information will be shared.

item.title: Polish Healthcare Reform Plans Move Forward
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Poland's health minister Bartosz Arłukowicz has presented a five-point schedule for the next stage of the reform of the Polish public healthcare system that includes the abolition of the central office of the National Health Fund and for the first time the proposal for the abolition of the Agency for Health Technology Assessment in Poland (AOTM) and the assumption of its responsibilities by a new pricing and evaluation agency, which will also take over the responsibilities of the NFZ in this area.
Source: Polish newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza
  • The abolition of the central office of the NFZ. For this to happen, there will need to be a change in the law on healthcare, and the proposals for this legal change are due to be presented around the end of 2012 and the beginning of 2013. The date for the abolition of the NFZ's central office has not yet been finally established.
  • Increased responsibility being given to individual NFZ branches, which will be able to decide what they spend their budget on. It has not yet been decided whether the current regional branch structure of the NFZ, with a branch in every voivodship, will be maintained, or if a set of wider regional divisions will be created.
  • All activities involving the assessing and pricing of treatment by the NFZ will stop, and a new agency will be set up that will have responsibility for the pricing of medical treatment and the assessment of its quality and cost-effectiveness. Additionally, the AOTM is to be abolished and its responsibilities will also be taken over by this new agency, together with those of the Centre for the Monitoring of Quality in Health Care.
  • Patients are due to register at general practitioners' surgeries and hospitals from January 2012 using only their electronic registration number, found on their identity cards. This will enable those treating them to verify that they are eligible for treatment. From 2014, an electronic card system is to be introduced that will include all information about a patients' treatment, including prescribed medicines, and medical history.
  • Once the new card system is in place, the Ministry of Health (MoH) will turn its attention to the introduction of additional, voluntary health insurance.
The pace of the reforms is certainly being influenced by the pressure from the main opposition party, Law and Justice, which has recently presented its vision for public healthcare at a time when the government is susceptible to attacks on the healthcare front, following the sometimes ineptly managed introduction of reforms in the past year – particularly reforms included in the Reimbursement Act, relating principally to regulations on reimbursed medicines. The government has until the latter half of 2015 before it must call an election – barring any catastrophic loss of popularity. Therefore it is possible that it could implement many of these reforms in the time it has remaining.
With regional NFZ branches being able to decide what they spend money on, there will be a more heterogeneous system in Poland, with regional variations, and the possibility of certain NFZ branches being more generous than others with their reimbursement budgets. This could present both opportunities and challenges to pharmaceutical companies. Another point worth bearing in mind is that the NFZ was created and came into operation in 2004 in response to the financial chaos of the regional sickness funds. It is yet to be demonstrated how such chaos is to be avoided this time around.
In earlier statements on the reforms, there is no specific mention of the AOTM's liquidation, and indeed it was seen as a possibility that the new pricing agency would be established around the AOTM. For efficiency reasons, putting all these related competencies together makes sense, but there will be questions regarding exactly how independent this new agency will be. The AOTM is still a dependent agency of the MoH, and for all their squabbles and disputes, the NFZ and the MoH are equally a part of the state apparatus. The AOTM has a Transparency Board, which includes independent and non-partisan members who assess treatments – usually medicines – and this new board, along with the Economic Commission, which is responsible for negotiating prices with applicants and making cost-effectiveness decisions, represents a structure that only came into place at the beginning of 2012. How this model for pricing and reimbursement in Poland is changed by these reforms – if it is at all – will be monitored very closely.
Source: Global Insight

item.title: Highlights of Leerink Swann's 3Q Cosmetic Survey Results
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The survey polled 32 U.S based dermatologists and 30 plastic surgeons. Bottom lines suggest that despite interest in Merz's Xeomin & Belotero, physicians only forecast ~6% share for either product through 2014. Interestingly, many respondents responded that they are particularly excited about bringing Merz’s Xeomin and Belotero into their practices in the next 6-12 months citing cost savings with this new market entrant. Over 75% of respondents were aware of Valeant's acquisition of Medicis but a minority expect it to impact their practice. Key results are provided below.

item.title: AstraZeneca to Co-Develop/Commercialize IBS-C Drug for the Chinese Market
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: AstraZeneca and Ironwood will co-develop and co-commercialize Ironwood’s linaclotide in China for adult patients suffering from irritable bowel syndrome with constipation (IBS-C).
Development and Marketing
AstraZeneca and Ironwood are jointly responsible for strategic oversight of the development and commercialization of linaclotide in China.
AstraZeneca will have primary responsibility for the local operational execution.
Financial
AstraZeneca will make an upfront payment of $25M to Ironwood and will share the net profits and losses associated with linaclotide in China, with AstraZeneca carrying 55% of each until a certain specified milestone is achieved, moving to a 50/50 split thereafter.
Ironwood will also be eligible for $125M in additional commercial milestone payments contingent on the achievement of certain sales targets.
- IBS-C is a chronic and prevalent functional gastrointestinal disorder in China and there are currently few treatment options for this condition.
- To capitalize on its leadership in the gastrointestinal sector in the emerging markets.

item.title: Firmagon Added to Poland's Reimbursement List in Draft November Update
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Polish Ministry of Health (MoH) has published the draft of the update to the country's reimbursement list, which is set to come into force at the beginning of November.
Another important change introduced in the reimbursement list update involves the availability of a number of oncology drugs which were previously only available in hospitals via the outpatient system – these are busulfan, chlorambucil, melphalan and thioguanine.
Firmagon was recommended by then Consultative Council of the AOTM in January 2012 – also with some price-related conditions, indicating that some concession has also been made here.
Source: Global Insight

item.title: SPA for Tivantinib in 2nde-Line Ph3 Trial in MET-High HCC Patients
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Daiichi and ArQule have announced a SPA agreement with the FDA for the design of the Ph3. Details of the trial as well as ongoing development program with the drug are provided below.
  • Design: randomized, double-blinded trial of tivantinib as single agent therapy in previously treated patients with MET diagnostic-high inoperable HCC.
  • PE: OS
  • SE: PFS
  • Recruitment: approx. 300 patients are planned
  • Location: approx. 120 centers WW
Oncology8537: ESMO Intelligence Part 3 - Key Developments In Hepatocellular Cancer

Comments
The first patient has been enrolled in the pivotal Phase 3 METIV-HCC (MET-high patients with tivantinib in HCC) trial of tivantinib (ARQ 197). PE will assess Overall survival (OS) in Intent to Treat (ITT) population.
The METIV-HCC trial is a randomized, double-blinded, controlled study of previously treated patients with MET-high inoperable HCC who will receive tivantinib or placebo. The primary endpoint is overall survival (OS), and the secondary endpoint is progression-free survival (PFS). Approximately 300 patients are planned to be enrolled at approximately 120 clinical centers worldwide.
Tivantinib, an investigational selective inhibitor of MET, a receptor tyrosine kinase, is being evaluated for the treatment of patients diagnosed with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) who have received one or two prior systemic anti-cancer therapies.

item.title: Dr Reddy's Intended Acquisition of OctoPlus to Bring Complementary Skill Set
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The strategy to build capabilities rather than acquire products is seen as very positive by analysts at Kotak and Morgn Stanley. OctoPlus, a small specialty company, will provide the required formulation skills for complex injectables (the US market size of long-acting injectable drugs is close to $2bn). Though OctoPlus appears to have built expertise in difficult technologies, its product visibility is limited (i.e., only Locteron in Ph2b).
  • to enhance Dr Reddy's formulation capabilities for complex injectables.
  • to complement its existing API strength.
Financial
- Acquisition of all outstanding shares of OctoPlus at EUR0.52/share is valuing the entity at €27.4 mn. The offer price is at 30% premium to the last closing price of OctoPlus and has been supported by the OctoPlus board.
- The transaction is expected to be closed by end of FY2013.
Business Model: 3 segments
- Founded in 1995
- Staff: 111 (in 2011)
- Business: formulation development and manufacturing of complex injectables.
- Location: Leiden, Netherlands where it operates an injectable formulation facility and research centre.
- Business model : development services to global pharma and biotech companies and also license/partner to monetize the proprietary technologies.
- Revenues: EUR4.8 mn in 1HCY2012; (fee for services contributed 73% of sales).
- Key Projects

item.title: Lilly's Once-Weekly GLP-1 Analog Tops Byetta Metformin and Januvia in Trials
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Lilly reported it aims to seek marketing approval for dulaglutide in 2013, based on data from the trio of 'favorable Ph3 studies'.
- dulaglutide lowered hemoglobin A1c levels more than twice-daily injections of BMS' Byetta given for 6 months, oral metformin taken for 26 weeks and Merck & Co's once-daily oral Januvia taken for 1 year.
Lilly is also conducting a trial that compares dulaglutide with Victoza. The study is expected to be wrapped up by late 2013 or early 2014.

item.title: VTX-2337 + Doxil in Ph2 for Ovarian Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled Ph2 trial is being conducted in collaboration with the Gynecologic Oncology Group (GOG) Partners Program. The trial will enroll approx. 210 patients with recurrent/persistent epithelial ovarian cancer who ave faled prior platinum-based chemotherapy. The primary endpoint of the trial is OS.
Oct. 3 2012 - exclusive, WW collaboration with Celgene Corporation for the development of VTX-2337 for the treatment of cancer.
As part of the strategic agreement, Celgene will retain the exclusive option to acquire VentiRx.
VTX-2337 is a small molecule Toll-like receptor 8 (TLR8) agonist that stimulates myeloid dendritic cells (mDc), monocytes, and enhances natural killer (NK) cell responses. It is administered subcutaneously (SC) on a weekly basis.
Clinical stage biopharmaceutical company committed to the development and commercialization of novel Toll-like receptor 8 (TLR8) immunotherapies for the treatment of cancer, respiratory and inflammatory diseases.
Privately held organization with operations in Seattle, Washington

item.title: First Ph3 Results of Botox Vs Placebo for Crow's Feet Lines (CFL)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: According to study results presented at the American Society for Dermatologic Surgery's Annual Meeting (Atlanta, USA), all primary and secondary endpoints were achieved. On the competitive front, Revance is to start a Ph3 with its topical toxin by the end of 2012 / early 2013.
Carruthers A. “Efficacy and Safety of OnabotulinumtoxinA for the Treatment of Crow’s Feet Lines.” Presented at: American Society for Dermatologic Surgery 2012 Annual Meeting; Oct.11-15, Atlanta.
Primary outcome measures
  • Severity of Crow's Feet Lines at maximum smile using the Facial Wrinkle Scale.
Secondary outcome measures
  • Investigator's assessment of the severity of Crow's Feet Lines at rest using the Facial Wrinkle Scale [ Time Frame: Day 30 ] [ Designated as safety issue: No ]
  • Subject's Global Assessment of change in appearance of Crow's Feet Lines [ Time Frame: Day 30 ] [ Designated as safety issue: No ]
  • Subject's assessment of facial appearance [ Time Frame: Day 30 ] [ Designated as safety issue: No ].
- Recruitment: 445 patients (mean age 46.4 years) with moderate-to-severe crow's feet lines at maximum smile.
Protocol
  • 222 patients received Botox (24U; 3 inj/side; 4U/inj site)
  • 223 patients received placebo
Visits: 1 and 2 weeks and 30,60,90,120 and 150 days

Comments
Please be informed that Dr Carruthers has been the "Botox"s pioneering in aesthetic. He and his wife are very popular worldwide.

item.title: re: Cosmo to Present its Methylene Blue MMX® for Colon Diagnosis
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Cosmo to Present its Methylene Blue MMX® for Colon Diagnosis 
Comment: Methylene Blue MMX® (for the diagnosis of lesions, polyps and adenomas in the colon) will be presented to approx. 500 specialists from around the world during the International Meeting for Advanced Gastroenterology Endoscopy at Humanitas Hospital in Milano/Italy. The Methylene blue-MMX® tablet, currently assessed in Ph2, is an oral colon-release formulation in form of coated tablets, containing methylene blue. The company expects market entry end 2013.  ...
According to the company, the Ph3 trials should end no later than H2 2013. Approx. 1500 patients will be screened, the majority of these are classical colon cancer screening patients but the clinical trials program will also include patients diagnosed with active ulcerative colitis for more than 8 years.
Locations: Major North American and European hospitals
Alessandro Repici, the Head of Endoscopy Dept. at Istituto Clinico Humanitas said: “If the excellent results we saw in this clinical trial are confirmed in the phase III trials then I am convinced that besides me, most of my colleagues on a worldwide basis will be prescribing Methylene Blue MMX® tablets to all their patients.”
Phase2 Results
Ph2 II clinical trials program for the evaluation of the polyp and adenoma detection rate in patients undergoing full colonoscopy after colonic staining with Methylene Blue MMX® tablets attained all the objectives and has generated the information required to complete the design of the phase III clinical trials.
In the tested patient population (n=96) the polyp detection rate in the whole colon was on average 1.8 polyps per patient and the adenoma detection rate was 0.9 detected adenomas per patient. Polyps were detected in 63.5% of patients, adenomas in 46.9% and serrated lesions in 27.1% of patients. According to literature, polyps are normally detected in 35% or less of patients, and according to an abstract published in 2012 by the Department of Colorectal Surgery, Digestive Disease Institute, Cleveland Clinic in Ohio USA, based on 18’003 colonoscopies, the adenoma detection was 31.5% and the serrated lesions detection rate was 20.6%.

item.title: Octreotide Fails To Benefit MBO Patients In PhIII Trial
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Disappointing results from a phIII trial with octreotide in malignant bowel obstruction has prompted Dr Currow, the study PI, to suggest that ranitidine plus dexamethosone may be a more cost-effective alternative.
Dr David Currow, Professor of Palliative & Supportive Care at Flinder University Hopsital Adelaide Australia presented the results of the study at the 19th Interanational Congress on Palliative Care
Octreotide has been used in the treatment of MBO for more than 20 years and has even been described in recent literature (Clin Rev Oncol Hematol 2012:82:388) as the the antisecretory agent of choice for MBO. It is approved for this indication in some markets and in other such as the US is used off-label.
Negative Trial
The phIII study just reported was well powered and involved 86 patients with MBO from 12 sites. Patients were randomised to receive a continuous 24-hour subcutaneous infrusion of octreotide 600 ug or placebo.
In addition, all patients received ranitidine (200mg over 24 hours), dexamethasone (8mg over 24 hours), and hydration.
The primary outcome was the number of days free of comiting in the initial 72-hour period. Secondary outcomes were Global Impression of Change Score, number of vomiting episodes, symptom control, additional medication use, nasogastric tube placement and surgery during the study period.
When the octreotide and placebo groups were compared, the number of days free of vomiting (p-0.724) was non-significant, as were all but one of the secondary outcomes.
Dr Currow is reported as saying that the new findings "put under a cloud a very expensive therapy and suggest that far less expensive therapies are as efficacious, well tolerated and importantly have a place in our clinical practice". He also noted that although there have been 3 other randomised positive trials with octreotide those have included smaller numbers of patients.
Source: 19th Interantional congress on Palliative Care Abstract D08-B.

Comments
The poster (attached) had been presented at ASCO 2012.
As mentioned by Raphael this poster has been presented at ASCO 2012 and the Medical Franchise liaised after ASCO with Dr Currow the PI of the study to get more data on it. The same data were presented again at the 19th International Congress on Palliative Care 2 weeks ago and made more noise than at ASCO with a Medscape article. The main point is that this Australian octreotide study, a double blind, placebo controlled, well designed study is negative (same effect for octreotide and placebo on the vomiting endpoint) challenging then the place of octreotide for this indication in some EU SMPC (Italy for example) and in many guidelines (US, Fr, Be, NL, UK...), the cost of the treatment being put upfront..
Within the context of our on going MBO dossier preparation with Somatuline 30mg, the Endo Medical Franchise and Clin Devpt are currently revisiting all the different studies performed with octreotide and lanreotide in MBO to illustrate similarities and differences of these studies (in terms of study population, drug formulation, endpoint, treatment duration, stage of the disease...).
This information will be shared.

item.title: re: GP Pharm's Lutrate 1M Launched in Spain
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
GP Pharm's Lutrate 1M Launched in Spain 
Comment: Thanks to E. Minguell we have learnt that   ...
Esther Minguell recently reported that the effective launching of the Spanish Lutrate 1M has been delayed due to a double price confusion that is to be clarified by the MoH in the coming days.
In July, Lutrate 1M was given the same price than Procrin Depot 3,75mg in Spain (EFP 107,09€, published in July 2012).
However, in September the EFP was modified to 85,50€ (a discount of 20%), and published in the September nomenclator.
Back in October, the price has returned to the initial approved price as of July.
Now the drug is still retained until clarification of an 'official price'.

item.title: ESMO Intelligence Part 3 - Key Developments In Hepatocellular Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Interesting data on the HCC therapeutic landscape was presented at both the Novartis symposium and during a special HCC symposium featuring the GIDEON data and Daiichi Sankyo's MET inhibitor tivantinib.
After many late-stage setbacks in the field, Novartis appeared to be positioning itself for perhaps more promising data from its mTOR inhibitor everolimus with which one phIII trial in the 2nd line advanced setting is currently underway (due to complete March 2013).
A selection of the key slides presented is shown below.
Of equal intererst was the data presented from the GIDEON trial showing the aetiological diversity in response to Sorafenib and the aetiological variability in the disease according to geographic region.
Whilst promising phII data has not always translated into good phIII efficacy in this field, at this juncture the phase II data on tivantanib does appear to suggest a promising way forward for patients in MET overexpressing tumours.

item.title: Potential Disease Modifying Therapy For Parkinson's Disease
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Proteostatis Therapeutics reportedly presented some interesting data at the recent Society for Neuroscience meeting demonstrating how small molecule inhibition of USP14 can stimulate the degredation of alpha synuclein a protein linked to progression of PD.
Proteostatis Presentation was entitled "Proteolytic degradation and clearnance of misfoled proteisn associated with neurodegenerative diseases by small molecule inhibition of Usp14
The company is advancing compounds toward lead nomination. In addition to alpha-synuclein, Usp 14 inhibition was whon to influence the degradation of other aggregation prone proteins suggesting that such agents may also have therapeutic application in Alzheimer's disease, ALS, SCA and frontotemporal dementia.
Based on its findings so far, Proteostatis intends to begin clinical development in Parkinson's disease in 2014.
Source: Pharma-E-Track

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: New CRPC Study With Tokai's galeterone
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: ClinicalTrials.gov is listing a new Ph2 study with Tokai's androgen modulator galeterone. The randomised 2 part trial will evaluate safety and efficacy in CRPC patients who have yet to receive TAK-700, ARN-509 , ketoconazole or enzalutamide as well as CRPC patients who have demonstrated progression on Zytiga.

Part 1 will confirm dose to be used in Part B of the study by assessing safety and efficacy by means PSA response. [ Time Frame: 3 months ]

Part 2 of this study will further assess efficacy of the dose of galeterone chosen in Part 1 of the study in terms of changes from baseline in PSA concentration and tumor response rate by RECIST criteria [ Time Frame: 3 months ] RECIST will be evaluated by tumor changes measurements as seen on CT/MRI.

The study will enroll 172 patients and is scheduled to start in December. Its primary completion date is June 2014. The location of the trial has yet to be specified.

ClinicalTrial Identifier: NCT01709734


Comments
Tokai has announced the treatment of the first patient in the ARMOR2 trial. With its improved new tablet formulation, ARMOR2 will provide the company with additional important insights on the clinical utility of galeterone in several distinct CRPC patient populations.
Investigators
The study is being led by co-principal investigators Bruce Montgomery, M.D., associate professor of medical oncology at the University of Washington School of Medicine and Mary-Ellen Taplin, M.D., associate professor of medicine, director of genitourinary clinical research, Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, Harvard Medical School

item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Lexicon Pharmaceutical has today announced the pricing of a public offering of its common stock which is likely to raise in aggregate net proceeds of approximately $37.2m. The public offering consists of 17,500,000 shares of its common stock at a price of $2.25 per share.
J.P. Morgan Securities and Jefferies & Company are acting as joint book-runners for the offering, with Needham & company, Stifel Nicolaus Weisel and Wedbush PacGrow Life Sciences acting as co-managers.

item.title: Intelligence Insights from the World Stroke Congress - Allergan
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan’s Post Stroke Checklist will roll out in the EU in 2013. Additional tools are being developed including a HRQoL measure and a screening tool.
Allergan’s WSC activities included a symposia entitled Improving Life After Stroke — A New Approach and three posters. No clinical data were presented. Neither Merz nor Medytox were present.
Hand-outs at the Allergan stand were in the local language (Portuguese) with only two staff which spoke English. Materials consisted of a spasticity post stroke booklet and a leaflet on 10 questions frequently asked after stroke.
It is clear that Allergan is focusing heavily on stroke support initiatives and is positioning itself as a company who is present through-out the continuum of care for a stroke survivor. Allergan is developing an arsenal of tools for patients and physicians alike which promote involvement with and action for the patient and/or the physicians. In addition to the Post Stroke Checklist (PSC), Allergan is developing a HRQoL measure for stroke survivors with spasticity and a screening tool to detect disabling spasticity in stroke survivors. Please open attachment 22 and 29 for a copy of the PSC.
Their moto is ACTS — Advancing Care for Treatment of Stroke with the strap line Advocacy, Education, Evidence.
Allergan’s approach and presentation of these initiatives have been similar to that of announcing results (of a clinical trial) so as to ‘speak’ to the audience in a clinical way even though the content is tool-based. The symposia was very professional and communicated the story of the PSC very well.
Furthermore, the imagery chosen for the handouts/background to the symposia had a local flavour (picture was taken from a sculpture of hands at the Rio De Janerio Carnival) and depicts an air of ‘togetherness’ and a wish to ‘help’ (Allergan + patients).
Symposia Summary:
Following on from the theme at WCNR 2012, Allergan’s symposia provided an update on the progress, methodology and validation of the PSC (Post-Stroke Checklist). Anthony Ward stated that the UK roll-out of the PSC should take place in January 2013 and translations for other EU countries are being finalised. Within the UK, the PSC will be distributed via Healthcare Providers and Stroke Networks. This distribution channel is expected to be utlised in the rest of the EU also.
Mobility will feature in the future in that the PSC will be delivered via an App or a web-based tool which will remind the patient of their check-up. The patient will be enticed (although not mandatory) to complete the PSC prior to an appointment so that time spent at the clinic is focused on actions and follow up.
The following slides outline the PSC rational and guiding principles along with a brief summary. A key aspect of the PSC is that is it so simple, it does not require training or additional resource from Allergan but is very helpful for the patients and the physicians
The PSC should be administered 6, 12 months post stroke and then annually thereafter although the speaker stated this can vary depending on the patient — (more frequent admission)
Methodology as to how the PSC came to fruition
Members of the Global Delphi Panel are below:
The panel of experts first defined the areas which were relevant to post stroke, these where then weighted according to importance — paying close attention that the PSC will focus on areas where there are evidence-based interventions that have the largest impact on a patients QOL but not is intended to cover every possible area. The theme of evidence based intervention was repeated through out the discussion.
This slide shows the results after the review and a second reweighing of domains
From the 40+ domains initially identified, the PSC was whittled down to 11 domains of importance and impact
The talk then moved to a review of the UK and Singapore pilot studies with the key findings from both geographies. The questions to answer included:
  • User-friendliness
  • Clinical value
  • Impact of the PSC on the patient visit
  • Patient satisfaction
Firstly, the Singapore pilot was set in the context of the Cognitive Outcomes After Stoke (COAST) study, an ongoing investigation of 400 stroke patients recruited from the acute stroke service
Methods and key outcomes of the study below:
Clinicans view of the PSC were very high as were the patients, with an added 9.2 minutes after the consultation to implement the PSC (10 mintues consulation increased to 20 min)
Unmet needs identified with the PSC with cognition ranking the highest.
Moving onto the UK pilot study, the methods and outcomes are similar to the Singapore studies (with less patients)
Like the Singapore pilot, the patient and physician satisfaction was high although it took almost double the amount of time to administerthe checklist than it did in Singapore. Consultation’s were 22.8 minutes with the PSC taking 16.5 minutes to administer.
Unmet needs in the UK also highlighted cognition as the main need to be addressed
Other observations included that the PSC items were understood by most patients at the first attempt of reading them and was relevant to the stroke patient
Anthony Ward then continued with a case study — a female stroke survivor (63yrs) whose mobility had further deteriorated and reverted back to walking with a quadripod but had not reported these issues to anyone as she thought it was a natural outcome of stroke
The patient underwent the PSC and her unmet needs were identified and she was then referred to the North Staff’s Spasticity Service for assessment. Anthony Ward highlighted that the PSC helps patients who might ‘fall through the net’ and enables them to maintain, in this patients case, her QOL.
Anthony closed his session with a reminder of UP/LL spasticity but did not mention BOTOX as a treatment
The session was then wrapped up by Stephen Davis who concluded that the
  • PSC is a simple and east to use tool with a strong content validity
  • PSC is able to identify a wide range of unmet needs for stroke survivors
  • Clinicians and patients expresses a high overall satisfaction with the PSC
  • PSC was generally well understood
The PSC global implementation plan is outlined below
Poster Review: Continuing with the support initiatives, two additional tools are being designed and validated, both are in the first rounds of formalization and will continue to evolve over the coming months
Poster: Conceptual design and content validation of a HR-QOL Measure for Stroke Survivors With Spasticity
  • Objective is to develop a multidimensional HRQoL that 1) assess the impact of PSS on the lives of stroke survivors 2)measures changes in the HRQoL as a result of the clinicians intervention
  • Conclusions: The HRQoL domains and concepts identified provide for an in-depth and multidimensional description of the impact of spasticity on the lives of a stroke survivors
  • Although all impact concepts relevant to a general population of stroke survivors with spasticity were observed, additional qualitative work may be required to clearly distinguish the subsets of concepts relevant to patients with UL/LL involvement
  • Next steps will be to assess the draft item pool for readability and comprehension through patient cognitive interviews and examine the resulting scale in assessing the impact of spasticity on the HRQoL of stroke survivors
Poster: Conceptual design and content validation of a Screening Tool to Detect Disabling Spasticity in Stroke Survivors
  • Objective: to identify the conceptual dimensons and content for a screening tool able to discriminate between disabling and non-disabling spasticity in stroke survivors
  • Conclusions: Stroke survivors with spasticity provided a robust matrix of PSS symptoms that will be used to design a screening tool to detect disabling spasticity
  • Additional qualitative work may be required to capture all symptoms concepts relevant to patients with PSS
  • Further measurement design activites will select those items for the final measure that best discriminates between strok survivors with disabling spasticity and those with non disabling spasticity
· Poster: The PSC, a tool for standardizing long term patient follow-up
  • Poster highlights are captured in the Symposia detailed above
Other intelligence collected at the congress:
· Allergan: Further confirmation that the CP trials were underway but no additional intell was forthcoming
· Merz: LL studies are now recruiting children in Eastern Europe. Thank you to Jovita Balcaitiene for this insight.
· International Guidelines: have stalled due to the participants wanting additional companies/organisations involved (not only Allergan). The hope is to have guidelines formalized by the next two years.

item.title: More Details on Medy-Tox' New Factory
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The aims of the brand new factory in Osong is to meet EU and US production standards. The construction started last June, and is expected to complete by mid-2013.
After construction is complete, the new plant is expected to commercialize new formulation of Meditoxin and be inspected by EU and US regulators before 2015.
The company expects a 10x rise in capacity by end of 2013.
Licensing-out with EU & US companies is now scheduled to begin in 2013 (previously slated for 2012).
Source: Nomura (Oct. 16, 2012) Wrinkle-free growth ahead
