item.title: Key Canadian Provinces Fund Jevtana
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: On Oct. 4th, Sanofi announced that Alberta, Ontario and Saskatchewan have reached positive reimbursement decisions for Jevtana (cabazitaxel). The drug becomes available to patients with second-line castration-resistant metastatic prostate cancer in combination with prednisone.
Clearly, as the largest and most influential province, the approval in Ontario represents the most critical outcome here for Sanofi, and it follows Jevtana's initial submission in July 2011.
The drug will be available on the New Drug Funding Program (NDFP) where costs are split between that programme and hospitals. Jevtana has so far had a mixed history on reimbursement, with significant clinical benefit offset by high costs in the eyes of many payors.
Source: Global Insight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Findings from the First Head-to-Head Comparison of Allergan's Botox and Anti-cholinergic Drugs
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: According to research led by a Duke Medicine scientist and funded by the HIH, a one-time Botox injection in the bladder worked as well as daily pills for reducing episodes of urinary incontinence (UI) in women with moderate to severe bladder incontinence.
Recruitment: 250 women with moderate to severe bladder incontinence, averaging 5 bladder leakage episodes a day.
Locations: 10 medical centers across the US
Protocol: One group received Botox injections in the bladder muscle along with 6 months of placebo pills. The other group received 6 months of anticholinergic medications and a bladder injection of harmless saline.
At the end of the active treatment phase, 70% of women reported adequate symptom control; women in both groups reporting an average of 3 fewer leakage episodes a day. Within 1 month after discontinuation of the oral regimen, significantly fewer women assigned to the pill therapy reported adequate symptom control compared to the injection group – 50% vs. 62%.
At 12 months, 25% of the anticholinergic group and 38% of the Botox group reported continued adequate control.
Women in the injection group were also twice as likely as those taking daily pills to report complete resolution of the problem - 27% vs. 13%.
Side effects: The pills caused dry mouth more frequently, and Botox injections resulted in more catheterizations and urinary tract infections.
The findings were published in the Oct. 4, 2012, issue of the New England Journal of Medicine and presented at the annual meeting of the American Urogynecologic Society.
Full text is available via an Ipsen subscription at : http://www.nejm.org/doi/pdf/10.1056/NEJMoa1208872
Source: http://www.dukehealth.org/health_library/news/botox-and-pills-for-overactive-bladder-show-similar-effect

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Regulus Raised $45M in IPO
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The $45M were raised through the sale of 11.3 million shares at $4. The company also raised $25M through the sale of 6.3 million shares at the same price to AstraZeneca (development partner of miR-33).
Regulus is currently optimizing anti-miRs in 5 distinct programs, both independently and with AstraZeneca, GlaxoSmithKline and Sanofi (see PharmaWorld10011: Leading MicroRNA Company Finalizes Two Deals).
Onco Program
Regulus’ lead program in oncology targets microRNA-21 (miR-21). Numerous scientific publications suggest that miR-21 plays an important role in the initiation and progression of cancers including liver, kidney, breast, prostate, lung and brain.
Regulus is developing oncology anti-miRs targeting miR-21 for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) because analysis of liver biopsies from HCC patients has shown that miR-21 is up-regulated approximately three-fold in tumors relative to surrounding normal liver tissues.
Pipeline
Source: Biocentury; Regulus

item.title: Aragon Raise $50M
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company has secured $50M of Series D through the venBio Fund to advance its pipeline of therapies targeting hormone-driven cancers, including ARN-509 (in Ph2 for CRPC). The financing brings the total capital raised in 2012 to $88M.
ARN-509 is currently in the Phase II portion of a Phase I/II clinical trial being conducted at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York as well as 15 other institutions across the US.
The open-label, study will determine the anti-tumor activity, safety and tolerability in patients with advanced castration-resistant prostate cancer.
venBio is the world's largest independent, strategically oriented, life sciences investment firm. It was established with a vision of creating a new model for life sciences investing with the belief that integrating all life sciences stake-holders is critical to success.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Sarepta Drug Continues To Show Benefit in Duchenne's Muscular Dystrophy
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Sarepta's updated data from its PhIIb study with eteplirsen in Duchenne muscular dystrophy was well received by the market with the stock increasing $29.94 (200%) to $44.93.
The New Data
Sarepta reported open-label extension data from its Phase IIb trial, demonstrating that high-dose eteplirsen for 48 weeks led to significantly better clinical outcomes at week 48 compared to placebo for 24 weeks followed by low- or high-dose eteplirsen for an additional 24 weeks.
The four patients in the high-dose arm had a 21 m increase in six-minute walk test (6MWT) from baseline to week 48 compared to a 68.4 m reduction for the four patients in the placebo/delayed eteplirsen group (p=0.016). The low-dose did not lead to a significant difference in 6MWT.
Both 48-week arms of eteplirsen and the placebo/delayed eteplirsen arm also led to significant mean increases in dystrophin-positive muscle fibers from baseline to week 48.
Eteplirsen is a phosphorodiamidate morpholino oligomer (PMO) targeting exon 51.
Next Steps
Sarepta plans to request an end-of-Phase IIb meeting with FDA by year end or early 2013 to discuss the design of a confirmatory trial.
Sarepta's Financial Position
Sarepta's stock has registered significant gains over the course of the year as the company has reported updated data such thatn now Sarepta's market cap is now $1 billion, up from a valuation of $78.3 million on July 23, before the initial data were reported.
Competitive Positioning
There are three drugs currently in phIII development for Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy, GSK,s drispersen, PTC Therapeutics ataluren and Takeda's idebenone.
Genzyme walked away from the PTC Therapeutics programme after spending $100m when atalulren failed a phII trial demonstrating no improvement in walking distance in Duchenne patients. Since then PTC has reported more positive data with the drug and has recently initiated a phIII development programme in patients with the nonsense mutation for Duchenne. The study which has a US and ex US arm will evaluate lung function in 208 patients with the disease. The regional goups should complete in Oct 2012 and May 2013 respectively.
Meanwhile, GSK announced in August that it had completed recruitment in its pivotal phIII trial and expects to complete the trial in July 2013 with results communicated late 2013. Takeda's phIII study with idebenone will similarly complete in late 2013.
source:www.saretpa.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Novo Nordisk to Add Staff in Emerging Markets
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Jesper Hoiland, head of international operations, has reported to Bloomberg that the company is "rapidly" hiring people in countries where it is targeting expansion, including Colombia, Egypt, Ukraine, Malaysia, Indonesia and Vietnam, which he suggested is "going to be a new mini-China".
Novo Nordisk plans to hire approx. 1000 people over the next 2 years as it looks to maintain growth in emerging markets.
To expand its reach in these countries, Novo Nordisk trains doctors to teach their peers locally. The company has created mobile clinics that travel to remote areas to screen people for diabetes and help them access treatment.

item.title: New Patent Granted to PROLOR's hGH-CTP
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company has received a notice of allowance from the USPTO for a new patent application covering its long-acting CTP-enhanced hGH. This new U.S. patent is expected to issue in the next few months.
This new patent is expected to provide additional protection for PROLOR's hGH-CTP compound, in addition to a number of CTP platform patents that have already issued.
Ph3 in adults with growth hormone deficiency (AGHF) and a Ph2 in growth hormone deficient children (PGHD) are planned for 2012.

item.title: Ph1 Study of Aeterna Zentaris' AEZS-120 is planned in 4Q 2012
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Preclinical data of the oral prostate cancer vaccine candidate were presented over the weekend at the 32nd Congress of the Société Internationale d'Urologie, which is being held in Fukuoka(Japan). The poster presentation underlined the feasibility of an oral therapeutic vaccination approach against prostate cancer.
Safety pharmacology and toxicology data suggest that the profile of AEZS 120 is similar to the approved carrier strain S. typhi Ty21a, which has already been safely applied in > 250 million doses.
Source: "Preclinical Proof of Concept and Characterization of AEZS-120, a Therapeutic Oral Prostate Cancer Vaccine Candidate Based on Live Recombinant Attenuated Salmonella", J. Fensterle, B. Bergmann, P. Schmidt, M. Teifel, J. Engel, T. Rudel, W. Goebel, and U. Rapp.

item.title: Coelho Promoted to VP Commercial Excellence at Merz Inc.
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In her new role, Hyunnah Cohelo will lead the harmonization of several critical functions, such as sales operations, market research, competitive intelligence, forecasting, and operational analytics for the company.
Jan. 2010 - Joined Merz Aesthetics as Area Business Director, East
Nov. 2009 - Joined Merz as National Sales Director, Aesthetics
Prior to joining Merz, she was Eastern Business Unit Director at OraPharma (a division of J&J) for > 8 years.
Coelho obtained her Bachelor of Science from U. of South Carolina in Columbia, SC. She also earned her Master of Business Administration with a concentration in Pharmaceutical Marketing from St Joseph's U. in Philadelphia, PA.

item.title: Sanochemia Outlicenses Tolperisone For US Market
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Sanochemia has announced today an agreement with US company Katama Pharmaceuticals covering the US & MexICan development and commercialisation of tolperisone for the treatment of painful muscle spasms and spasticity. A pivotal registration trial will be paid for by a group of venture investors with a view to commercialisation of the product in 3 to 4 years.
San Diego based Katama Pharmaceuticals is a young innovative company specialising in the development of products to treat pain disorders. It is headed by Jeff Raser, an entrepeneur who is on the board of a few companies (and is adding Sanochemia to his bow) including OrthoPro (Cystic Fibrosis company). He is supposedly the Sr. Vice President Sales and Marketing at Somaxon Pharmaceuticals.
Tolperisone is registerd and marketed in certain European markets for the treatment of neuromuscular spasms, most notably Germany and Switzerland where it has been marketed by Orion since 2007. It is available as an oral immediate and controlled release formulation and is a centrally acting non-sedating muscle relaxant. Toleprisone will be regarded as an NCE in terms of the US market and thus if approved will be able to gain market exclusivity through data protection.
The license agreement provides for milestone payments tied to development and distribution objectives, as well as revenue-dependent royalities. Sanochemia will also own a 9% share of Katama and manufacture the product for the duration of the contract with KATAMA.
The agreement with KATAMA is viewed as an important milestone for Sanochemia and the first cooperation in the course of the development and marketing of Tolperisone for the US market.
Source:www.sanochemia.de

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Update on Merz Injunction in the US
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In a PR published yesterday on its website, Allergan reported that the Court injunction on Xeomin, in facial aesthetics market, remains in place until January 9, 2013.
U.S District Judge A. J. Guilford also entered an order providing that the terms of the injunction that restrict Merz Aesthetics' ability to sell and solicit purchases of its dermal fillers, as well as the terms that restrict Merz Pharmaceuticals' ability to sell and solicit purchases of Xeomin in the therapeutic market shall remain in place until November 1, 2012.
The order follows the court’s ruling in March 2012 issuing a permanent injunction against Merz, concluding the company misappropriated important trade secrets belonging to Allergan regarding its products BOTOX® Cosmetic, BOTOX® and JUVÉDERM®.
Neurology6298: Merz Clarifies Its Position In The US Market Post Recent Court Ruling
Neurology6283: U.S Federal Court Finds in Favor of Allergan vs Merz
Source: Allergan

Ferring to Assess Degarelix in a New Phase 3 
Comment: This study will assess the safety and efficacy of Degarelix given intermittently vs continuous androgen deprivation therapy with Lupron or Degarelix in patients with prostate cancer with prior treatment failure after localized treatment.  ...
This Ph3b completed in September 2012 (18 months later than previously planned). Regarding the locations, 59 sites were involved instead of the 65 projected.
Other endpoints to be assessed is Qol in intermittent and continuous treatment.

item.title: Study - Negative Results for the IGF-1 Receptor Inhibitor MK-0646 Phase II Study in NETs
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment : No partial or complete responses were observed in 15 patients with carcinoid tumors and 10 patients with pancreatic NETs. The median progression-free survival was 4.2 months in the pancreatic NET cohort (range, 0.7-6.7 months) and 2.7 months in the carcinoid cohort (range, 2-3 months).
Rationale :Preclinical studies suggest that SSA and mTOR inhibitors exhibit antitumor activity against NETs through inhibition of IGF-1-dependent signaling, suggesting that IGF-1R inhibition may be a promising therapeutic approach. The authors of this report evaluated the safety and efficacy of the insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor inhibitor MK-0646, a fully human monoclonal antibody (MoAb) that binds to the IGF-1R in patients with metastatic, well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumors.
Treatment : 25 patients received intravenous MK-0646 10 mg/kg once weekly over 1 hour.
CONCLUSIONS: Despite a compelling preclinical rationale, MK-0646 was inactive as a single agent in well-differentiated NETs. Further studies of MK-0646 as a monotherapy in unselected NETs are unwarranted.
Reidy-Lagunes DL ; Vakiani E ; Segal MF ; Hollywood EM ; Tang LH ; Solit DB ; Pietanza MC ; Capanu M ; Saltz LB A phase 2 study of the insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor inhibitor MK-0646 in patients with metastatic, well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumors. Cancer 2012: 118(19): 4795-800

item.title: re: Cosmo to Present its Methylene Blue MMX® for Colon Diagnosis
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Cosmo to Present its Methylene Blue MMX® for Colon Diagnosis 
Comment: Methylene Blue MMX® (for the diagnosis of lesions, polyps and adenomas in the colon) will be presented to approx. 500 specialists from around the world during the International Meeting for Advanced Gastroenterology Endoscopy at Humanitas Hospital in Milano/Italy. The Methylene blue-MMX® tablet, currently assessed in Ph2, is an oral colon-release formulation in form of coated tablets, containing methylene blue. The company expects market entry end 2013.  ...
The company will start a Ph3 this month to evaluate in approx. 1000 patients, the safety and efficacy of Methylene Blue MMX® modified release tablets administered to subjects undergoing screening or surveillance colonoscopy. Primary endpoint will assess proportion of patients with at least one histologically proven adenoma found during colonoscopy.
Source: NCT01694966

item.title: Bayer and Evotec in Endometriosis Deal
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Evotec, a drug discovery alliance and development partnership company, and Bayer Pharma AG have entered into a five-year, multi-target collaboration with the goal of developing 3 clinical candidates for endometriosis. Both companies will contribute innovative drug targets and high quality technology infrastructures and will share the responsibility for early research and pre-clinical characterisation of potential clinical candidates in endometriosis.
Bayer will be responsible for any subsequent clinical development and commercialisation.
Evotec will receive €12M as an upfront payment. In total Evotec may receive pre-clinical, clinical and sales milestones of potentially up to approximately €580M, plus potential royalties of up to low double digit percent of net sales, depending on which party brought the compound to the collaboration and the successful development and approval of potential drug candidates.

item.title: Aetna Expands Coverage for Provenge in the U.S
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Health insurer Aetna will now provide coverage for patients with metastatic prostate cancer who have failed to respond to hormone therapy, and whose disease has spread to the lungs or the brain.
Previously, patients whose cancer spread to the brain or lungs were not covered. Patients whose disease has spread to the liver still are not covered.
The vaccines generated just $213.5M in 2011 (roughly half of what Dendreon had originally projected).

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: First Patient In EU Study Begins Sipuleucel-T Infusion
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The open-label study is being conducted in European men with mCRPC to describe product release parameters and report on safety in a EU population. Additional details are provided below.
Recruitment: approx. 45
Locations: 4 sites
EU - Dendreon has submitted a MAA for sipuleucel-T which is currently under review by the EMA.
US - Sipuleucel-T is approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in the U.S. for the treatment of asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic metastatic castrate resistant prostate cancer.

item.title: Teva Acquires NeuroSearch' Huntexil®
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Under the Asset Transfer Agreement, Teva will pay to NeuroSearch approximately $26M over a period of at least 6 months. Regulatory and commercialization milestone payments may result in additional funding for NeuroSearch. According to analysts at Jyske Bank, the sales price and the structure of the deal reflects the NeuroSearchs rather weak barging power derived from the lack of financial flexibilit.
Espansion of Teva's CNS development pipeline.
Teva intends to design and complete new clinical studies of Huntexil® to assess its potential for symptomatic relief of HD.
Advanced-stage clinical studies of Huntexil® conducted in the US, EU and Canada in patients with HD demonstrated a significant treatment effect on Total Motor Score [TMS]), but failed to meet the primary endpoint (Modified Total Motor score [mTMS]).
Data from the clinical studies were presented to the FDA and EMA in the first half of 2011, but were found insufficient to file for marketing approval.
Sources: Teva; Thomson One

Comment: GSK has partnered with the Tokyo-based company to discover and develop peptide therapeutics using PeptiDream's Peptide Discovery Platform System (PDPS).

item.title: AstraZeneca AKT Inhibitor to Enter Ph1 for mCRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Ph1b of AZD5363 monotherapy will assess anti-tumour activity (primary endpoints), safety, tolerability and PK. Approx. 60 participants will be included.
cODE/ NCT01692262
Start date: Oct. 2012 / Completion dates: May 2014 / August 2014
Design

AZD5363 will be investigated in patients who have progressed after chemotherapy (Part A) and in patients who have progressed before receiving chemotherapy (Part B).

Part A, Group 1 patients (naive to 2nd generation anti-hormonal therapies) will receive AZD5363 480 mg bid intermittently (4 days on/3days off). Part A, Group 2 patients (progressed after 1 or more 2nd generation anti-hormonal therapies) will receive AZD5363 320 mg bid continuously as monotherapy.

Part B will only start if there is evidence of anti-tumour activity along with AZD5363 having an acceptable safety profile in Part A. Part B will be conducted in pre-chemotherapy patients on a dose and schedule selected from Part A.


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Intelligence from ESPE (Part4) Considerations for Ending GH Treatment
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Novo Nordisk's Symposium was dedicated on factors influencing GH treatment outcome in short children. This report will focus on Philippe Backeljauw's presentation, which outlined pathophysiological and management consideration for ending GH treament and in particular 'when not to stop therapy with GH'.
The decision to stop therapy with GH is jointly taken between patient and doctor, as well aseconomic factors such as insurance coverage. However there is no strong consensus about how and when to discontinue GH therapy. It generally depends on :
However, full maturation continues after completion of longitudinal growth :
Data from 9 studies show the effect of severe GHD in young adults taken off GH for 8 years after reaching adult height (AH). Of note, the increase in fat and LDL and the decrease in muscle mass and bone mineral density (BMD).
Major consequences induce the development of a syndrome of metabolic abnormalities and impaires QoL.
Philippe Backeljauw highlighted that :
In conclusion, he reported that for patients with GHD, somatic development is not finished at adult height achievement. During the post-pubertal transition phase, GH-deficient patients deserve re-evaluation of the GH/IGF-I axis using evidence based guidelines.
Consensus statement on the management of the GH treated adolescent in the transition to adult care - Eur J Endocrinol 2005; 152:165-170
However further research is needed to determine the appropriate timing of this evaluation, and when indicated, the best way to monitor the continuing GH treatment response, to allow for an optimized, individualized treatment approach.

item.title: MHRA Approves UK Usage of Botox For NDO
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan has announced the approval of Botox in the UK for the treatment of neurogenic detrusor overactivity due to spinal cord injury or multiples sclerosis in patients inadequately managed with anticholinergics.
In its press release, Allergan notes that approx 140,000 people in the UK are living with MS or SCI and that between 75-80% of the MS patientat and 60-80% of the SCI sufferers will experience some degree of bladder dysfunction.
Highlighted alongside the announcement, are the resutls of the PhIII Dignity programme which eveluated usage of Botox in nearly 7000 pts. The trial found that 76% of patients treated with the toxin had statistically significant reduction in urinary wetting episodes by week 6, with nearly 40% of the patients treated with 200 units dry by week 6 compared to only 9% of placebo patients.
The NDO indication is already approved and commercialised in many countries, with the UK one of the few outstanding approvals Allergan has been waiting for.
Source: www.allergan.com

item.title: Intelligence From The 15th ENEA Meeting in Vienna - Key Pasireotide Extension Data
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Thanks to Dr Dowling's coverage of the ENEA meeting we have an up-to-date account of Novartis's positioning of pasireotide for acromegaly and Cushing's disease and some interesting scientific data on Novartis's experimental approaches to NFPA.

OC05: “Long term use of pasireotide results in sustained reductions in UFC and continued improvements in signs and symptoms in patients with Cushing’s disease, presented by R. Pivonello, Italy.
  • Methods: 162 patients with persistent/recurrent or de novo Cushing’s disease and UFC ≥1.5 x ULN received pasireotide 600µg or 900µg sc bid. Patients with UFC ≤ ULN or achieving clinical benefit at month 12 were eligible for the extension.
  • Results: 58 patients entered the extension study. Among patients who completed the 24 month therapy (n=39), mean percentage change in UFC from baseline to month 24 was -62.7%. At month 24, 20/58 (34.5%) patients had UFC ≤ ULN. Similarly plasma ACTH and serum cortisol decreased from baseline to month 12 and were maintained to month 24. No new patients experienced hyperglycemia AEs between 12 and 24 months.
  • Conclusion: 24-month pasireotide treatment resulted in sustained reductions in UFC, plasma ACTH and serum cortisol and improvements in signs and symptoms and these results further support the long term used of pasireotide for the treatment of Cushing’s disease.
OC06: “Clinical and Patient reported outcomes associated with Pasireotide in patients with Cushing’s disease, presented by X. Badia, Spain.
  • Results: At 6 months, 37% of patients normalised UFC, 80% of patients had a reduction in diastolic BP ≥ 5 mmHg (58%), decrease in weight ≥ 7% (42%) or had improvement ≥ MID on CushingQoL (46%) (mean SD 11.1 ± 15.2) Improvements in symptoms and HRQoL were maintained at 12 months.
  • Conclusion: Pasireotide leads to meaningful improvements in HRQoL in patients with CD.
  • Treatment for acromaegaly in 2012 and beyond was shared and presented by Annamaria Colao (Italy) and Monica Gadelha (Brazil)
  • A year in Cushing’s disease: New treatment options was shared and presented by Andre Lacroix (Canada) and Antoine Tabarin (France)

AMORE Study - (Aggressive Pituitary tumours- a multi center Observational Retrospective study of ENEA) was updated by Annamaria Colao, Italy.
MISSION Study - retrospective observational study in Cushing’s disease was updated and presented by Rosario Pivonello, Italy.

S11: Mechanism of Apoptosis Resistance in Pituitary Adenomas, presented by M C Zatelli, Italy
S12: Pituitary Stem cells during tissue (re-) modelling, presented by H Vankelecom, Belgium

S14: Vasopressin receptors in corticotropinomas: Is there a diagnostic/therapeutic role? A translational approach, presented by J Castano, Spain

item.title: Intelligence from ESPE (Part2) - Cushing Syndrome/Disease in Children
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: An update on the molecular pathogenesis and new avenues in the management were reported in a unique session dedicated to the indication. Pediatric Cushing Syndrome is a very rare clinical problem, which is associated with significant morbidity (growth failure; osteopenia; arrested puberty; obesity; fatty liver; depression) and represents diagnosis and therapeutic challenges.
The session was moderated by Helmuth Dörr (Germany) and George Chrousos (Greece).
Constantine Stratakis introduced the recent advances in the genetics of the various forms of Cushing Syndrome and presented the genetic defects causing the syndrome.
When it comes to clinical evaluation of the patients with suspected Cushing Synrome, Helen Storr highlighted that in approx. 75-80% of ped. cases, the disorder is secondary to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. Most children and adolescents have a typical cushingoid appearance. Almost all CD patients have weight gain, evidence of growth failure and short stature.
She concluded by saying that a diagnostic protocol for investigation is required which broadly follows the model for adults (series of tests, aetiology of CD).
Ashley Grossman presented the recent therapeutic advances for Cushing Syndrome in children. In cases of adrenal adenoma or carcinoma thee need to be surgically removed.
For Cushing disease, the initial treatment of choice is transsphenoidal surgery (25% failure rate). Few data exists with radiosurgery, which does not allow to see the tumour. Radiotherapy is often very effective.
When it comes to medical therapy, Dr Grossman outlined:
  • 1st choice: Metyrapone used for 20 years has a rapid onset of action and is effective in the short-term.
  • 2nde choice: Ketoconazole has a slow onset of action (rare hepatotoxicity)
  • Metyrapone and Ketoconazole may be used in combo.
  • IV etomidate has an immediate effect as being life saving where parenteral therapy is essential.
He added that mifepristone may also have its place. Pasireotide has shown to normalise cortisol levels in adult patients, although the induction of hypoglycemia is of some concerns, and is unlikely to be licensed for use in children.

item.title: Merck Serono Updated Restructuring Strategy at Bernstein Conference in London
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Last week, Dr Stefan Oschmann (Head of Pharmaceuticals) updated on the company's transformation process (2012-2018). In the near term (2012-2013), management expects stable revenue, attractive double-digit growth by emerging markets, and solid performance from Endocrinology and Fertility franchises. By 2014, €300M net cost savings will come from R&D and commercial operations (€180M).
Management reported that the lack of patent cliff provides resiliency to revenue streams.

item.title: Mallinckrodt to Acquire CNS Therapeutics for $100M
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: CNS Therapeutics currently markets Gablofen, for severe spastivcity, and has a diverse pipeline of pain and spasticity products in development. Mallinckrodt, the pharma business of Covidien, is the largest U.S. supplier of opioid pain medications and among the top 10 generic pharmaceuticals manufacturers in the U.S., based on prescriptions.
- Covidien said the deal will complement its portfolio of CNS pain and managmeent products.
- Covidien announced last December that the Company planned to spin off Mallinckrodt into a stand-alone company, a process that is expected to be completed in mid-2013.
In November 2010, the FDA approved the drug for severe spasticity, a movement disorder affecting more than 500,000 patients in the U.S. alone. It is often brought on by multiple sclerosis, cerebral palsy, spinal cord injury, brain trauma and stroke.
http://www.gablofen.com/product-info.php
Gablofen is easy to administer with ready-to-use vials and pre-filled syringes offering clear advantages over glass ampules including a reduction in both refill preparation time and the risk of medicine contamination.
The company is also developing treatments for the management of severe pain, and is collaborating with the U. of Helsinki on novel intrathecal therapies for Parkinson's disease. This research is in part funded by a grant from the Michael J. Fox Foundation.

item.title: HDAC Inhibitor Belinostat Meets Primary Endpoint in PTCL Trial
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Topotarget A/S has announced top-line data from the pivotal BELIEF trial in patients with relapsed/refractory PTCL, highlighting that the primary endpoint has been met.
BELIEF is an open-label mulitcentre safety and efficacy study evaluating intravenous belinostat.
A special protocol assessment (SPA) agreement with the FDA required the BELIEF trial to reach an objective response rate (ORR) of at least 20% and this objective was met.
The trial was initiated in December 2008 and recruitment was completed with 129 patients in September 2011. In total, the study included approximately 100 clinical centers globally
Data from the trial are being further analyzed and are expected to be communicated during the fourth quarter of 2012.

Under the terms of a 2010 license and collaboration agreement, belinostat is currently being developed jointly by Spectrum Pharmaceuticals Inc. (Spectrum) and Topotarget. Spectrum possesses the commercial rights to market belinostat in North America and India. A new drug application (NDA) for belinostat in PTCL is expected to be filed with the FDA by Spectrum in first half of 2013.

Should Spectrum receive FDA's acceptance to file the belinostat NDA, Topotarget is entitled to receive one million shares of common stock in Spectrum and a double-digit million dollar cash payment. If belinostat is approved by the FDA, Topotarget will further receive a double-digit million USD cash payment.

FDA has granted belinostat orphan drug and fast track designation for the treatment of PTCL.
Belinostat's Profile

Belinostat is a new pan-HDAC inhibitor in late-stage clinical development with more than 1,000 patients treated. Belinostat has a promising safety profile, which allows combination with traditional chemotherapy. Preclinical experiments demonstrated belinostat to be effective against multiple cancers by inhibiting cell proliferation and inducing programed cell death (apoptosis) in tumor cells. Belinostat has been tested in a number of Phase I/II clinical trials in hematological cancers and solid tumors both in mono- and combination therapy. Data from these trials have provided evidence of the anti-tumor effect of belinostat, including as monotherapy in PTCL and cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL), liver cancer, and thymoma.
Source: www.topotarget.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Intelligence from ESPE 2012 (Part1) - Developments and New Results of rhGH Drugs
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Ph1 results of Versartis’ VRS-317, the only once monthly dosing, demonstrate that single doses of VRS-317 sustained IGF-1 responses in the normal range in a dose dependent and tunable manner. The PROLOR’s once weekly Ph2 positive results now support Ph3 in adults, expected to be intiated later this year. Biopartners, which presented 2 years of Ph3 of LB03002 metabolic profile, expects a launch in 2013 (when asked about the device, a representative from the company highlighted that it is still an ongoing "challenge"). When it comes to nasal drug delivery, Critical Pharm reported they will partner CP024 to complete development and commercialization (currently the company is actively working on the optimization of its device to ensure full dose delivered).
VERSARTIS - "Safety and Tolerability of a New Long Acting Human Growth Hormone (VRS-317) in Adult GH Deficiency"
The primary objective of the Phase 1 study was to evaluate the safety and tolerability of a single subcutaneous (SC) dose of VRS-317. The 60-day, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, single-ascending dose Phase 1 trial enrolled 50 GHD adult patients in the US and EU.
Results
In the Q/A session, Dr Bright answered that 5 of 40 patients presented low titer antibody at Day60. He highlighted that the ped study is to start in a month.
Safety: AEs that were considered drug related were primarily mild and transient. There were no reported SAEs, no unexpected AEs and no injection site lipoatrophy observed during treatment. No significant post-dosing changes were observed for fasting glucose, post-prandial glucose or fasting insulin. Substantial reductions in cholesterol, triglycerides and LDL were observed in GHD patients receiving 0.80 mg/kg VRS-317.
VRS-317 was rapidly absorbed, achieving a Tmax 2-3 days after a single SC dose. The half-life of VRS-317 increased significantly (p=0.016) as a linear function of increased dose with a maximum mean terminal half-life of 131 hours at the 0.80 mg/kg dose of VRS-317.
The PD profile of VRS-317 indicated that IGF-1 was normalized in a dose-dependent manner with the duration of IGF-1 normalization increasing with dose, thus enabling up to once monthly dosing for future clinical trials.
LG LIFE SCIENCES — “Metabolic effects of LB03002, a sustained release formulation of rhGH, in children with GH deficiency”
Two years of Ph3 were presented.
The effect of the drug on glucose metabolism and lipid parameters were reported in the P1d3293 poster. The results show a metabolic profile comparable to conventional daily rhGH products. Choloesterol slightly decreased, while fasting glucose, insulin and HbA1c increased overt ime but remained within the normal range.
PROLOR — “Once-weekly, CTP-modified hGH (MOD-4023) effectively maintains IGF-1 levels within the normal range in AGHD supporting initiation of clinical development in children”
In this Ph2 trial, hGH-CTP demonstrated a good safety and tolerability profile. In addition, the study showed that only 50-65% of the cumulative weekly dose of conventional human growth hormone was required for the majority of the patients to remain within the normal range of IGF-1, a key biomarker of growth hormone activity.
The safety profile of hGH-CTP in this trial was further enhanced by the finding that it did not cause excessive IGF-1 levels in patients, nor was any IGF-I accumulation observed. An exploratory part of the study also demonstrated the potential for a twice-monthly injection regimen. hGH-CTP demonstrated a good safety and tolerability profile in these studies, with no unexpected adverse events.
CRITICAL PHARM - "Intranasal human growth hormone (CP024) induces IGF-1 in healthy volunteers"
In the Q/A session, Faron Jordan, PhD answered that antibodies ratio as well as fibrosis have not been assessed yet. When questionned on allergy reactions, he answered that mucosa secretion was reported.
Ph1 Results show that :
The drug is the 1st intranasal GH to induce IGF-1
In conclusion:

item.title: Novo Nordisk Invest Further in China
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Novo Nordisk announced it has invested an additional $100M to expand its facilities in Beijing. With this expansion, the company will ensure the full range of protein research capabilities in China.
The new, expanded facility will enable even stronger contributions from the science team in China across the range of Novo Nordisk’s protein technology, biology and pharmacology research activities.
  • Established in 1997
  • Currently approx. 130 scientists (the new site will accomodate a doubling of that number with further expansion potential).
The HQs and R&D Centre are located in Beijing, the production site is in Tianjin, and local offices are located in Shanghai, Guangzhou, Shenyang, Wuhan, Jinan, Hangzhou, Chengdu, Hong Kong and Taiwan.
Currently, Novo Nordisk employs around 3,000 people in China.
Source: Novo Nordisk

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: EMA Has Recommended 1st Medicine in EU for IBS-C
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The CMPH reported that linaclotide (guanylate cyclase-C agonist) should be authorised for adults with moderate to severe IBS with constipation. Almirall holds exclusive marketing rights for the drug in EU-27, and Mexico. Once approved, it will be marketed as Constella®.
- Statistics: IBS-C affects >20% of the population in the western world.
- Current Treatment: until now no medicines have been authorised in the EU to treat IBS-C specifically. Therapies are limited to modifying lifestyle to reduce stress or alter diet, or laxatives.
The positive recommendation is based on the efficacy and safety of linaclotide evaluated in two double‐blind, placebo‐controlled Ph3 clinical studies.
The clinical trials involved approx. 1,600 adult patients (of which more than 800 were treated with linaclotide 290 mcg).
In both trials, treatment with linaclotide resulted in statistically significant improvements in both abdominal pain/discomfort and degree of relief of IBS‐C symptoms (co‐primary endpoints), as well as complete spontaneous bowel movement frequency, stool consistency and severity of straining and bloating (secondary endpoints).
These improvements were maintained over the entire treatment period (12 and 26 weeks). The incidence of adverse events was similar in both studies, with diarrhoea being the most common adverse event in linaclotide‐treated patients.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: EU Backs Approval Of Avastin For Recurrent Ovarian Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The CHMP has adopted a positive opinion regarding the use of Avastin in combination with chemotherapy (carboplatin and gemcitabine) as a treatment for women with recurrent platinum-sensitive ovarian cancer.
Basis For Approval
Patients are said to have "platinum-sensitive" disease if their ovarian cancer returns more than six months after completion of the last platinum-based chemotherapy.
In platinum sensitive disease, Avastin demonstrated in the phIII (OCEANS study) that those women who received the combination Avastin and chemotherapy and then continued with Avastin lived significantly longer without their disease getting worse compared to those who received chemotherapy alone.
An approval for recurrent disease, would represent another milestone for Avastin following its approval last year for newly diagnosed patients.
Dosage Schedule
The recommeneded treatment schedule for the new indication is to give Avastin 15mg/kg of body weight once every 3 weeks as an intravenous infusion for 6 - 10 cycles in combination with carboplatin and gemcitabine, followed by continued use as a single agent.
Source: www.roche.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Survey Points to Little Growth in Dendreon's Provenge
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Wedbush commissioned a survey of 33 medical onco and 20 uro in the US, who treat advanced CRPC patients (mean patients treated/month= 38). Results show that a significant portion of physicians still cannot find appropriate patients for Provenge. They also cite difficulty of use and reimbursement issues. Last July, Dendreon announced Provenge sales 2.4% below the previous quarter, the restructuration of one plant, and the loss of approx. 600 jobs.
  • Objectives: to gather insight into physician awareness of new treatments for CRPC and their opinions of new therapies recently approved and still under development.
  • Physicians' practice: avrage of 16 years post-residency in their specialty.
While the majority of physicians (55%) had prescribed it, the majority of the remainder of both oncologists and urologists who had not prescribed stated that a primary reason was “no available appropriate patients.” If, at this stage of the launch of Provenge, a significant portion of physicians still cannot find appropriate patients for Provenge, we believe that our muted expectations for Provenge are justified.
Importantly, physicians foresee little increase in their use over the next 6 months.
Currently, Provenge-prescribers state they prescribe Provenge to about 18% of their patients (range 10-25% for the bottom and top quartiles), and 6 months from now, they estimated they will prescribe Provenge to about 20% of their patients (range of 5-30% for the bottom and top quartiles).
Availability of appropriate patients was chosen by 61% of physicians as the reason for a change in Provenge use.
While physicians generally are favorably disposed to Provenge’s safety and efficacy, difficulty of use and reimbursement concerns are also top-of-mind for non-prescribers. One-half to two-thirds of non-prescribers also cite difficulty of use (51% as a #1 or #2 reason) and reimbursement issues (33% each for #1 and #2 reason).

item.title: Viropharm Launches New Adrenal Insufficiency Drug The First In 50 Years
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: ViroPharma Inc has launched its new modified hydrocortisone formulation in Denmark marking the occasion with a symposium at the recent ENEA meeting. Plenadren is a new, oral, once daily hydrocortisone, modified-release tablet that is designed to better mimic the body's normal, cortisol profile, compared with standard treatment.
Key Clinical Findings

The results of a pivotal Phase II/III trial showed Plenadren to be effective and well tolerated, compared to standard treatment, demonstrating a delivery of cortisol, which is more in line with the body's own cortisol profile, thus avoiding the afternoon/evening peaks. These peaks are thought to be associated with an increased risk of morbidity and premature mortality.

Dr Anna G Nilsson, principal investigator for all Plenadren studies and consultant in endocrinology at the Sahlgrenska University Hospital, Goteborg, Sweden, said, "There is a clear need in the treatment of AI for an oral hydrocortisone replacement therapy that better resembles the body's natural cortisol production, that can be given once a day and that may improve patients' metabolic status and compliance to treatment. A new therapeutic option for the first time in 50 years, that appears to achieve this is exciting news for AI patients. The once-daily dosing schedule will help them to manage their condition in a more simple and effective way."
Plenadren's Profile

Plenadren is taken orally as a single dose in the morning and has been designed to provide a dual release pattern of hydrocortisone. The outer coating provides a high concentration of cortisol in the morning, meeting the body's requirements. The extended-release core provides a smooth cortisol release throughout the day, followed by a cortisol-free interval during the night, avoiding the unphysiological afternoon/evening peaks observed with standard treatment.

Plenadren is proven to be well tolerated with patients reporting favourable impact on quality of life compared to standard treatment, in terms of psychosocial and cognitive functioning, and psychological general well-being. In an 18-month long-term follow-up trial, 98.5% of patients rated tolerability as 'very well', 'well' or 'acceptable'.
What The Pituitary Foundation Has To Say

Pat McBride, patient support manager of The Pituitary Foundation, UK, said, "For people living with a cortisol deficiency, conventional treatment can have an impact on quality of life, with many patients struggling with peaks and troughs in their replacements as well as managing complicated regimes. The availability of Plenadren is an important step forward for patients and may help to improve the management of their condition, helping patients to more actively take part in their work, family and social commitments."
Launch Status

In November 2011, the European Commission (EC) granted European marketing authorization for Plenadren, an orphan drug for treatment of adrenal insufficiency in adults. Plenadren is not approved in the US; however, it has received orphan drug designation status in the US and has maintained orphan status in Europe.

Source: www.viropharm.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: PhII Localised Prostate Cancer Study Receives Positive Interim Safety Review
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Nymox Pharmaceuticals has reported that the Independent Data Monitoring Committee for the company's Phase II study of NX-1207 for low risk localized prostate cancer (NX03-0040) has reported a positive interim safety analysis.
The safety data represents that collected from the first group of patients to receive either a high or low dose of NX-1207 for treatment of their localized prostate cancer.

The NX-1207 dose is administered directly into the area of the prostate where the cancer has been detected. The procedure is performed by a urologist in an office setting, does not require anaesthesia, sedation, or catheterization, takes only a few minutes and involves minimal discomfort to the patient.

Patients in the study are randomly allocated to either low or high dose NX-1207 or to active surveillance (no treatment). Patients undergoing active surveillance in the trial also have the opportunity to receive NX-1207 after their trial active surveillance participation is completed.
Lead Indication Is BPH Which Is Partnered With Recordati

NX-1207 is in late stage Phase III development in the US for the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), a common condition of older men associated with growth in prostate size as men age. Phase III trial activities of NX-1207 for BPH have recently begun in Europe sponsored by Recordati S.p.A.
In the BPH studies to date, a single dose of NX-1207 has been found to produce symptomatic improvements about double that reported for currently approved BPH drugs without causing the sexual or cardiovascular side effects associated with those drugs.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Medy-Tox Registers Strong First Half Performance
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Meyd-Tox posted record-high quarterly earnings in 2Q12 with sales (Meditoxin) of W9.4bn (up 70.1% y-y), operating profit of W5.3bn (up 174.5%) and net profit of W4.6bn (up 120.3% y-y).
Sales Performance
According to Woori Securities domestic sales of Meditoxin reached W4.3bn (up 120.5% y-y) led by strong sales of therapeutic Meditoxin (commercialised in Q411).
The company's export sales growth was also robust coming in at W5.1bn (up 42.7% y-y) led by increased exports to Thailand and Hong Kong and recovering exports to Brazil and Japan. Brazilian growth is expected to be even stronger moving forward in the year. In detail exports to Asia came in at W3.9bn (up34.8% y-y) to Eastern Europe at W0.3bn up 73.5% y-y) and to other countries including Latin America at W1.0bn (up 52.7%).
Based on widening distribution Woori is forecasting 2012 sales of W39.3bn (up 81.2% y-y).
After changes in contract terms with Pacific Pharma Medy-tox started distributing Meditoxin for itself in mid-June in its local market a factor analysts will drive up domestic sales and profits in the second half of the year. This year the group has hired 15 employees to sell the product in the domestic market.
Next Generation Meditoxin
A phII trial is ongoing in Australia and expected to conclude by the year-end with plans now underway for phIII to start in 2013. The group is still aiming for approval in developed countries in 2015 and launch in 2016. It will invest W40bn in a new manufacturing plant over 2012/2013 to support this development. The analysts claim that Medy-tox's new product is drawing much attention from foreign firms increasing its chances of forging a strategic partnership with an overseas partner.
Source: Tongyang & Woori Securities Reports

Comments
Comment: Thanks to Il-Ok Kim (Korea) we have learnt that as of Sept 24th, Medy-tox was granted approval in Korea for the use of Meditoxin (50, 100 & 200 Units) for adult post stroke upper arm spasticity, strengthening its therapeutic toxin label in this market.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Baxter Acquires EU Rights to Onconova's PI3K inhibitor
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Baxter has acquired European marketing rights to Onconova's PI3K inhibitor rigosertib for the treatment of myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) and pancreatic cancer in a deal valued at $565m, the former representing a good strategic fit alongside the group's hemophilia franchise.
Deal Terms
Baxter will make an upfront payment of $50m with further payments of $515m agreed on the basis of development and regulatory milestones.
Baxter which has an existing $50m investment in Onconov also has the option to participated in the development and commercialisation of rigosertib in other indications.
Rigosertib's Development Status
Results from a phIII study of injectable rigosertib in 270 patients with MDS who have failed or relaspsed after receiving existing therapeutic options are expected in the second half of 2013.
A phII/III combination study in patients with previously untreated metastatic pancreatic cancer is also underway, whilst further back in development is an oral formulation of the drug.
Strategic Rational
Rigosertib's first indication is viewed as complimentary to Baxter's existing treatments for rare hematological conditions, namely its hemophilia business. For Baxter rigosertib provides an ideal training-wheels product. MDS represents a good fit with the existing blood business, as it relates to myeloid stem cell disorders, which affect the ability of bone marrow to produce normal, red and white cells as well as platelets.

The inability of blood stem cells to mature in the disorders mean that these cells, called blasts, either die in the bone marrow or enter the blood. MDS is often seen as a precursor to full-blown leukaemia because the more blasts are present in the body the higher likelihood of developing leukaemia.

At present the only treatments for MDS are blood transfusions, bone marrow transplants and chemotherapy. Rigosertib is being developed for patients who have failed or relapsed on these treatments, and if approved would be the first product on the market. An oral version of the drug for first-line use is in phase II trials and it is also being studied in a combination phase II/III study for metastatic pancreatic cancer.

Rigosertib also gives Baxter a way of cashing in on big pharma’s increased interest in rare diseases. It has been granted orphan drug status on both sides of the Atlantic, meaning that if and when it is approved in Europe it should slot into the existing haematological sales force with little extra cost.
Source: baxter.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: GTx To Present Data On Capesaris's MOA At ESMO
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Mitchell S. Steiner, MD, Vice-Chairman and CEO of GTx, will present data from the company’s Phase II G200707 clinical study of Capesaris providing evidence that Capesaris increases SHBG, decreases FT, and reduces serum PSA. The data will be presented on September 29th at 1pm.
In another recent Phase II clinical study conducted by GTx (G200705) in men with advanced prostate cancer who were hormone naïve, a significant reduction in free testosterone was observed in Capesaris treated subjects in comparison to those treated with Lupron®.
The Phase II clinical studies were stopped early due to an increased risk of venous thromboembolic events (VTEs) at the higher Capesaris doses used in these previous clinical studies. However, clinical data from Phase I and Phase II studies suggest that significant increases in serum SHBG, and corresponding reductions in free testosterone, can be achieved with lower (125 to 500 mg) doses of Capesaris.
GTx has therefore, initiated a new Phase II clinical trial (G200712) to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of lower doses of Capesaris to treat men with metastatic castration resistant prostate cancer.
Seventy-five men with metastatic castration resistant prostate cancer will be randomized into one of three cohorts to receive a 125 mg, 250 mg or 500 mg daily dose of Capesaris. Each arm will have 25 subjects and the enrollment will be conducted sequentially, with the 125 mg cohort being the first to be enrolled. The enrollment into the next higher dose of Capesaris will commence if an acceptable incidence of VTEs is observed among randomized patients for 30 days following enrollment of the last patient in the previous cohort. The primary endpoint will be to lower serum PSA by ≥ 50% by day 90. Other key cancer endpoints include serum PSA progression, time to progression and progression free survival in these study subjects. In addition, the study will evaluate the ability of Capesaris to treat certain estrogen deficiency side effects associated with medical castration such as hot flashes, bone loss, and insulin resistance.
Source: http://phx.corporate-ir.net/phoenix.zhtml?c=148196&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=1736387&highlight=

item.title: Generic Substitution Rates Rise in France
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The French public health insurer CNAM has revealed that generic substitution rates in the country have risen to almost 80%. According to Agence France-Presse, CNAM is confident that it is still on course to meet its target substitution rate of 85% by the end of 2012.
CNAM owes its success to a new policy whereby pharmacists are given financial incentives to implement generic substitution, and patients who refuse must pay the additional costs upfront. Patients who refuse substitution must pay the full cost of the brand name product and can then reclaim the reimbursement amount (15%, 30% or 65%, 100%) by sending off a form.
Significance
The rise in generic substitution rates is a continuation of a trend that has been taking place since June, when the substitution rate was just 72%. However, although the new reimbursement policy has been successful in driving up sales of generics, there have been a number of teething problems, with some pharmacies wrongly withholding reimbursement from patients whose prescriptions have been marked "NS" (i.e. non-substitutable) by their doctor. A limited number of drugs, such as epilepsy treatments, are also non-substitutable
Source: Global Insight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Bayer Expresses Concerns on Drug Prices
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Marijn Dekkers, Bayer's Chief Executive, said that pressure from governments to lower drug prices risk undermining medical innovation. He added that "it was easy to attack pharma companies rather than focus on more complex methods of controlling H/C costs".
Speaking a the Boston College yesterday he also indicated that pressure in the US is not as great as in Germany.
He highlighted that Bayer has "a very strong financial foundation" and "good cash flow" but is not angling for an increase in its credit rating (which is currently A-minus).

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: J&J to Create Regional Innovation Centers to Identify Acquisitions
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The 4 centres will be located in California; Boston; London; and China and will be operational in coming months. They will comprise science and technology experts and have "local deal-making capabilities, with flexibility to adapt deal structures to match the early-stage opportunity".
According to Paul Stoffels (Global Pharmaceuticals Head), the company wants to:
- strengthen significantly its capabilities to bring on board more products from the biotechnology and academic community.
- be partners when opportunities emerge in academics, during the venture capital rounds.
Areas: Immunology, oncology, and infectious diseases.
Organization: Each will have an initial staff of approx. 15 to 20 people, tasked with hunting out partnership and investment opportunities across drugs, medical devices, diagnostics and consumer health.

item.title: Gene Therapy to Enter Ph2 for Relapsed Non-Muscle Invasive Bladder Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: FKD Therapies Oy, a newly formed company specialising in advanced gene based medicines, will assess the efficacy and safety of intravesical administration of INSTILADRIN (rAd-IFN with Syn 3). Primary endpoint will evaluate the incidence of high grade-recurrence free survival following up to 4 instillations of the product.
Interferon alfa 2b protein therapy is a well-established anti-cancer therapy. Its efficacy for the treatment of bladder cancer is limited by the fact that after direct administration into the bladder, it is completely cleared within 24hrs.
Instiladrin™ is an adenoviral (Ad5) vector based gene medicine, containing the interferon alfa 2b transgene with Syn3, an excipient to improve transfection.
Administered as one dose, the adenovirus carries the interferon gene into the bladder wall cells where it is transported to the nucleus causing the interferon protein to be made intracellularly. Evidence suggests that Instiladrin™ may produce a therapeutic concentration of interferon measurable in the bladder for seven days3 killing even cells that are resistant to externally administered interferon protein.
Recruitment: approx. 40
Completion date: March 2014 /June 2014
Location: US (1 site)

item.title: Strong Support For New Life Science Venture Fund
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: New Life Science Venture Fund Longitude Venture Partners announced in a recent SEC filing that its has raised $331m for a second fund and could continue raising up to $375m.
The company's website suggests that attractive deals for Longitude are with companies developing clinically and cost-effective treatments for unmet medical needs, and platform technologies that facilitate novel product development.
It gives preference to early stage medical device and mature biotechnology companies, but will invest in companies at any stage with an average investment of $10 million to $30 million total.
Longitude’s portfolio includes several publicly traded companies such as Amarin (N, Cadence Pharmaceuticals, Corcept Therapeutics and Jazz Pharmaceuticals. It also holds stake in a number of privately held companies including diagnostic test makers CardioDx and Precision Therapeutics, and pain drug developers Collegium and Xanodyne Pharmaceuticals.
Longitude closed its $325 million inaugural fund in 2008. It’s exited a few companies recently including eyeonics to Bausch & Lomb in 2008, Ablation Frontiers to Medtronic for $225 million in 2009 and Sadra Medical to Boston Scientific for $225 million in 2010.
The firm, with offices in Menlo Park, California and Greenwich, Connecticut, joins the company of numerous others raising or closing $100 million-plus venture funds focused on health this year.
Source: www.longitudecapital.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Dicerna Presents Positive HCC Preclinical Data At the ILCA Meeting
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Results from the company’s hepatocellular cancer (HCC) program were presented at the International Liver Cancer Association (ILCA) Annual Conference held in Berlin, September 14 – 16, 2012. The data were features in three separate poster presentations at the meeting.
Background

Dicerna has identified the MYC oncogene as a primary target for RNAi intervention and will focus on HCC as its initial indication given the significant need for new treatment options for this disease.
MYC is a key regulator of oncogenic pathways and has been identified in multiple types of cancer including, HCC, breast, colorectal, gynecological and prostate, among others. However, despite being one of the earliest oncogenes identified, MYC has remained “undruggable” by small molecules and antibodies.
The Poster Data

Highlights from the posters presented at the meeting follow below:

The poster “MYC Dicer Substrate siRNA Formulated in EnCore Lipid Nanoparticle Reduces Tumor Burden in the Hep3B Orthotopic Hepatocellular Carcinoma Model,” Darren H Wong et al., demonstrates that EnCore delivered DsiRNA exhibited targeted knockdown of MYC mRNA resulting in tumor growth inhibition in a preclinical model. Additionally, MYC DsiRNA co-treatment with sorafenib, the current standard of care for late stage HCC, was well-tolerated and also resulted in significant tumor growth inhibition.

This outcome is due to MYC gene target knockdown dependent efficacy, which was demonstrated through a determination of MYC mRNA and MYC protein levels. It was further determined that a cellular protein, located downstream of MYC and dependent on MYC expression, was also reduced through the treatment. This study provides a rationale for the clinical evaluation of DsiRNA molecules against MYC, a traditionally “undruggable” target, in patients with advanced HCC.

In the poster “Dicer Substrate siRNA-Mediated Knockdown of Tumor ß -Catenin Reduces Tumor Burden in The Hep3B Orthotopic Hepatocellular Carcinoma Model,” Hank Dudek et al., DsiRNAs were developed against ß-catenin, a protein with both regulatory and structural functions and a role in human cancer. The work presented illustrates that the targeted knockdown of the ß-catenin gene in a mouse model of human HCC results in the reduction of tumor growth.

Large-scale screening was used to identify DsiRNAs that are highly potent for ß-catenin knockdown, including those that received extensive secondary modification to their properties, including immunostimulatory properties. Delivery of these DsiRNAs in EnCore particles to this orthotopic model of human HCC effectively knocked down tumor ß-catenin expression and inhibited tumor growth. The ß-catenin DsiRNAs also inhibited expression of downstream genes dependent on ß-catenin expression in tumors, including MYC, further demonstrating the capability of DsiRNAs to block the oncogenic activities of their molecular targets.

The poster “In Vivo Delivery of Multiple Independent Dicer Substrate siRNAs and Gene Silencing Using Encore-DsiRNAs In Multiple Orthotopic Liver Cancer Models And A Liver Fibrosis Model,” Sujit K. Basu et al., describes robust and generalizable in vivo delivery of DsiRNA in a series of established mouse models of human HCC and a carbon tetrachloride-induced mouse liver fibrosis model.

In the orthotopic Hep3B HCC model, EnCore particle formulations of DsiRNAs targeting either MYC, ß-catenin, or several other challenging gene targets, when administered three times per week for two weeks, resulted in up to 70 percent mRNA knockdown as well as approximately 60% tumor growth inhibition. These studies form the basis for the clinical evaluation of EnCore-DsiRNAs in liver cancer patients. The poster was selected by the ILCA editorial committee as a Top Scored Poster.

Douglas Fambrough, chief executive officer of Dicerna, said, "We were very pleased with the positive reception these findings received at the ILCA conference. MYC remains a very challenging target for pharmaceutical development when employing small molecules and antibodies. Our in vivo success targeting MYC expression with DsiRNA technology delivered via EnCore lipid nanoparticles in models of HCC suggests a significant therapeutic opportunity for this challenging disease.”
Source: www.dicerna.com
 

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: OS Advantage Remains Elusive In Pancreatic Cancer Study But Threshold Blames Trial Design
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Threshold announced yesterday that TH-302 plus gemcitabine non-significantly improved median overall survival (OS), a secondary endpoint, vs. gemcitabine alone in the Phase IIb TH-CR-404 trial to treat advanced pancreatic cancer. However, with positive previously reported PFS data the company plans with its partner to enter phIII development in the 1st line setting by the year end.
The New Data
TH-302 plus gemcitabine led to a median OS of 8.7 months in patients receiving 240 mg/m2 (p=0.827) and 9.2 months in patients receiving 340 mg/m2 (p=0.8) vs. 6.9 months in patients receiving gemcitabine alone.
Threshold claims the trial was not designed to detect a significant improvement in OS. The company added that patients who crossed over from the gemcitabine alone arm to receive gemcitabine plus TH-302 upon disease progression contributed to an increase in survival in the control arm. As such, Threshold said it believes the lack of significant OS data was partly due to the crossover design of the trial.
Previously Reported Data
In February, Threshold reported that pooled data for both doses of TH-302 plus gemcitabine met the primary endpoint of median progression-free survival vs. gemcitabine alone (5.6 vs. 3.6 months, p=0.005). The forthcoming phIII trial in the first-line setting will evaluate higher doses of TH-302.
TH-302 is a hypoxia-activated cytotoxic 2-nitroimidazole prodrug of the DNA alkylator bromoisophosphoramide mustard (Br-IPM). The drug is also being evaluated in a Phase III trial to treat soft tissue sarcoma.

item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment:

Comments
Comment: Germany's Joint Federal Committee (GBA) issued a final assessment on Signifor (Novartis's pasireotide) last week concluding that it provides only a "marginal degree of additional benefit" for patients with Cushing's disease for whom surgery has failed or is not an option. Novartis will now negotiate a price with German's statuatory health insurance funds.

item.dc:creator: spoon

Comment: Clinicaltrials.gov is listing a new observational study to collect information on patients treated for blepharospasm with incobotulinumtoxinA, abobotulinumtoxinA and onabotulinumtoxinA.
Information to be collected
  • how often patients are treated with botulinum toxin,
  • how long their treatment lasts,
  • how satisfied they are with their treatment,
  • any improvement in their symptoms with the treatment
Recruitment: approx. 150
Duration: 3 months
Location: USA (Florida; Ohio)

item.title: Merz Inc. Appoints VP Neurology
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Cynthia Schwalm will be responsible for the Merz's growing neurology business unit in the U.S., which includes the recently acquired product CUVPOSA®, an oral solution for ped. patients with chronic severe drooling associated with neuro conditions. Bill Humphries, President & CEO of Merz Inc., reported he will name his entire North American Leadership Team within the next few months.
Prior to joining Merz, Schwalm was the Senior Advisor to the Chief Executive Officer at Chimerix, Inc.
She has held various international commercial leadership and general management positions with Optimer, Eisai, Amgen, and Johnson & Johnson. Schwalm brings with her 30 years of experience in the pharmaceutical and healthcare industry, with commercialization experience in movement disorders and neurology including pain management, Alzheimer's disease, and epilepsy including Lennox Gaustaut syndrome.
Education
Schwalm obtained her Bachelor of Science in Nursing from the University of Delaware in Newark, DE. She also earned her Executive Master of Business Administration from the Wharton School of Business from the University in Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, PA. Schwalm is a member for Beth Abraham Family Health Services Board and Sarah Cannon Oncology Research Institute Board. She will be based out of the office in Greensboro, NC.
See Neurology6529: Merz Strengthens its Neuro Business in the US.

item.dc:creator: spoon

Comment: Andrew J. Grethlein will be appointed as Executive VP of Technical Operations. He will be responsible for Geron's manufacturing and quality functions as well as the development of imetelstat, and GRN1005.
  • 2010-2012 Inspirations' Executive VP and COO
  • 2008-2010 Ipsen's Senior VP of Biotechnology and Portfolio Management Team Leader for Hematology
  • 2003-2008 Tercica's Senior VP of Pharma Operations
Dr. Grethlein received his A.A. degree in liberal arts from Simon's Rock Early College, his B.S. in biotechnology from Bates College, and his M.S. and Ph.D. in chemical engineering from Michigan State University.

item.title: French Government Urges Citizens to Reduce Medicines Consumption
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: French health minister Marisol Touraine has revealed that the government wishes to encourage the population to consume fewer medicines, reports Reuters. However, in an interview on the Europe 1 radio station, Touraine emphasised the fact that it is not the government's job to evaluate medicines, and that this role must instead be undertaken by the French National Agency for Drug Safety (ANSM), which is the country's recently created independent drug regulatory body.
Touraine made her comments in the context of a discussion over savings that the healthcare service needs to make in order to help reduce public debt.
The French population's heavy consumption of medicines has fallen under the spotlight following the recent publication of a book entitled "Guide des 4,000 médicaments utiles, inutiles ou dangereux" (Guide to 4,000 Useful, Ineffective or Dangerous Medicines), which claims that half of all medicines available in France are ineffective and that 5% are potentially dangerous.
The book, written by two prominent doctors, has received widespread coverage in the French media. The issue of drug safety and efficacy has been particularly sensitive in France since the scandal involving Servier (France)'s diabetes drug Mediator (benfluorex), which was estimated to have caused hundreds of deaths.
Source: Global Insight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: re: Resminostat Demonstrates Improvement In Survival in HCC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Resminostat Demonstrates Improvement In Survival in HCC 
Comment: 4SC AG has reported additional data from the PhII Shelter trial demonstrating an improvement in overall surivival with its HDAC inhibitor resminostat in the 2nd line HCC setting. Median OS was 8 months for the resminostat /sorafenib combination is believed to the highest OS value seen in the 2nd line HCC setting. 4SC AG is reported as having ongoing partnership discussions with 3 different companies (Bayer seemingly amongst them).  ...
Interestingly, resminostat appears to dampen the increase in VEGF seen with sorafenib alone. This may turn out to be an important feature of its activity, with the potential to show the same with other VEGF pathway inhibitors.

item.title: PhIII Pasireotide Extension Data Presented At The ENEA Meeting In Vienna
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Extension data out to 18 months of treatment demonstrates that pasireotide (Signifor) maintains its efficacy profile in those switched from octreotide to pasireotide. The level of hyperglycaemia and diabetes, however, remains high at 23.5% and 16% resepctively for pasireotide LAR vs. 7.9% and 7.9% for octreotide LAR with even higher nos reporting hyperglyceamia-related AEs.
Efficacy Data
With respect to efficacy 21% of patients inadequately controlled by octreotide LAR during the core 12 months of the study acheived biochemical control 6 months after switch to pasireotide LAR compared with 2.6% of patients who were inadequately controlled on pasireotide LAR who swtiched to octreotide LAR
In the core study tumor volume decrease was fairly comparable. At month 6 after crossover tumor volume had further decreased by a mean of 18.1% (CI 13.6,33.6) and 12.3% (3.2%,21.4) from extension baseline after patients crossed over to pasireotide LAR and octreotide LAR respectively.
Safety Profile
60.5% of patients switched to pasireotide LAR reported hyperglycaemia-related AEs compared with 18.4% of patients switched to octreotide LAR, with 12.3% of patients who switched to pasireotide LAR discontinuing the study because of hyperglycaemia-related AEs compared with 0% who switched to octreotide LAR.
The full poster can be accessed through the link below.
http://novartis.medicalcongressposters.com/Default.aspx?doc=4713D
A full report on the meeting will be published on Traction in due course.
  1. ScreenCapture1.jpg  (85,3 KB)
  2. ScreenCapture2.jpg  (100,9 KB)

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Resminostat Demonstrates Improvement In Survival in HCC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: 4SC AG has reported additional data from the PhII Shelter trial demonstrating an improvement in overall surivival with its HDAC inhibitor resminostat in the 2nd line HCC setting. Median OS was 8 months for the resminostat /sorafenib combination is believed to the highest OS value seen in the 2nd line HCC setting. 4SC AG is reported as having ongoing partnership discussions with 3 different companies (Bayer seemingly amongst them).
Data from this trial will be presented this weekend at the annual meeting of the International Liver Cancer Association meeting in Berlin.
Study Design
The international, open-label, two-arm SHELTER study enrolled patients with advanced liver cancer who had shown proven radiological tumor progression under first-line therapy with the cancer drug sorafenib (Nexavar(R)). The study investigated safety and efficacy of resminostat as a monotherapy and in combination with sorafenib in this patient group with currently no approved treatment option.
Final median overall survival (OS) of 8.0 months was determined in the resminostat/sorafenib combination 'intent-to-treat' (ITT) population (n=26), i.e. all study patients who were treated with the combination of 600 mg resminostat total daily dose (TDD) and 400 mg sorafenib TDD. In the resminostat monotherapy group (ITT population, n=19), the final median OS value has been determined as 4.1 months. All presented data are subject to review upon database lock. In both study arms, resminostat has proven to be safe and well tolerated.
High Unmet Need
Given the survival expectation of advanced HCC patients after developing progressive tumour disease on this treatment is only 5.2 months and there is no approved second-line treatment, there is a particular high medical need for the development of new therapies for advanced HCC.
Competitive Landscape
The HCC area has been littered with high-profile failures (see Oncology8329: ASCO Intelligence Update - Part V - HCC) but a few promising drugs are now moving towards phIII development including, Arqule 197 (tivatonib) and Exelixis (cabozatinib) (see Oncology8459: Exelixis- Update On Pipeline Progress).

Comments
Interestingly, resminostat appears to dampen the increase in VEGF seen with sorafenib alone. This may turn out to be an important feature of its activity, with the potential to show the same with other VEGF pathway inhibitors.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Allergan's R&D Head Comments on DARPin and TEM
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Analysts at Morgan Stanley hosted Scott Whitcup at its Global Conference on September 11th. Although Whitcup was not convinced that Allergan has the right dose for Latisse (scalp hair loss), he was bullish on DARPin (wet AMD), and TEM (targeted toxin for PHN).
DARPin - Whitcup hopes to present data in late 2013 and start Ph3 by early ’2014.
TEM - Whitcup likened TEM to the discovery of mAbs. He said TEM could open up a whole new platform, much like monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) did over the last few decades. Laboratory data suggests that TEM could also be used to target other diseases, including cancer.
Dr. Whitcup has been Executive Vice President, Research and Development since July 2004 and in April 2009 became Chief Scientific Officer. Dr. Whitcup joined Allergan in 2000
