item.title: Final Version of Italian Healthcare Reform Revealed
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The draft decree on healthcare reforms, dubbed a "mini reform", prepared by Italian health minister Renato Balduzzi, has been finalised and made public, and now requires only the signature of the Italian president before it can proceed. The decree has been amended, and now comprises 15 articles, rather than the 27 in the first version. There are changes to the measures proposed relating to the pharmaceutical sector, although most of these are the same as in the original version.

Revision of National Reimbursement List

Under the revised decree, by 30 June, the Italian Medicines Agency (AIFA) will carry out a one-off review of the National Reimbursement List, and drugs that are considered therapeutically outdated, or the efficacy of which is considered insufficient in the light of evidence shown since they have been marketed, will be withdrawn from reimbursement and transferred to category "C" of the reimbursement system (non-reimbursed prescription drugs). For medicines that do not fulfil cost-effectiveness criteria, price negotiations will be carried out, and in the event of these drugs' prices not being reduced as required, they will be withdrawn from reimbursement by the end of 2013.

Off-Label Medicines

A medicine can be reimbursed for an off-label indication even if there is a reimbursed medicine available that is registered for that indication, on the condition that that it is judged by AIFA's Technical-Scientific Committee (CTS) to have a safety profile in the indication that is not inferior to the registered medicine, and if treatment with the off-label medicine is at least 50% less expensive than treatment with the registered product.

Innovative Medicines

Italy's regions and autonomous provinces must reimburse medicines judged by AIFA's CTS to have therapeutic innovation of particular relevance, irrespective of their inclusion in Regional Therapeutic Formularies or Regional Hospital Formularies. These regional formularies must be updated every six months, with copies sent to AIFA. A permanent monitoring roundtable of regional formularies is to be established by AIFA, in which regions will be included, which will discuss problems and provide guidelines on updating and harmonisation.

Administrative Procedures

Pharmaceutical companies may only apply for classification for reimbursement for a product within the Italian National Health Service after they have received marketing authorisation for the product. In the case of orphan drugs or other drugs considered to have exceptional therapeutic and social importance, subject to the CTS's assessment, these can be reimbursed before they have marketing authorisation; this also applies to medicines that are envisaged for use only within hospitals or similar structures, but does not apply to generics. Also, for generics, no classification for the purposes of reimbursement can be made until the exact date of expiry of the originator product, or the exact date of the end of the application for its supplementary protection certificate.

Requirement to Supply Sales Data

Marketing authorisation holders of reimbursed medicines are required to supply data on the sales of these medicines, according to the method foreseen in the Ministry of Health decree of 15 July 2004. In the final version of the decree, however, the measure relating to fines for breaching this regulation has been removed.

Customised Packaging

It will be possible for hospital pharmacies to prepare individual packaging for medicines, dividing existing packages into smaller units in hospitals, or for patients being treated at home; this also applies to medicines being used off-label. The regions will be able to experiment with repackaging in hospitals and for residential treatment, with the aim of eliminating waste and the risk of improper use.

Farmindustria in Talks on INN Prescribing As Branded Drugs' Sales Reportedly Down 10%

The association of innovative pharmaceutical companies in Italy, Farmindustria, has been in talks with Minister of Economic Development Corrado Passera concerning the recently implemented regulations on prescription by international non-proprietary name (INN), reports Italian news agency ANSA). The source reports Farmindustria's president Massimo Scaccabarozzi as saying that, on the basis of data received concerning the 20 days since INN prescription regulations came into force—which he concedes is only partial data—sales of branded drugs were 10% lower than in the equivalent period of 2011. Scaccabarozzi is reported as saying that it is necessary to take a step back and reflect on the situation surrounding INN prescribing, adding that he appreciates the government's willingness to discuss the situation.

Balduzzi's mini reform roused some strong reactions from the pharmaceutical industry, and although a few changes have been made to the pharmaceutical-related measures in the decree, the bulk of them remain unchanged).
Cost containment dominates the decree's pharma-related measures, as could be expected, in particular those relating to the withdrawal from reimbursement of medicines considered therapeutically outdated, insufficiently efficacious, or lacking cost effectiveness. It remains to be seen how transparent the process of selecting which medicines in the national reimbursement list fall into these categories will be; pharmaceutical companies will certainly be interested to know the criteria being applied in each case.
There are measures that are favourable to the innovative pharmaceutical sector, however: the initiative relating to the reimbursement of innovative medicines in the regions is a continuation of a long series of attempts by successive Italian governments to solve the problem of regional disparities in access to new innovative medicines. It remains to be seen how effective it will be, however, and how much co-operation it will receive from the regions, particularly those in the most financial difficulty.
Additionally, the provision that means companies can only apply for classification for the reimbursement of generics after the originator's patent or supplementary protection certificate has expired means that, in effect, the originator could have several months' extra exclusivity, because the process of classification can take some time.
Considering the fact that INN prescription came into force less than one month ago, the innovative pharmaceutical sector has several reasons to feel aggrieved with Italy's regulators at the moment; the current talks concerning the new regulation are unlikely to result in its withdrawal, however, and there is not much chance of any significant modifications to INN prescription either. For now, it seems like the innovative industry will have to make do with the concessions offered in the new decree, while generics producers are also pegged back a little with restrictions on applying for reimbursement classification.
Source: Global Insight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: German Newspaper Reports Novartis is Shifting Clinical Trials to Emerging Markets
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Novartis is shifting more of its clinical trials in Asia-Pacific, the Middle East and Africa, Handelsblatt reported, citing the company.
The newspaper reported that the number of trials rose to 44% of all Novartis trials (excepted cancer drugs).

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Zealand Starts FIM Diabetes and/or Obesity Study with its Glucagon/GLP-1 Dual Agonist
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The clinical development of ZP2929 will start with a randomized, double-blind study to evaluate the safety and tolerability of single ascending daily doses of the drug in healthy subjects.
The study will be conducted in the U.S under an IND application with the FDA.
See Endocrinology6432: Zealand and Boehringer Sign Global Agreement for T2DM and Obesity.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: European Drug Monitoring Gap Filled by European Parliament Vote
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment : The EU's drug monitoring legislation received a further boost on Tuesday September 11th, when the European Parliament voted through the additional pharmacovigilance rules that were proposed last year in the wake of the Mediator affair.
Those new rules complement the major pharmacovigilance package that was adopted in 2010 and came into effect at the beginning of July :
  • The most notable innovation is that an urgent consultation at European level is automatically triggered if a company decides not to apply to renew a marketing licence for safety reasons.
  • This is accompanied by a new obligation on companies that voluntarily withdraw a drug or do not reapply for a marketing licence. They must specifically declare if this is due to a safety concern.
  • The new rules also extend the list of medicines subject to additional monitoring - indicated by a "black symbol" on the packaging.
Sources : APM International, September 11, 2012.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Astellas' Oncology Strategy
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Last week at the Merryll Lynch Investor Conference, management highlighted the company's vision and strategy for development in oncology and urology. In the near term the company's plan is 1/to leverage expertise in urology to establish a leadership position in UroOncology, 2/to ensure successful global launch of enzalutamide (MAA submitted in June, and US launch planned this month for post-chemo setting), and 3/ to launch next month degarelix 1M (Gonax) in Japan. Mid term plan is to develop robust LCM strategies.
Sales expansion in Oncology thanks to growth of Eligard and Tarceva revenues, as well as contribution of enzalutamide.
Maximization of OAB global sales to come from the growth of Vesicare and contribution of mirabegron

item.title: Latin American Countries to Create Unified Drug-Pricing Database
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: A group of 12 Latin American nations have agreed to create a shared pricing database for drugs. According to Dow Jones Global Equity News, the 12 countries, which are all members of the Union of South American Nations, are Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Guyana, Paraguay, Peru, Surinam, Uruguay, and Venezuela, and have a combined population of 400 million people.
Significance
The construction of a unified database for the 12 Latin American countries participating in the project is significant as regional governments can increase savings on purchases and will be able to plan ahead in relation to investment policies.
The database, which was originally proposed by the Argentine government, is also aimed at helping the countries to work together with pharmaceutical companies to guarantee the safe delivery and storage of drugs. The database is a good opportunity for the 12 countries to provide transparent information on drug pricing in the country, in order to avoid manipulation from pharmaceutical companies wishing to invest in the region.
Source: Global Insight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Avon's "Revolutionary" Anti-Wrinkle Cream Makes the Buzz in the UK
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: According to an article published in the Mail Online, the £30 wrinkle cream is reported to have reduced the signs of ageing in 7 days. Some women tested said they decided against cosmetic surgery and Botox since using the cream, the firm said. A-F33 will go on sale this week.
A-F33 (Amino Fill 33) is a modified protein discovered by scientists in Princeton (US),and licensed to Avon. It is reported to boost production of collagen and elastin.
Shop Online
69 women (between 35 and 59 years old) used the Anew Clinical Pro Line Corrector Treatment cream twice a day for 11 weeks. All claimed their wrinkles had been reduced, with some improvements noticeable in a week.
Dermatologists used a 3D imaging camera to look at the skin's response and claimed the cream had thickened the epidermis. Another thest on skin cells suggested they expressed more collagen and elastin after being treated with the cream.

  2. ScreenCapture2.jpg  (39,4 KB)

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: UK Commercial Launch Of Signifor For Cushing's Disease
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Novartis Pharmaceuticals UK Limited has announced the UK launch of pasireotide (Signifor®) injection for the treatment of adult patients with Cushing’s disease for whom surgery is not an option or for whom surgery has failed.

Thanks to Gillian Doodson (UK Product Manager for Somatuline) for highlighting the announcement on the UK's NELM.

Dosage & Administration

The recommended initial dose is 0.6 mg by subcutaneous injection twice a day.

It is recommended that two months after the start of therapy, patients should be evaluated for clinical benefit and those who experience a significant reduction in urinary free cortisol levels should continue to receive the drug for as long as benefit is derived.

A dose increase to 0.9 mg may be considered based on the response to the treatment, as long as the 0.6 mg dose is well tolerated by the patient.

Importantly, patients who do not responded after two months are advised to consider discontinuing treatment. It is also suggested that in terms of the management of suspected adverse reactions at any time during treatment a temporary dose reduction should be considered.

Pricing

The basic NHS Price (excluding VAT) for 60 x 1ml ampoules of the following strengths is as follows:

• 0.3mg £2800

• 0.6mg £3240

• 0.9mg £3240

It is important to note that the dosage of Signifor for Cushing's disease is very different to that under development for acromegaly, where all studies have been undertaken with the monthly LAR formulation. As such, we do not anticipate off-label usage for acromegaly.

http://www.nelm.nhs.uk//en/NeLM-Area/News/2012---September/03/Pasireotide-Signifor-injection-launched-in-UK-for-treatment-of-Cushings-disease/

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Cold Genesys to Start Ph2/Ph3 Study for Non-Muscle Invasive Baldder Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Cold Genesys, a privately held company, acquired the rights to develop CG0070, a adenoviral vector, from Biosante. The BOND Ph2/Ph3 protocol is designed for non-muscle invasive bladder cancer patients with carcinoma-in-situ (Cis) or Cis with Ta and/or T1 who have previously failed BCG and refused cystectomy.
Primary Outcome Measures:
  • Complete Response (CR) proportion
  • Durable complete response (CR)
Recruitment: approx. 112 participants
Completion date: December 2016 / March 2017
Principal Investigator: Mxwell V. Meng, MD UCSF School of Medicine Department of Urology
Alex Yeung (President) has outlined that they will 'be searching for the right partners for clinical and manufacturing as soon as possible to ensure that the Ph3 portion of the trial will not be delayed.'
  • ASCO GU meeting (Feb 2-4, 2012) #271
  • ASCO Annual meeting (June 1-5, 2012) #4593
  • Launched in August 2010
  • Shareholders include BioSante Pharm.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Takeda Eyes Russia Expansion
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Takeda has announced the completion of its Russian pharmaceutical manufacturing state-of-the-art facility in Yaroslavl (280km from Moscow). The company has invested approx. €75M ($96M) in the 24,000m² production plant, which is expected to be fully operational by 2014. The project was initially started by Nycomed in 2009, but never achieved. Russia along with Brazil is Takeda's most important emerging market.
Takeda put a big bet on emerging markets when it bought Nycomed last year (Oncology7407: Takeda Acquires Nycomed To Expand Its European & Emerging Market Presence). Emerging markets already account for 13% of Takeda's sales, up from 3% before the Nycomed takeover.
- to outgrow rivals in the Russian market with the help of a local manufacturing facility (Oncology8436: Takeda's Strategy in Emerging Markets).
- to meet demand in Russia of Cardiomagnyl, Actovegin, and Calcium tablets.
- to defend its 7th position in Russia (by sales), and extend it (with a local production base).
IMS Health expects the Russian drugs market to grow by 11 percent annually between 2012 and 2016.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Novartis's Oncology Strategy
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Yesterday at the Morgan Stanley Investor Conference Herve Hoppenot President of Novartis Oncology highlighted some of the key products in the company's oncology portfolio and the paradigm shift in development that is occurring in terms of development of oncology therapeutics.
Hoppenot emphasised that the case fro investment in the field of oncology today in research is the fact that one can move faster than ever from early-stage research to translational medicines and from translational medicine into full development.
He highlighted LDK the group's ALK inhibitor as an example where just a few months ago the company didn't even speak about the product and where now as a result of phI testing in a well-identified group of patients, the level of acitivity seen means that the project can move from early to late-stage far faster than has ever happened before. This drug is potentially a new targeted therapy for NSCLC.
Hoppenot suggested that after a year of fairly trial and errot type research it is now entering a new phase, previously only seen with Glivec and Herceptin where products can be designed that are significant driveres of disease.
Interesting Late Stage Assets
  • HDAC Inhibitor LBH. PhIII in multiple myeloma now fully accrued
  • PKC that addresses the FLT3 mutation in AML
  • TKI which is an FGF inhibitor in PhIII for kidney cancer
  • PI3K inhibitor BKM which is starting phIII studies in breast cancer.
In terms of the full cycle management of the mTOR PI3 Kinase pathway, Hoppenot, noted that it is really the next step moving from a fairly pure mTOR inhibitor like Afinitor to a more specfic product targeting PI3 kinase and where the hypothesis can be tested that PI3K mutation can be a predictor of activity of a product. Today this is not established. He suggested that it is exactly the same logic as described with ALK and that the portfolio of PI3 kinase products - because Novartis have so many of them - three in clinical development - is likely to be very powerful.
Afinitor itself is expected to experience rapid adoption in the breast cancer setting because of its significant impact on progression of metastatic disease, a very valid enpoint where it was able to delay progression by 8-10 months.
There was no mention of pasireotide throughout the presentation.
Source: www.novartis.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Botox 'Booster' to be Launched in the UK
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: According to an article published in the Mail Online, Zytaze Supplementation, which contains a high dose of zinc combined with phytase, is promising to make the effects of Botox injections last for 30% longer. British manufacturer Eden Aesthetics says the pill is unique and can reduce the price of Botox for regular users.
Clinical trial
A recent pilot study, utilizing Zytaze demonstrated that increasing zinc levels for 4 days prior to a planned botulinum toxin injection resulted in an increase in both the treatment effect as well as duration. The study included blepharospasm, hemifacial spasm and cosmetic patients.
In a completed formal study (please see attached @3) of the pill found that 92% of patients taking Zytaze reported Botox treatments lasted for several weeks longer than normal, and also helped the jab to take effect more quickly. The duration of effect increased from 23.6% in the pilot study to be 30% in the completed formal study.
Source: Koshly JC, Sharabi SE, Feldman EM, Hollier LH, Patrinely JR, Soparkar CNS. - Effect of dietary zinc and phytase supplementation on botulinum toxin treatments - J Drugs Dermatol 2012 Apr 1; 11(4):507-12.
NHS' view : http://www.nhs.uk/news/2012/09September/Pages/botox-pill-zytaze-claims.aspx
Cost
£45 for a pack of 10 (in comparison standard zinc supplement costs approx. 8£ for a pack of 100 tablets).
Administration
5 days, 10 capsules : 25mg pills a day for 4 days prior to having Botox, and on the day they receive the jab.
Prescription
Zytaze is classed as a dietary supplement. Patient do no need a prescription.
Testimony
From Kevin Hancock (plastic surgeon, a member of the British Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgery Council): " ... we do know that zinc is crucial in helping injured patients to recover, for example burns victims, so it is fundamental in reparing tissue ... that may well be influencing the action of the Botox ..."
Neurology5218: Study: Oral Supplements Enhance Effectiveness of Botulinum Toxin Injections
Neurology5760: USA: Zytaze Now Available For Physician Dispensing.

item.title: Investigator-Sponsor Study to Assess Combination of OGX-427 and Zytiga (abiraterone)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Clinicaltrials.gov is listing a new randomized Ph2 study in approx. 74 patients with mCRPC who have PSA progression while receiving abiraterone. Primary endpoint will measure PFS.
Sponsor: Hoosier Oncology Group
PI: Christopher Sweeney, M.B., B.S. (Hoosier Oncology Group).
According to the company's presentation at the Stifel Nicolaus Annual Healthcare Conference on Sept 5, 2012 interim data might be presented at the beginning of 2014, and estimated primary endpoint results by the end of 2014.
The development program for OGX-427 aims to demonstrate inhibition of Hsp27 can lead to improved prognosis and treatment outcomes for cancer patients.

item.title: Astex' HSP90 Inhibitor Enters Ph1/Ph2 Trial for CRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: AT13387, a potent and selective non-natural product inhibitor of HSP90, is tested in patients with CRPC who are no longer responding to treatment with abiraterone and steroids. The primary objective is assessment of safety, tolerability and antitumor activity of the drug + abiraterone.
Phase 1 (Part A)
Protocol: patients will continue to receive the same doses of abiraterone and steroids received prior to entering the trial, and will be randomized to receive 1 of 2 different treatment regimens of AT13387 in combination with abiraterone acetate.
Part A will recruit >52 patients, and will establish the safety of the combination, clinical activity, and confirm biological activity by monitoring depletion of androgen receptors in tumor and Circulating Tumor Cells (CTCs) samples following treatment with the drug.
Phase 2 (Part B)
The best combination regimen in Part A will then move forward to Phase 2 (Part B) where patients will be randomized to receive either the selected treatment regimen and dose of the drug in combination with abiraterone or the drug alone.
Part B will recruit > 112 patients
Source: Astex Pharm.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Uncertainties About Costly Cancer Drugs in Norway
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Norwegian Directorate of Health (COM) has announced that it is unable to assess the eligibility of a number of costly cancer drugs for inclusion in the national guidelines for cancer treatments in Norway due to the lack of pricing information. The COM will now reach out to the Norwegian Medicines Agency (NMA) to ascertain the cost versus benefit of prostate cancer drug Zytiga (abiraterone; Janssen-Cilag, United States), Jevtana (cabazitaxel; Sanofi, France), and melanoma drug Zelboraf (vemurafenib; Roche; Switzerland).
The COM did, however, decide to amend the national guidelines for cancer treatment by recommending lung cancer drug Alimta (pemetrexed; Eli Lilly, US) for earlier intervention to improve the overall treatment outcome. Eli Lilly's drug was found to be adequately priced in relation to its clinical benefits.
The Directorate of Health in Norway did not assess Xgeva (denosumab; Amgen, US) as it was "not within the mandate to consider this drug". The drug, used for treatment of prostate cancer, was consequently priced too high to even classify for consideration.
With no precise pricing information at hand to make an informed decision about the cost versus benefit of these drugs, the Department of Health is to work closely with the NMA to obtain such information.
These cancer drugs are found to be highly expensive, with little exception, across the Nordic region and the retail price for Zytiga was found to be at USD5,283 in Finland and USD6,414 in Denmark, and Xgeva's price interestingly was found to be significantly lower, at USD583 in Denmark and USD483 on the Swedish market.
In addition, the COM drew attention to the fact that the drugs offer limited life extension for serious cancers. The tendency to reject innovative medicine at a national level will in extension hinder innovative companies in advancing their research and development capabilities.
Source: Global Insight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Exelixis- Update On Pipeline Progress
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: At the BioCentury and Thomson Reuters NewsMakers in the BIotech Industry Conference last week, Exelixis presented an update on the cabozantinib's development pipeline highlighting not only the drug's potential in medullary thyroid cancer and prostate cancer but also illustrating its potential efficacy in a number of other indications, notably hepatocellular cancer, renal cancer, melanoma and NSCLC.

item.title: GSK Announces New Business in China
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: According to China Daily, GSK is to open a new research unit in China to look at traditional Chinese medicine (TCM). The company's strategy is to integrate the existing TCM knowledge of diseases with modern drug discovery technology and clinical trial methodology.
According to Zang Jingwu (senior VP & Head of R&D China), GKS's new research unit is working with academic TCM experts in China to develop new TCM products for patients in China and the rest of the world.

item.title: re: Leading MicroRNA Company Finalizes Two Deals
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Leading MicroRNA Company Finalizes Two Deals 
Comment: Regulus Therapeutics a company founded by Alnylam Therapeutics and ISIS to focus on non-coding microRNAs has announced two deals in two days one with Biogen-Idec the other with Astra Zeneca.  ...
The company amended its IPO, and now plans to sell 4.5 million shares at $10-12 per share. An 11$ price would raise $50M, and value the company at $239M.
Regulus said several partners have expressed interest in participating in the offering. Sanofi plans to purchase up to $10M, Isis Pharm.and GSK plan to purchase up to $2M each.
Source: Biocentury

item.title: Merz Finalizes Acquisition of Pierre Fabre's Glytone(R) Filler Range
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The companies have signed a partnership agreement on the marketing of Glytone(R) products. Merz becomes owner of the global rights to Glytone(R), and the non-US rights to the 'other products of the brand'. This move reinforces Merz' strategy in the field of aesthetic dermatology.
Merz acquires the Glytone(R) range of products as well as "several accompanying dermo-cosmetic products".
Financial terms: non disclosed.
Transaction started on May 14, 2012 (please see Neurology6397: Merz Starts Negotiations to Acquier Pierre Fabre's Filler)
Belotero(R) hyaluronic acid filler, Radiesse(R), Bocouture(R).

item.title: Allergan's New Targeted Toxin to Enter Safety and Efficacy Trial for PHN
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Currently being evaluated in Ph2 for iOAB (preliminary data to be released soon), AGN-214868 (senrebotase) is planned to enter Ph2 next month for postherpetic neuralgia (PHN). Primary outcome measures will assess change from baseline in average pain intensity.
Recruitment: approx. 342 participants with PHN (with pain present for at least 9 months)
Completion date: Nov. 2014 / Aug. 2015
Protocol: 3 arms
Locations: USA (1 site); Australia (1 site)
Please click > NCT01157377 OR see Neurology5055: Allergan's Targeted Toxin to Enter Ph2 in iOAB and PHN.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Germany: Health Technology Assessment - Progress
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Industry representatives have claimed that there is still not enough evidence to suggest that Germany's early benefit assessments for new drugs is a success.
However, the GBA, the body in charge of health technology assessments said that the system, introduced under the AMNOG healthcare reform act, is so far working well and there is no need yet for further legislative reform.
The BPI, which represents small and medium-sized pharmaceutical companies in Germany claims that they have not seen enough evidence and that the transparency and the legal certainty is still somewhat unclear.
So far, 25 products have passed through the GBA and IQWiG, and all assessments were completed on time. Some 64% of the products were deemed to provide some level of added value compared to the current standard of care.
The head of the GBA Josef Hecken acknowledged that no drug had yet been deemed to provide "considerable" added benefit, the highest rating a drug can win. Four drugs were awarded a rating of "significant" additional benefit and nine drugs a "minor" additional benefit. Three drugs were awarded a level of additional benefit that was not quantifiable, while another three drugs were found to provide no additional benefit. Two of the products allocated to the "no additional benefit" category were consigned to reference price groups, meaning that the drugs will not attract a premium price.
In six cases companies failed to give the appropriate evidence which meant that no additional benefit for these products was proven, however companies can submit a new dossier to the GBA.
See PharmaWorld9761: P&R End-of-Year Review 2011 and Outlook for 2012
Source: Scrip 5 September 2012

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: J&J is Evaluating Abiraterone in Chinese Patients
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The objective of the Ph1 is to evaluate the PK of the drug after oral administration of different doses (250, 500 and 1000 mg). According to clinicaltrials.gov, the 42-day trial is expected to complete this month.
Recruitment: approx. 15 healthy Chinese male participants.
Protocol

The study consists of 3 phases: screening, open-label treatment, and follow up phases.

After screening, randomly assigned participants will receive different dose levels of abiraterone acetate (Treatment A = 250 mg; Treatment B = 500 mg; and Treatment C = 1000 mg) on Day 1 in each of the 3 treatment periods according to a randomized schedule under fasted conditions (Sequence 1 = ABC; Sequence 2 = BAC; and Sequence 3 = CBA).

Each treatment period will be separated by a washout period (period when participant is not receiving any study medication) of at least 7 days.

In the follow-up phase, study-related adverse events will be monitored by the investigator. Serial blood samples for pharmacokinetic analysis will be collected and safety will be monitored throughout the study.


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: re: First Patient Enters in Ph2 of Oncothyreon's PI-3K for Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
First Patient Enters in Ph2 of Oncothyreon's PI-3K for Prostate Cancer 
Comment: The trial is being conducted by the NCIC Clinical Trials Group (NCIC CTG), Queen's U. in Kingston (Canada). The primary endpoint of this single-arm screening trial is the proportion of patients with lack of disease progression at 12 weeks from the initiation of therapy with PX-866.  ...
Oncothyreon has announced that the ongoing Ph2 trial of PX-866 in patients with recurrent or metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer will be expanded to include an additional group of up to 25 patients whose disease has begun to progress while receiving abiraterone (Zytiga®) and prednisone.
Part A - The initial part of this trial (Part A) has enrolled approx. 36 of a planned 40 patients with progressive castration-resistant prostate cancer who have received no prior chemotherapy.
Part B - Enrollment of Part B of the trial will commence following full enrollment in Part A. Part B will enroll patients who demonstrate disease progression while receiving abiraterone as evidenced by a rising prostate specific antigen (PSA). PX-866 will be administered in addition to continuing treatment with abiraterone and prednisone. The primary endpoint of each part of this single-arm screening trial is the proportion of patients with lack of disease progression at 12 weeks from the initiation of therapy with PX-866.

item.title: Roche Looks to Emerging Markets for Growth
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: At its R&D Day on Sept. 5th, management reported it would build on its drive into personalised medicine, and keep up spending on R&D. As austerity hits EU markets, Roche is targeting growth in emerging markets.
With its diagnostics division, Roche has pioneered personalised medicine, or tailoring therapy to the genetic profile of patients.
CEO S. Schwan outlined that "... more than 60% of Roche pharma pipeline projects are coupled with the development of companion diagnostics in order to make treatments more effective".

item.title: The Formation Of A New Venture Backed Bioinformatics Company
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: As part of its restructuring measures, Merck KgAa is spinning out its bioinformatics department creating a newco Quartz Bio from which it plans to commission work of the order of Euro 2m over the next two to three years.
The new company will provide biomarker data management and exploratory biomarker analysis services and will be lead by Jerome Wojcik who previously worked in Merck Serono's bioinformatics department. The company will employ 4 scientists.
The company is the second newco created by Merck in a matter of weeks and has been formed as part of Merck's Euro 30m commitment to fund spinouts of non-core activities. Prexton Therapeutics was launched in July to develop Merck Serono's Parkinson disease programms targeting mGLuR3 &4 (see Neurology6518: Merck Serono Creates Newco To Develop Parkinson's Disease Assets).
Source: www.merck.de

item.title: re: Telotristat PhII European Data Due Mid Q3
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Telotristat PhII European Data Due Mid Q3 
Comment: Lexicon is continuing to make good progress across it broad pipeline of product programmes. A number of key data points will be reached in Q3 plus two phIII programmes will initiate before the year-end, one of these being for telotristat in carcinoid syndrome (details of which are shown below). The emphasis of the group's partnering activities remains focused on its diabetes product LX4211.  ...
Design of the Ph3 has just been published in clinicaltrials.gov. The TELESTAR randomized, placebo-controlled, parallel group, multicenter, double-blind study will enroll approx. 105 participants with carcinoid syndrome refractory to SSA therapy. Primary outcome measures will assess change from baseline in number of daily bowel movements.
Study Details NCT01677910
Timelines: Start date expected this month, with completion date in April 2015

item.title: Effect of GH Therapy in Children with Anorexia Nervosa
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Juliane Leger, principal investigator at Robert Debré Hospital (France), will be leading this new Ph2/Ph3 study to evaluate the effect of Norditropine(R) Simplexx(R) on the growth velocity (primary outcome measures) in prepubertal children (or children in early puberty) with anorexia nervosa and significant reduction of height velocity.
Start date: Sept 2012 - Completion date: Sept 2016
Recruitment: 20 participants (both genders; 8 years to 203 months)
The primary endpoint will be the linear growth rate 1 year after the start of the trial expressed in cm/1 year in the group with hGH compared to the placebo group.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Medicis Acquisition - Key Takeaways From Conference Call
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: One of the key reasons Valeant was attracted to Medicis was its excellent reputation in terms of sales and marketing. Valeant hopes to navigate the integration so that it retains this capability. That said it was keen to emphasise its own success in this area but highlight its hopes that by bringing the two companies together it will bring together the strengths of both resulting in an even more powerful sales and marketing presence in Dermatology.
Key Areas of Complimentarity
  • Solodyn and Valeant's anti-acne preparations
  • Medicisi injectable portfolio of Restylane, Perlane and Dysport and Valeant's Sculptra
  • Pro-therapy MD offerings
Impact On Geographic Revenue Mix
As a result of the transaction, an increased share of our combined revenues will come from the U.S. reflecting the fact that Medicis sales are predominantly U.S. based. After the Biovail/Valeant merger, U.S. revenues represented approximately 65% of combined revenues. However, within two years the spilt was roughly 50/50 and the goal is to continue to have roughly 50% of our revenues generated outside of the United States.
Impact On Product Mix
In addition to increasing the percentage of our business in the U.S., the transaction will also expand the dermatology segment or dermatology business globally to account for roughly 50% of Valeant's revenues.
And From A Development Perspective
Developing a more robust Late Stage Pipeline wass another key strategic driver of this transaction. Medicis strong Late Stage Pipeline which includes both Novel developments and lifecycle management programs in Aesthetics, Anti-Fungals. Despite making this statement there was an unwillingness to discuss anything about the pipeline products, their potential or contribution to the value of the deal.
Potential Cost Savings

Valeant attaches signficant importance to its ability to quickly integrate Medicis and achieve cost saving of $225m within six months of closing, highlighting its previous success with integrating both Bioavail and Demik and generating cost savings of $110.7m by the first quarter of 2012 from those two deals.
Comment on Dysport
Valeant was quizzed about whether any product might return to its original owner, Dysport being specifically mentioned. Michael Pearson Chairman and CEO stated: "No we obviously did a lot of due diligence on that area and we feel quite comfortable."
Source: www.valeant.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Valeant To Acquire Medicis To Become The No 1 Rx Dermatology Company In The US
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: US based Valeant Pharmaceuticals has agreed to buy Medicis in all cash deal valueing the company at $2.6bn. This is its 2nd acquisition in under a year aimed at building a leading dermatology business. In December 2011 it acquired Sanofi's Demik business for $422m to gain access to W/W rights to the injectable filler Sculptra.
Deal Terms & Analysts Initial Comments
Valeant will purchase Medicis outstanding common stock for $44 per share in cash representing a 39% premium to Medicis closing price on Friday.
The transaction is subject to customary closing conditions, including approval by Medicis stockholders and expiration of any applicable regulatory waiting period. Valeant expects the transaction, once completed, to be immediately accretive to Valeant's cash earnings per share. The combination is expected to yield cost synergies at an annual run rate of at least$225 millionwithin six months of closing. Valeant has secured committed financing for 100% of the transaction value fromJ.P. Morgan Chase Bank, N.A.
Morgan Stanley's report on the acquisition suggests that it is both "strategically and financially compelling". Deutsche Bank suggest that the combined company's US dematology and aesthetic business for 2012 is expected to exceed $1.7bn which likely makes it the largest domestic Rx dematology business.

Rational For The Purchase

Valeant's stated rational for the deal is to strengthen "its leadership position in the dermatology field" through the purchase of complimentary products in actinic keratosis, acne aesthetic injectables and antivirals.
Jonah Schacknai' comments note that the combined portfolio under the Medicis name will be well positioned to capitalize on the meaningful opportunities in the dermatology and aesthetic markets.
The combined company's commercial dermatology operations will be located inScottsdale, Arizonaand will operate under the name Medicis, a division of Valeant, with its dermatology research and development operations inLaval, QC,Scottsdale, AZandPetaluma, CA, and corporate support functions primarily based in New Jersey.
Company & US Dermatology Business Overview

item.title: A Potential Competitor To Botox For BPH
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Sophiris Bio Inc, a urology company developing a targeted treatment for BPH has announced data from its transrectal safety study demonstrating that the drug was well tolerated through three months potentially enabling its administration in future in the urologist's office.
What is PRX302
PRX302 is designed to be a single treatment for the long-term relief of BPH symtoms. The drug is highly targeted to prostate tissue. Delivered directly to the prostate tissue via localized injection it is activated by prostate-specific-antigen.
PRX302 has demonstrated meaningful improvements in IPSS and peak urinary flow rates in a randomised placebo controlled phIIb trial (TRIUMPH study) (see Oncology6467: Protox Data at AUA Meeting)_
Why Transrectal Administration
The primary objective of the small study which has just reported was to evaluate the safety and tolerability of delivering PRX302 via the transrectal route using TRUS versus the transperineal route which has been used in previous studies with the drug.
The decision to move to this route of administration was based on input from advisors and leading urologists treating BPH patients. This routr will allow the drug to be administered easily in a urologist office setting in a brief procedure that doesn't require catheterisation.
Allergan's BPH Development Programme
Allergan reviewed its work in the BPH area with Botox at its R&D meeting in February this year. Allergan has completed a phII dose ranging study in BPH patients and expects to move into phIII in 2013. Botox is administered transrectally in its development programme. (see Neurology6332: Allergan's R&D Day Highlights New Therapeutic Opportunities For Botox & Its Novel TEM Programme)
Source: www.sophiris.com

item.title: Update On The Stampede Trial (Systemic Therapy in Advancing or Metastatic Prostate Cancer: Evaluation of Drug Efficacy)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The STAMPEDE trial, which has been enrolling patients in the UK and Switzerland for much of the past 7 years, is rather different to typical trials. Instead of comparing a standard therapy in one treatment arm to one or two investigational therapies in other trial arms, it started out with six trial arms.
STAMPEDE is a randomized, controlled, multi-center, multi-stage, multi-arm trial that will enroll a total of about 5,000 patients taking one or more of several different therapeutic agents. What is more, it is a trial that has been able to accept addition of new trial arms over time.
The STAMPEDE trial was designed to compare outcomes of potential treatments for men with high-risk, non-metastatic (M0) or metastatic (M1) prostate cancer for whom some form of continuous androgen deprivation therapy (CAD) was now considered appropriate.
Why Is This Trial Important
It is only going to be through trials like this that we will ever have a chance to discover “the best” way to manage most men with CRPC. and mCRPC
The initial, primary goal (endpoint) of the study was to see whether any of the investigational treatments could increase overall survival for men with high-risk, non-metastatic (M0) or evidently metastatic (M1) prostate cancer compared to CAD. The secondary endpoints include things like biochemical progression-free survival (bPFS), presence of metastases, toxicities of the therapies (their side effects), the occurrence of fractures and other “skeletal-related events” (SREs), quality of life, and cost effectiveness.
Eligible patients could be enrolled and randomized to any one of the trial arms open to recruitment at a specific point in time. The trial arms are listed in the table below. All patients receive CAD; this is supplemented with standard radiotherapy for men with M0 prostate cancer. So all trial arms have a common therapeutic core and then “add on” therapeutic components are tested:
You will see that this trial assesses efficacy and safety of a number of interesting potential treatments at the same time. It has the potential to allow comparison of treatments that look like much more like “real world” therapeutic options,
As of August 1, 2012, the trial has enrolled a total of 3,300 patients. No more patients are being enrolled to trial arms D or F and recruitment to arm G was only initiated in November 2011. A further new research arm, radiotherapy to the prostate (arm H) for men with metastatic disease, will be initiated late in 2012; scientific approval has recently been granted for this.
The investigators hope to have the original research arms (B, C, and E) fully enrolled by early in 2013 and the trial should be able to provide detailed outcome data for these comparisons in 2015. Survival data for the abiraterone comparison should be known in 2017.
The trial is designed so that recruitment can be stopped early to research arms that are not looking sufficiently encouraging in terms of bPFS (because it is very unlikely that a benefit in overall survival would be seen at the end of the trial if there is no benefit earlier on for bPFS). Earlier this year, the STAMPEDE investigators published data on arms D and F showing that the combination of CAD with celecoxib, dosed at 400 mg b.i.d., appeared to show no clinical benefit compared to CAD alone. The trial’s independent data monitoring committee therefore recommended no further accrual of patients to trials arm D nor any further accrual to arm F (celecoxib plus zoledronic acid); administration of celecoxib was terminated in all patients previously assigned to these two arms of the study. This result is commensurate with data from other trials investigating the clinical effectiveness of celecoxib in advanced forms of prostate cancer (a form of treatment once thought to look promising).
Trials like the STAMPEDE study are the likely “gold standard” for comparative effectiveness research because they ought to (a) provide quicker answers than a series of separate two-arms trials and (b) allow us to do more research with the funding available. These trials have also been constructed to fit “real world” forms of therapy along with investigational forms of therapy. We can expect to see (and should probably be insisting on) more trials of this type as the range of treatments available for the management of advanced forms of prostate cancer expands. Whether such trials will ever get conducted in America, where individual choice is a key factor in how people decide to get treatment, is open to greater question. We may be relying on data from Europe and elsewhere for trials like this for a while.
However, as an example of the possible, it would be highly informative to see data from another STAMPEDE-like trial in which men with metastatic, chemotherapy-naive, castration-resistant prostate cancer could be randomized to any one of the following seven therapeutic regimens:
  • Trial arm 1: CAD + sipuleucel-T followed by enzalutamide followed by abiraterone acetate + prednisone (after failure of enzalutamide)
  • Trial arm 2: CAD + sipuleucel-T followed by abiraterone acetate + prednisone followed by enzalutamide (after failure of abiraterone acetate + prednisone)
  • Trial arm 3: CAD + enzalutamide followed by abiraterone acetate + prednisone (after failure of enzalutamide)
  • Trial arm 4: CAD + abiraterone acetate + prednisone followed by enzalutamide (after failure of abiraterone acetate + prednisone)
  • Trial arm 5: CAD + enzalutamide + abiraterone acetate + prednisone (all together)
  • Trial arm 6: CAD + enzalutamide + radium-223 (all together)
  • Trial arm 7: CAD + abiraterone acetate + prednisone + radium-223 (all together)
Following complete failure in any one of these trial arms, participants could then (perhaps) be further randomized to one of a couple of chemotherapy regimens.
The same general trial structure might also be appropriate for men with non-metastatic, castration-resistant, chemotherapy-naive prostate cancer.

item.title: re: Pfizer Initiates Novel Comparison Ph3 Study Between New Mark VII Pen and Genotropin Pen
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Pfizer Initiates Novel Comparison Ph3 Study Between New Mark VII Pen and Genotropin Pen 
Comment: The 'CHOOSE' study will assess the perception of convenience and preference between the two pens.  ...
Results of the study which will be presented at next ESPE (Sept 19-23 in Leipzig) show that both pens were considered easy to use with the majority finding the new pen (Mark VII) as easy or easier to use than the current pen.
Among those expressing a preference, the majority preferred the new pen.
Adult participants selected the new pen more often than child/parent dyads as did participants from the Eastern as opposed to Western parts of Europe.

item.title: Enzalutamide (XTANDI) Receives FDA Approval
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In a suprise early ruling (PDUFA date was November 29th), the FDA has approved the use of Medivation's (XTANDI) enalutamide for the treatment of patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer who have previously recieved docetaxel. Medivation also confirmed that the European regulators have accepted its MAA for review.
Approved Dose & Key Efficacy Data
The approved use is 160mg administered orally once daily with or without food. Treatment with XTANDI does not require concomitant steroid use, however, in the phIII AFFIRM trial 48% of patients treated with XTANDI and 46% fo patients on placebo recieved steroids.
As a recap, the AFFIRM trial demonstrated that XTANDI prolonger survival by 4.8 months compared to placebo. The median survival in the XTANDI group was 18.4 months as compared to 13.6 months in the placebo group, and XTANDI reduced the risk of death by 37% as compared to placebo. Patients had a median duration of therapy of about 8 months.
Medivation has agreed with the FDA to conduct an open-label safety study of XTANDI at its approved dose of 160 milligrams per day in 350 patients who are at high risk for seizure, with a commitment to provide study results in 2019. In addition to receiving marketing approval in the U.S.
Commercialisation
Medivation sales team will begin promoting XTANDI shortly after Labor Day and the drug should be available to patients by mid-Sept. It will share responsibility for promoting XTANDI in the U.S. with the Astellas sales team. Medivation has a team of 60 sales people whilst Astellas has about 90. Medivations' s reps have an average between 10 to 15 years of oncology sales experience, and have come from some of the most prominent companies in oncology.
The wholesale acquisition cost of XTANDI will be $7,450 for a 30-day supply. Astellas has also put programs in place to enable eligible patients to have access to XTANDI regardless of insurance status or ability to pay.
Financial Implications Of The Approval
The FDA’s approval of XTANDI and EMA’s acceptance of full review of the European marketing application for XTANDI triggered milestone payments to Medivation of $30 million and $5 million, respectively. It is required to share 10% of these milestone payments with UCLA under the terms of its license agreement and to pay a low single digit royalty on sales.
Analysts are projecting sales of around $375m in 2013 based on this approval up from $60m last year.
Source: medivation.com

item.title: Researchers Are Looking for Funds to Develop an Experimental Drug for Neuroendocrine and Prostate Cancers
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Swedish medical researchers are offering to name an experimental treatment after anyone willing to donate 1 million pounds to fund their work. The research group is developing genetically engineered viruses and T cells for cancer therapy.
Focus: prostate adenocarcinoma, neuroendocrine carcinoma and neuroblastoma.
